Bottle to pint glass
Lemon, grapefruit, grain, and syrup. Clear light amber with a thin creamy white head. Taste is lemon, grain, bubble gum, and bitterness.

Served in tulip glass from bottle. Less than 1-inch head, decent lacing. Hoppy aroma, more pine than citrus, with biscuit-like, malt warmth coming through. Pine taste, malt backbone but definitely hop-forward, and remains dry, hop-centric. Medium mouthfeel. Slightly metallic on the back/end. Long finish, lighter than used to with an IPA, especially English-style. Not bad, not my favorite.
Bottle at the Assembly Rooms, Epsom. Pours hazy orange amber with a cream head. Pine aroma. Bitter sweet finish.
(bottle) clear bright light amber colour with a small white head; aroma of tropical fruit; balanced flavour with a long light bitter finish

Transfer from BA review on 11-30-12-
 Served on tap in a 10 oz chalice glass

 Appearance – The beer is served a copper amber colored brew with a one finger white head. The head had a fair level of retention, fading over time to give a lighter amount of lacing.

 Smell – The aroma was fruity with aromas of orange, pineapple and mango as well as had a nice malty smell. Mixed with these are some hop aromas of a pine and grapefruit citrus nature.

 Taste – The taste begins with some of caramel and bready tastes with a lighter grapefruit citrus hop. As the flavor advances sweeter notes of a tropical and citrus fruit flavor come to tongue with the taste getting sweeter toward the middle. More hop flavors soon come to the tongue and take the taste to its end. A bitter pine and more bitter citrus come to the tongue, drowning out some of the sweet (but not all) and leaving a bready bitter but balanced hopped taste on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel – The body of the beer was average in terms of it creaminess/thickness with a carbonation level that was average as well. 

 Overall – A very enjoyable and drinkable IPA. One that is good for a session brew and well worth a try.

Draft. What a wonderful good beer! The dry, bitter hops are featured in every aspect from aroma, to taste, to finish. Not heavy, nor light. The fantastic hops are prominent without being isolated, even the right amount of alcohol. Just a perfect beer!

American ’single’ IPA with off-white, coarse, milky, thinnish foam and warm orange blonde colour, clear. Aroma shows citrussy American hops (most notably yellow grapefruit) but seemingly less so today than was the case years ago, tonic water, orange peel, pineapple, herbs, honey, suggestions of aniseed and cloves. Soft malty taste, citrus freshness, unripe peach, caramel touch, slowly increasing in hop bitterness and ending in a mildly citrusy, spicy, grapefruity finish, yet remaining relatively soft.  Accessible American style IPA for a larger audience - and I am convinced it has become less hoppy and more 'straightforward' than it used to be.

Draft pour. Pours a clear gold with a white head of foam. The aroma is big pine and grapefruit pith. The taste is fairly bitter and just a touch sweet. Highly carbonated. Spritzy mouthfeel. On the lighter side for an IPA.
Pours a darker amber with a bubbly head. Decent hips aroma on a malty base. Strong hops taste with a biscuity malt back. Hops aftertaste with a slightly sticky mouthfeel.
Golden orange pour with small off white head. Aroma of caramel, hops, oranges and grapefruit. Taste of caramel, malts, faint fruits and hops. Medium bodied, medium carbonation and well balanced.

December 23rd, 2012 - I blame distribution channels from keeping me and Goose Island’s keystone IPA apart for so long. It appears that everyone in the world has had the pleasure of droning a Goose Island IPA at least once, and now that it’s distribution lines include San Diego, it is easier to understand why. The marketing is aggressive, true, but it’s a solid pale ale at a good price - the same formula that popularized Sierra Nevada’s own Pale Ale. A lighter spectrum of oranges lights up in the sun, and a thinner white head ensures the drinker feels close to the beer. Pine scents and orange juice dominate the nose, and appear in varying degrees in the flavor. Mild, noble hops style flavors replace the sweetness hinted at in the nose, and a drop of grapefruit lights up the flavor all the way through a long aftertaste. The more places this appears, the better.
Pours a nice golden color with a 1 finger head. Aroma of citrus, pine, and a bit of grass. Flavor matches aroma with the addition of some sweet notes from the malt.

Där orden tar slut börjar ölet att sjunga. Ur Goose Island frigörs en strid ström av locktoner som hittar sin klangbotten långt ner i ölmagen. Fast tömmer man tillräckligt många kan den där smeksamma melodin förvandlas till en godnattvisa.

Bottle. Slightly hazy light amber with small white head and good lacing. Light roasted malts, lots of aroma hops with pine, lime, tropical fruits, apricots and some peach. Light yeast with almost funky smell. Light bready. Bit sweet at first and goes into a medium bitter hoppy finish. Medium to light bodied and slightly dry. Ok IPA. Not extremely hoppy but well balanced.

Goose Island delivers a reliably delicious IPA, milder hoppiness than others but very enjoyable. Pours a copper/ yellow orange color, just average appearance. Smell is fresh fruity hops and toasty caramel malt. Anticipates the taste which is likewise a well-balanced combination of slightly caramel maltiness and tropical and piney hoppiness. Very smooth, finishes with a pleasant hoppy aftertaste. Bitterness is light and refreshing, also reminiscent of English style ales. Very well done overall, recommended!

Bouteille. La Cervoise 91. Robe orange limpide coiffée d'une mousse écrue. Nez de caramel aux senteurs fruitées et résineuses de houblons. En bouche c'est doux et suave sur le caramel avec des notes fruitées d'orange amère, de pêche blanche et de lytchee. Finale sèche et amère. Une leçon américaine de justesse. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
35.5cl bottle, poured into a tulip glass. Lovely golden orange, with a good head. Citrus, pine, nice hop taste and aroma. Light caramel. Lovely bitterness. A smooth IPA.

Bottle from maggies grill. Pours a hazy golden orange with a small white head that lasts. Excellent lacing. Aromas of caramel with orange and some floral notes. Has a nice taste with a hoppy spice and a sticky fruity hit. Lovely
Bottle from Booths, Media City. Yellowish-gold with a thin head. Plenty of hops with a nice underlying fruitiness.
On tap at Memphis airport. Pours a copper color with white head. Balanced hoppy, slight grassy, bitter, yet solid malt backbone. Solid, but just not that great.

12oz can. 01MAR14 date. Says brewery fresh for 180 days. Not sure if I believe that, but then again im not the target audience for this one. Anyway, not too bad. Bitter and piney. More malt heavy than I prefer.
bottle, decent IPA, copperish pour, medium body. more a British take, earthy bitterness, caramel backbone. decent
Draught at an airport restaurant. The beer is a good and reliable ipa: no surprises and all good. There’s sweetness in the taste in addition to the bitterness of the hops.
Tap at Lazy Dog. Pours a transparent dark golden with a thin layer odd cream colored head. Taste of oranges and hops. Aroma of floral hops and citrus.

Bottle. Light amber white head. Nose is caramel/pine/citrus, nasal clearing. Flavour leans more toward the hops but still balanced by the caramel. Finish does have caramel but has a slight dry bite. Not sticky. Very solid version of an old school American IPA, deserves its rep as a classic. ABV is surprising, thought it was ~7%.

Bottle into a Leffe glass. Clear yellow-orange with a nice bubbly head, although it collapses fairly quickly. Zesty floral hops with a note of spice, it smells good. Crisp, fruity but dry with a certain malty biscuit too. Very good. For what is becoming a mainstream beer this manages to still be decent stuff.
Pretty good IPA from goose island. Love that they distribute everywhere now!

Aroma: Spicy, fruity, hoppy. piney, passion fruit, 
Appearance: Hazy gold body with orange tint. Medium-small off-white head. Good retention, 
Flavour: Very high bitterness. Strong hop flavours, resin, fruity, slight grassy, Medium malt sweetness. Lingering bitterness. Balanced towards bitterness. Dry finish. slight astringency
Mouthfeel: Medium body, medium-full carbonation. Creamy. Slight warming.
Overall: Very good IPA. 

330 ml bottle, poured. Thanks Andre!
14A. English IPA
light amber color with a thin white head. aroma is light citrus hops. Flavor is citrus hops and light malts.
Often the best beer available at bars, but nothing special. Pretty generic IPA.

Appearance shows a light golden amber color supporting a light dissipating head. Smell of grapefruit citrus and sweet malts. taste has a lighter malty backbone with a grassy hop flavor that end dry. Mouthfeel is light - medium with good carbonation. Not a full bodied and balanced IPA.
On tap. It’s ok. Bright citrus flavor and aroma. Nice lacing as well. A little maltier than I’d hoped, but still ok.

Dimanche 4 juillet 2021. En bouteille au Fût et à Mesure de Bordeaux. Bière de couleur jaune dorée brillante translucide avec une mousse blanche moyenne abondante ; légère rétention. Nez sur le biscuit-pain, bouche plus herbeuse, agrumes et des notes caramélisées. Amertume moyenne sèche rafraîchissante; cristalline propre ; note douce légère épicée. Corps moyen qui s'élève, texture fine, bonne carbonatation, final sèche rafraîchissante agrume. Bref, bon et même très bon ! 8-4-7-3-14 = 36

June 29, 2014. Bottle, 35.5cL. Home. A wonderful golden orange yellow beer with a medium creamy white head. Thin bubbles. Medium persistence. Good lacing. Fruity aroma (exotic fruits), resin, herbs, smoke. Intense ! Medium to heavy refreshing bitter, sharp dry, light sweet. Medium body, thin texture, fizzy carbonation, dry lasting bitter finish. Overall, beautiful, delicious (basket of fruits), good dry bitterness. 9-4-7-4-16 = 40
355 ml bottle 5.9% abv. Golden amber with huge head. Good bitternes with caramel notes. Refreshing and balanced.

BOTTLE 355ML (6 months old)

Look: clear amber/brandy, light beige frothy to creamy head.
Aroma: lots of caramel, toffee with hints of mint and a touch of resin - that’s pretty much all the hops, some malt?
Taste: sweet, strong caramel, CO2 acidity, moderate hop bitterness.

Lots of caramel, not much hops. I wonder if it is way too old.
For me, I would describe this as a moderate hops ad alcohol beer, but it does have a full flavored mouth feel. Pretty decent.

See:
Dark gold, amber/copper. 1 finger white frothy head. Lively pour. 

Smell:
Fresh, clean, grassy, citrus fruits especially grapefruit. 

Taste:
Nutty. Nowhere near as hoppy as expected with the aroma but the fruit notes and character definitely come through at the end of the sip. 

Pallet:
Medium bodied, quick thick and resin like in the mouth. Minimal carbonation, there is fizz in the mouth but very few tiny bubbles in the glass. Malty, nutty aftertaste. 


Quite a mellow American style IPA. Strong hop presence but not over powering like some. Very nice, well balanced with a surprising and pleasing nuttiness. Strong (5.9%) but sessionable, it doesn’t have an over powering bitter aftertaste, in fact the ending of each sip is very mellow and more malty than hoppy.

Bona cervesa molt equilibrada i gustosa.
Buena cerveza muy equilibrada y sabrosa.

From notes, O’Caseys, Manhattan, 6-7-14. On Tap, Poured slightly hazy golden. Aroma of flowers, lemon. Taste is nicely balanced between the sweet malt and bitter hops. Light body, smooth, nice light small bubble carbonation. Finishes with hints of oranges, lemon zest and herbs. Very nice!

Aroma: hoppy aroma, more floral than citrusy unlike the IPAs I’m used to. As it gets warmer, the caramel and baking bread aroma is more evident.

Appearance: really doesn’t look great, poured into a glass from a bottle and the head was white but not pillowy, more like broken bubbles which immediately turned into a very thin layer of head that actually had staying power.

Taste: a good medium body, not too bitter

Palate: I felt the palate was outstanding, just enough bitter to keep it interesting. Pleasant long finish. Perhaps a bit thin. It is medium bodied on the tongue but then feels light bodied on the palate.

I would drink again and again.

On tap at Iggy’s on Ludlow. Pours a cloudy copper with medium frothy white head that lasts leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is strong pine, hemp, grapefruit. Medium mouthfeel with light hop bite and grapefruit with lingering bitter finish. Very good.
Amber color , medium white head. Aroma of tropical fruits and pine. Sweet fruity taste with notes of grapefruit and notes of bread. Nice hoppy bitterness in finish. Long bitterness in aftertaste.

Pours a clear amber with a thick white head. Smells of spruce, bread, grapefruit. Taste is bitter and sweet - moderate hops giving pine and little citrus with moderate malt backing of bready sweetness.

Bottle at Piccadilly, Bodø. Pours a slightly hazy orange colour with a medium, creamy and light beige head. Fruity aroma with grapefruit, citrus and fruity hops. The flavour is also fruity with tones of peaches, oranges and more fruity hops. Has a slick mouth feel, and a medium bitterness. A very fruity and easy drinking IPA.

Couleur ambrée trouble, légère mousse dense. Nez fort de houblon floral, fruité ,orange et agrumes, note de malt. Gout fort amer de houblon floral et résineux, abricots, agrumes, note de levure. Peu de carbonation, presque cremeuse en bouche, bien ronde sur palet et longue fin amère houblonnée.

Bottle, 355 ml. Pours a pale, cloudy amber with around half a finger of soapy white head. Lacing is quite thick. Aroma of pine resin and floral hops, lemon, honey, apricot, pineapple with a backdrop of caramel malts. Malts are more present in the taste, being of a bready or yeasty nature, perhaps even with a tiny bit of cheese, though the notes of honey, citrus, pineapple and hoppy bitterness are still coming through in full force. Body is a good medium and carbonation is moderate, making for a smooth feel in the mouth. Could be a little sharper and hoppier, but other than that does everything a fine IPA should.

(On tap) Pours a clear light gold with one finger of fluffy head diminishing gradually to a thin cap, moderate lacing. Nose is bright pine and citrus hops against toasty biscuit malt. Taste follows suit, with grapefruit hops followed by mild malt and finishing with a lingering bitterness. Mouth feel is light- to medium-bodied, with low carbonation and an off-dry bitter finish.

Not bad at all. A fairly straightforward IPA, but not at all unpleasant. Easy drinking, with a pleasantly crisp texture and a decent hop profile.
Pours a orange golden color with no cloudiness and 2-3 cm of head. Heavy on the hops, grapefruit, nice mouthfeel. Medium alcohol content makes it a very good sessionable beer. Solid but not amazing.
Pours a clear golden color with white head. Hops on the front and the back end. A typical IPA.
What to say. Straight forward IPA, very friendly but authentic. Not particularly hoppy, helping create a dry finishing beer.
Deep golden pour with white head. Aroma of sweet melon, grapefruit, cereals. Flavour is the same, with decent bready malt backing. Not overly bitter, but flavourful.

355ml bottle from Vinmonopolet. Medium off-white head, medium lacing. Hazy orange/amber body. Aroma is mostly malty. Grapefruit. Slightly grassy, pretty light for an IPA. Light bitterness on the tongue. Fruity, perhaps a bit boring.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle stamped 03JAN14-BF51. So this is a few months later. Still it looks nice with its medium copper-amber pour and long lasting off-white head. The hops in the aroma are somewhat muted and the toasted biscuit malts are more forward. But that is not to say I am not getting hops at all. The body is Light to medium. The floral hops express themselves more in the taste than on the nose making this a nicely balanced hops to malts IPA.
12 oz bottle. Golden pour with a white head. Super hoppy from start to finish. Hard to taste much over the bitter. Not one I would try again.

Draft @Home Team Sports (ex ESPN) Stop 2 on a lay over in Houston to Las Vegas. Goose Island, what can you expect? Thin, weak, watery, below average. Finish is vey blah. Next. Food Pairing: Grilled Chicken & Jalapeño Bacon Sandwich.
Orange pour with a thin white head and lacing that clings solidly to the glass. Light pine and citrus aroma. Taste is citrus and light pine. Really crisp and refreshing.
Clear amber with a creamy white head. Taste is quite bitter. Aroma of marmalade. Long bitter finish. Lively carbonation.
Tap at O’Hare. Pours dark gold with a thin white head. Nose is mild earthy hops. Taste is nice hop flavor. A really nice IPA.
Clear oramge pour with a small white head. Big citrus pine and floral nose. Nice and bitter throughout with a sufficient malt backing for balance. Medium mouth with averaage carbonation. Nice
Bottle at home - poured amber with white head. Hoppy, floral aroma - long bitter finish. I liked it

Quite a fruity aroma. Brown slightly cloudy. Good head. Very bitter but slightly creamy texture.

Bottle, dark gold pour with a white head, taste starts sweet with the malt and finishes bitter with the hops, nice balance and taste

Hazy amber with a creamy white head. Good retention and good lacing. Aroma of grassy hops, orange, hint of cereal. Taste of bitter marmalade, grassy hops. Medium sweetness. Long strong bitter finish.

Très bonne IPA!
Gout prononcé des houblons, moins fleuri sur la fin mais reste agréable
Clear golden body with off-white head & excellent lace. Malt and floral aromas. Hefty malt backbone with crisp hop bitterness. Balances well
Amber color, off-white head with good lacing. Resin and peach nose, floral notes. Resin taste, fruity, malty, hint of caramel and alcohol. Moderate bitterness. Soft carbonation, medium body.

Bottle. golden with white head. Aroma is quite floral with some grapefruit and pine. Similar flavour. Medium body with a medium bitterness. All well balanced. Have drank plenty of times pre-Inbev and now post, can’t say I notice any difference, still good

Again a good beer from the yankees.

Light orange brown.Translucent/ cloudy.Lightly hoppy,sweet,floral and fresh nose.Carboniced and sweet with a medium body. Will probably buy this again.

On tap poured into a shaker. A citrus and bubblegum aroma are noticeable before the first sip with a faint floral or spicy note to it. As it settles, a toasted caramel malt aroma comes through, although nothing too strong, with a grass character as well. The oily looling, gold-yellow beer is topped by a light, white head that leaves an abundant, tight, microbubble sheet-like lace. A healthy ring is retained with a light cloud of surface coverage. This beer strikes a really nice balance between medium levels of sweetness and bitterness. A soft carbonation gives this beer a creamy smooth texture. The medium body is primarily bubblegum and citrus with a slight floral spiciness and some caramel mid-sip. It finishes clean and dry with a resin-like quality and a mellow aftertaste that combines a light, sweet citrus with a light grass and floral note that has an average, pleasant staying power.

Bottle @ home. Hazy amber body with a medium offwhite head. Lots of hopds, tropical fruit and malt in the nose and mouth along with some perfume flowery notes. Lovely, long bitter finish. Nice and refreshing ipa.

Reviewed from notes.
The appearance had a golden colored body with a small white head that immmediately died. The lacing was spotty and left no rings. There wasn’t any surfacing carbonation.
The smell was mostly floral with some pine in the background. The hops were mainly balanced with some light malts in there as well.
The taste was basically the pines and the malts with the hops coming back very faintly.
On the palate, she sat at medium, had a light carbonation, and was pretty sessionable.
Overall, this wasn’t a bad beer, but wasn’t anything spectacular but I was hoping for better.
Amber with bubbly off white head; aroma is mild hops ; Flava is mild bitter hops; feels light and very fizzy; finishes dry bitter hoppy with some tanginess

A- Pours a clear orangey color with a 1 finger, off white head.

S- Light, piney hop notes

T- Light pine, slightly bready, extremely crisp.

M- Thin to medium bodied with ample carbonation.

D- A very mild interpretation of the style but solid none the less.

Bottle at the Bankers Draft, Bedford. Amber/copper with loads of carbonation. Not so much head. I don’t care for the aroma: butter, soap and overripe apple. Taste is middle of the road sweet with a bitter tinge, short finish. Not a very enticing beer, I liked this when I was younger but not so much now.
A little hazy orange beer with a medium beige head. Fruity smell with caramel. Soft and round mouth feel, medium bodied. Grape fruity hops, caramel, toffee, bubblegum. A very nice IPA.
Fairly dark for IPA, fairly strong alochol taste, decent aroma, decent taste, not the best but far from the worst....

Bottle. Pours clear amber with a decent white head that disappears quickly leaving a thin ring and some lacing. Hints of pine and grass in the aroma. Taste is medium bitter and almost no sweetness. Average carbonation, light to medium body, flavors of grapefruit, maybe other citrus, no perceptible malt, medium texture and a solidly bitter finish that shows a sticky sweetness in the far finish.
Superbe IPA. Classiques arômes houblonnées et floraux. Belle longueur. Excellente !
bottle. Deep golden with small head. Light malt body, medium hop bitterness. Slightly above average IPA.
Bu en bouteille de 33cl, une couleur blonde très Pils et un grosse mousse, grosse attaque sur les houblons très floraux, on a aussi une seconde attaque sur les épices, un régal
Clear orange colour with white head. Aroma is very hoppy and fruity. Taste is a great combination of sweet maltiness and hoppy bitterness. Medium to full bodied with a nice kinda bittersweet finish.

Bottle - Amber Gold in colour. Very Fruity; citrus grapefruit and tangerines. Very Hoppy; piney resinous and spicy peppery hops. Malty backbone; caramel, buttery malt base. Good fruit/hop/malt balance. Rather salty. Moderately bitter citrus fruity hoppy throughout. Dry finish. Very refreshing. Nice IPA!

Clear golden with a thin foamy white head. Strong hoppy grassy aroma with a wee touch of grapefruit rind. Flavor is clean and lightly hoppy with the same grassiness and light grapefruit rind tones from the nose with a touch of floral hops at the finish. Pretty nice and floral.

Bottle from waitrose, teignmouth. Poured at about 6 degrees celsius at home

Appearance: effervescent slightly hazy amber liquid with fairly stable frothy yellow tinged head 

Aroma: Tangerine, grapefruit, pomegranate, pine, subtle hints of cherry/apple and a buttery biscuitness. Stings a little if you get it up your nose and reveals slight vinegar qualities.

Taste: hits immediately with strong bitterness that fades rapidly revealing orange zest, biscuits, cappucino, avocado, melon (and possibly over ripe banana skin). Finishes with butter, orange and biscuit.

Palate: smooth and very creamy with a pleasant thick sugaryness at the back. Good light fizz and slightly antiseptic feel.

Overall: a zesty little number, strong smell and taste of orange, that is fairly bitter to begin but develops into creamy, sweet beer that really tickled the tongue.

Bottle from Village Wine and Spirits. Clean, light caramel and fruity hops. Clear bright medium straw color with a 2cm. off-white head. Light sweetish caramel / smooth gentle hopping, with exceptional balance / light fruity finish. Not your uncle’s West coast IPA, but smooth sessionable stuff.
Very nice IPA, with a lovely orangey colour. Tastes kind of orangey to me in flavour too.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein orangegoldenes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr malzig fruchtig, hopfig grasig,. Geschmack sehr fruchtig bitter, malzige Fruchtigkeit, bitter.
Pours a light pale orange with a fluffy white head. Aromas of citrusy hops with orange peel and grapefruit peel. One of my favorite all purposes IPAs.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet, Norway. Pours light and hazy golden, with a thick white head. Faint aroma of grass and orange peels. Medium mouthfeel with a flavour of some grapefruit, pine and a moderately dry and bitter finish. Very drinkable low abv IPA, but nothing special.

Bottle. Shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: clear blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: hoppy, fruity, nice.
TASTE: fruity, dry and bitter.
Very nice IPA!
On tap - gold in color with an average head. The taste is grassy and somewhat piney. Medium body and average bitterness.

Draft. Pours a dark gold color with a brief white head leaving some nice lacing. Aroma is mostly malt with some hops but the taste brings out more of
The hops which are balanced. Clean finish, medium body. Very good!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

DATE TASTED: February 14, 2014... GLASSWARE: Corsendonk thistle...OCCASION: in between storms--with another of Dave’s Super Bowl leftovers... APPEARANCE: massive, mountainous white head that begins as an iceberg peak; consistently active, orange amber body; glass lip to beer top lacing... AROMA: aromatic floral hops; slightly malty; piques the interest...PALATE: creamy, active and warming at the throat; the modest alcohol is properly situated--a balanced mouthfeel...TASTE: powerful,, cutting, arresting--any siege-like hyperbole aptly fits; wonderfully sprucey and citric without being overbearing... OVERALL: kudos to Dave for his Super Bowl selections--both Honker’s and the IPA play well as samplings or sessionables; a big IPA that remains accessible and relatively affordable...
Pretty standard IPA. Quality brew from a quality brewery. Hoppy goodness that is balanced nicely.
Served draft in a plastic cup. Not enough aroma for my liking but easy drinking. A nice, balanced, dare I say old fashioned IPA.

355ml bottle. slightly hazy amber colour, small frothy off-white mostly lasting head, good lacing. Heavily hoppy fruity and slightly perfumey aroma of orange and herbs backed by moderate grainy malts. Taste is initially even somewhat sweet and malty, turning into a very bitter long finish with a moderate to heavy astringent feel. Medium body, initially dry and later oily mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Well above-average American craft IPA. Actually one of the best ones I tried, especially tastewise.
Valjuhko. Komea pullo, ihan mukava tuoksu. Kermainen ja hiivainen. Rappa kalja. Ja Santtu.

Pours deep amber colour with tight head. Smells of distinct sweet tropical citrus fruitiness. Taste to follow full malty Sweetness with fruity dry bitterness balance. Nicely balanced and falvourful ipa
Draft. Nice hoppy aroma. Nice copper color. Flavor has that piney aspect I’m not entirely fond of. Not bad though.
Klar gylden, tæt kompakt skum. Aroma: mørk citrus. Smag: let, lys citrus og ananas. Rigtig god bitterhed, bittersødme som harmonerer godt med medium carb og hænger ved i eftersmag.

Bottle sainsburys. Amber colour thin white head and lacing. Aroma is fruity and hops. Taste is also fruity with some sweet malts coming through and ok hop bitter finish. Medium body decent mouthfeel medium sot carbonation. Ok IPA.

This really does have a fruity aroma to it. Somewhat hoppy, but not that typical IPA taste I’m used to. Somewhat light body, with a fruity taste and a mild bitter/sour finish. Good IPA, but overrated in my opinion.
Fruity aroma. Pour red-amber with a fine White head. Taste sluger sweet, medium bitter. Great mouthfeel and a long bitter aftertaste

355ml bottle. Poured an orange-golden color with a thich white head. Aromas of pine, citrus, lots of flowers. Taste was the same with maybe some spiciness (??) . Long aftertaste, dry and bitter. Body was light (a bit too light maybe) with medium carbonation.

Tap@o’reillys, nyc. Golden color with a dense white head. Aroma has pine, grape, tropical fruits. Taste is malty bitter with very fruity finish. Flavors of citrus, tropical fruits, pine, grass. Excellent fruity touch.

0.35l bottle. 5.9%. Gold/amber color with a crisp white head. Fruity smell were you feel the hops. Some stings of yeast in the smell. Feel very light in the mouth. A bit aqueous for a IPA. Easy on the bitterness and mild. A thin fruit taste combined with a light sweet malty character. Maybe a bit thin for my taste, but great as a summer beer with a bit more taste then the normal lagers.

An easy drinking IPA, wont blow your socks off by any means but it will do in a pinch. Light gold color, faint grassy hops aroma and flavor. Very sessionable.
An India Pale Ale with a harsh, tingly and sweet after note that does not settle well.

Bottle at Red Lion, LGW. It pours orangey-amber with a medium yellow-white head. The nose is fresh, tangerine, mandarin, sherbet, nectarine and dough. The taste is crisp, bitter, tangerine, orange peel, toast, light alcohol, marmalade and diet Irn Bru, with a dry, bitter finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Fresh. Crisp, balanced and crushable!

Bottle at Midway Airport. Drank it right from the bottle. Tastes more like a PA than an IPA but balanced well.

Pours a light gold, with white head. Aroma of hops and malt. Taste is well blended, smooth, and very drinkable. Thumbs up!
Pours a medium yellow-brown with a white head. Nose is hops with malt. Palate is full body with malt up front and hop bitterness at the end; aftertaste, lingers.

Aroma was a bit flat, with a little malt, hops and something funky in an off kinda way. Nice pour, good head. Taste malty, roasted and a small amount of bitterness. This beer fell short of an average IPA. Disappointed.

Had it out of a bottle. Poured a beautiful clear "sister" golden color. It has a fizzy head and uneven lacing. Wet basement booty stank smell belies the good but not great tasting hoppy malty IPA. I also had it on tap at the Clybourn brew pub
pours a amber color with a thick white head. the aroma is hops and citrus and the taste is similar. the beer is very well balanced and worth a try.
Tasted from a 12oz. bottle. It poured a clear amber with a frothy off white head and streaky lacing. Has a grassy hop aroma. Well hopped with a lasting bitter finish.

Had a six pack from race track watching the national championship game. While this beer food not get a great rating it has a nice subtle hop aroma that is unique. Taste is sweet and citrus. I would drink again. Good session beer
Pours a golden amber colour. Strong aroma of apples with hints of citrus fruits. Smooth on the palate with a lovely bitter finish and a big hops kick. Great beer.

This beer pours a slightly hazy amber color with a small white head that fades fairly quickly, which is typical but definitely not bad looking. The aroma of this brew blends hops (floral and grass) with some light malts, and this shows once sipped. The taste is mildly bitter on the front end, but soon the light malts make themselves know to mute the bitterness and include a slight sweetness, leaving a less-intense flavor on the tongue for quite awhile after swallowing. Furthermore, the way this beer feels in your mouth complements the taste well due to the medium body, slick texture, and soft carbonation.
Pours golden with a big head. Nose of grapefruit and some pine. Biscuit finish on the palate with a malty kick and a touch somewhere deep down a hint of cinnamon.
Bottle. Clear reddish orange pour with half a finger of head. Pine, grapefruit, less aroma than others. Smooth medium body. Very easy to drink compared to some others. Very good

Hipster alert! Goose Island India Pale Ale was a great IPA years before great IPA’s were cool. This beer was one of the few great templates that other brewers now follow and look to as an example of the style. Today, its taste - complete with citrus and aggressive bitterness - is common. Truth be told, the steep prevalence of bold, innovative IPA’s makes this ale seem a little dated by modern standards. Still, there’s always room for a classic.

Pours cloudy pale gold. Floral hop nose, with flavors well balanced citrus and floral hop flavors with smooth maltiness. Nothing spectacular, but just a really solid IPA without being too heavy on the hops.

Aroma: Moderate grapefruit and caramel malt sweetness go hand in hand; very "balanced" and more typical of the IPAs that were in vogue 5+ years ago, which is by no means a bad thing. Appearance: Light gold/copper body with ideal carbonation supporting a sustained frothy white head. Nice looking beer, really. Flavor: Caramel malts up front with increasing grapefruit, which dries out most of the way toward the finish. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, average/lively carbonation, bitter finish. Overall: This is a well-made beer, but just doesn’t hold up to the newer generation of IPAs. Still, I’m happy to have it out of my mother-in-law’s fridge.

Draft. Pours a clear light amber deep golden color with a foamy off-white head and moderate lacing. Aroma is a subtle piney grassy floral hop. Flavor is mildly bitter with some piney and light fruity hops and a hint of caramel sweetness. Lighter in body and very easy to drink. Mild fruity bittersweetness lingers in the finish. Solid all around IPA.

Hoppy, citrus aroma. Murky gold appearance. Pure white head. Balanced hop flavor, pleasant bitterness not too overpowering which allows for more citrus, and malt character to come through. Medium finish. Medium body. Overall calm IPA nothing too overpowering. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

Draught at Hickory Tavern - Wesley Chapel, NC. Clear and amber in color. Hoppy aroma, citrus notes. Taste was not so great at first. The first two sips had a very skunky aftertaste, but went away as it warmed up. Conversely, this beer tasted brewery-fresh; almost too fresh. Taste was fresh hops flavor, I’m guessing citra, cascade and centennial. Not bad overall but not the best IPA I’ve had by far.

A very mediocre IPA. Pours the usual golden-yellow, brownish hue with a decent head. Taste is classic IPA but is lacking and watery with no complexities to speak of. Not a bad beer, but nothing special.

Nice sweet citrus aroma, but it dissipates quickly and turns a little oniony as it warms. A slightly astringent burnt carmel flavor is soon swallowed up by a more astringent bitterness. It’s not bad, certainly drinkable, and better than most mass market beers. But it’s not nearly balanced or any real "hop lover’s dream." There are so many more tasty choices out there; why bother?
Bottle. Clear amber pour with significant white head. Sweet notes from the malt but also significant hoppy notes. Bitter finish

Pours a large white head, golden honey color. Significant lacing as head bubbles down. Hoppy, bitter, refreshing, delicious.

This was the first American IPA I ever tried and over here along with Sierra Nevada APAit’s one of the most easily obtainable good American beers. It pours. It pours with a minimal off white head and has a dark golden amber colour. The smell is floral hops and citrus with pine. The taste is very good indeed initially citrus and pineapplewhich stays with you as mild sweet malt flavours enter before the dry refreshing hops add the bitterness which stays throughout the finish. It is very very drinkable and I would definitely suggest this as a good first IPA for people to try, whilst for me personally it’s one I think I will always come back to.

This is an exceptional IPA. If I were going to give a friend a good, balanced, first IPA.... This would be a great one. This one has an awesome balance of hop aroma and flavor. Great brew from Goose Island.

12 oz. bottle poured into shaker. Pours clear amber with a generous off-white head with slight carbonation and light lacing. Nice citrusy-pine hop aroma. Very well-balanced flavor. Typically I don’t love the highly-rated, balanced IPA’s (Sculpin, Headhunter, etc.), but for some reason I’m quite fond of this.
Très bonne bière, très aromatique, sans prétention, bon goût de malt, on sens bien le houblon, on y reviens tres facilement, donc excellente bière à mon goût...
Nice pale color when poured with a lacey white head. Hops flavor is pretty mild. Very drinkable. Wife hated it.

Pours cloudy pale gold. Floral hop nose, with flavors well balanced citrus and floral hop flavors with smooth maltiness. Nothing spectacular, but just a really solid IPA without being too heavy on the hops.

On tap at the Forge. Appearance: small white head, good lacing, amber-golden color, clear. Aroma: heavy hops, light malt, citrus, grassy, floral, bread. Palate: medium body, slightly oily and coating texture, lively carbonation. Taste: amazingly well balanced after the mostly hoppy aroma, heavy malt sensation up front, slowly transitioning to a smooth hoppy finish, lasting. Overall I was very impressed with how well balanced this beer is. Not too many IPA’s in my experience are this capable of making it well balanced without detracting from the fact that it is an IPA.
Bottle to glass at room temp. Pours a golden colour. Some floral and citrus on the nose. Some citrus flavour with a good hop taste. Nice strong bitter finish. Very good drinkable IPA.

Pours a crisp golden color with a white head. Hop, grass, floral, citrus, biscuit and malt aroma. Hop, citrus, floral, biscuit, grass and malt flavors. Light body and moderate carbonation and bitterness. Floral and biscuit finish.

Pours clear bronze, tall white head. Very sweet citrus aroma. Taste comes heavy fruit, perhaps a bit o’ honey. Sweet malt. Rounded out with light bitterness. Light and crisp. Pretty on-point. Very drinkable.

A: A simple nose of citrus and pine hop aromas with light notes of Kiwi or other tropical fruit.
A: Clear orange color with a one-finger head.

35.5cl Bottle: BBD 5th Apr 14, poured into a Duvel glass on 19th Nov 13.

Orange to old goal body, slight haze: on top there sat a full, deep head of foaming bubbles.

The nose is fairly sweet, tropical fruits, mild grapefruit notes and pine nut esters.

The taste was also semi-sweet and again, like the aroma it had tropical fruit hints, a citrus feel with a few nuts thrown in for good measure. Add a yeasty undertone and you end up with a fine tasting beer.

Not like many IPA’s I’ve had before, but most enjoyable.

couleur or profond, nez classique d’IPA, un peu de résine, beaucoup d’agrumes, pamplemousse, citron, un peu de mangue. Belle attaque, très fruitée, surtout sur les agrumes, puis de plus en plus sur le citron. Ca manque un peu de fruits en fin de bouche, l’amertume commence à se faire sentir. Finale moyenne, sur le citron, et une amertume très sèche. Beau départ, mais malheureusement le fruité ne dure pas jusqu’à la fin. Ca reste une bonne IPA, simple et facile à boire, légère et désaltérante

10/6/2018 Poured a clouded dark amber with a thin layer of light tan foam that diminished quickly to a blotchy cap that laced poorly. Carbonation moderate, lively and medium to coarse. More a pale ale style than an IPA. 18/11/2013 Poured a clear golden amber colour with a two-finger white foamy head that retained well and produced curtain-like lacing. Pine, citrus and a hint of caramel in the aroma. Golden colour with a white head. Medium sweetness with a medium to heavy bitterness, very well balanced. Medium body with a lively carbonation. Overall a nice IPA, enjoyable.

Bottle, at O’Hare brewery pub. Wonderful aroma of sweet grapes, pine, grapefruit and passionfruit. The beer pours light copper, just too translucent, with a beautiful creamy white head. I am thrilled that NZ suppliers of craft beer have this one on stock now. Although it has been criticised, I love the presentation/label. The naivity of that near nursery rhymes goose is brilliant, when the original name for the river island was likely based on Canada Geese.

Flavor tends to underwhelm. It's got all the characteristics of an IPA but very little bite. Super mellow beer compared to similar beers in its class. I hoped for more from Goose Island, but it never came. Even the finish is dry and forgettable.

12oz Bottle. The pour was a lightly cloudy medium amber with an average (1-2 finger) white frothy head that reduced slowly, down to a thick film and large collar with excellent sticky spotty lacing.

The aroma was of grain malts, pine and floral hops and a soapy yeast with notes of caramel, toffee, citrus (grapefruit) and a mild fruity ester (apricot and pineapple I believe).

The taste was lightly sweet with a strong fruity presence and a hint of caramel early on, with a medium hoppiness creeping in along with a nice citrus peel bite right at the end. The flavor lasted only a short while after the swallow, with the slight fruitiness fading away allowing the bitter citrus peel finish to linger for a little while longer.

Mouthfeel was light in body with a mildly dry texture and a soft carbonation.

Overall I found this to be a VERY enjoyable IPA. Not as bitter as most, but possessing a nice fruitiness which allowed for a very good balance of bitter and sweet. This is a superb example of an East Coast IPA... www.facebook.com/KAJIIsBeerReviews

Goose Island IPA has a thick, spongy, off-white head, a clear, orange-gold appearance, lots of tiny streaming bubbles, and thick, splotchy lacing left behind. The aroma is of faint citrus, pine, and some white bread. Taste is of citrus & pine, walking hand in hand with white bread and white bread toast. One would not guess this is a 55 IBU beer. Mouthfeel is light to watery, and Goose Island IPA finishes crisp, clean, refreshing, dry, and drinkable. Overall, this is most excellent. RJT

I would be interested in seeing this beer’s ratings trajectory since the purchase by AB-InBev. Given how underrated the beer is, I surmise their has been an unwarranted decline. Beer pours a beautiful clear gold with white head. Scent is clean and citrusy with no hint of grass. Bitter front with sweet back. Light-Medium with well-balanced carbonation. Draft - Fado - Atlanta, GA

Love this stuff because it totally opened my eyes to American craft beers. I don’t want to insult it by calling it a gateway beer, but it’s not QUITE as fantastic as I remember it now that my palate has developed. The hopping is mainly a firm, clean bitterness, with only mild hop flavor but powerful aroma. To me it’s very piney, woody and almost waxy. Typically clean/neutral US malt & yeast.

Pours clear amber-orange appearance, lively carbonation, lasting lace, hop-forward, fruity, citrusy aroma, set off by a perfectly balanced hop/malt middle, creamy, refreshing palate, nice citrusy finish.
Pours golden color with nice creamy head. Fruity aroma. Nice blend of hops and malt. Nice iPa without overwhelming hops.
Golden pour, nice head. Aroma of fruit and hops. Has a little kick but not overally bitter. Fruit was not in taste like aroma. Not terrible but not great.

Pours a light amber color with light head and medium lacing. Fruity aroma with a bit of hops but misleading as there is a bitter note to this beer that overtakes all other flavor that I personally don’t care for.
Very good IPA. Being a Chicagoan I have to support Goose, and in this case rightly so. Good hop presence, but not overwhelming. Nice bite. Good classic ipa.

I like 5.9 abv for an ipa and it is not garbage. However, it is nothing to savor. Good carbonation. Pleasantly spicey. A little weak on aroma. Just falls flat aftertaste. Average ipa.

Bottle pours orange-amber with a rapidly dissipating white head. Aroma is very piney, lots of hops apparent. Taste is dominantly hoppy with a hint of citrus.

Floral citrus like hop aroma. Full flavored. Maybe a bit on the malty side, and slightly sticky palate? But enjoyable.

Bottle from Wal-Mart. Citrus aroma. Cereal malt in the flavour with a massive dose of grapefruit. Some dryness to the palate, but juicy as well. Nice.
Klar orange öl med ljus orange skum. Doft: Humle, riktigt mogen mango, persika, banan, päron soda, kungs gran. Smak: Samma som doft.

Bottle pour at Rocket City Brewfest. Pale clear tan with a light head. Very hoppy aroma with some citrus and a bit of an earthy scent. Slightly sweet with a nice bitterness, strong flavor of hops and grass. Different and very nice.
Bottle. Poured clear amber color with good lace. Mild aroma of sweet citrus lager. Quite smooth slight bitter taste. A milder IPA for the masses.
Good, but nothing remarkable about this one. That is not to say it wasn’t enjoyable and I wouldn’t drink it again. Malt build is in balance with a hefty does of hops.

From bottle at Henry's in Harrison. Pleasant aroma. Straight from the bottle. Very smooth. Nice mix of mold hops. Very drinkable. Would drink again.

Oeil : couleur dorée, belle mousse compace

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange. Sweet caramel tropical fruit aroma. Nice - sweet, sticky, caramel and tropical candy fruit. Could do with more bitterness. OK. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Great session IPA. A ton of citrus and zesty fruity flavours with dry toasted and caramel malts. Floral and aromatic hop notes accompany mild resinous and citrus hops. A really solid balance and crisp finish with moderate bitterness on the finish and a clean easy to drink IPA flavour.
Orange gold with a small white head. Tropical fruit and citrus aroma. Malty with a firm bitter finish. A good standard IPA.

Light golden body, frothy white head. Citrus aromas coming from the hops. A little malt coming through to balance the bitterness. Hops and bitterness aren’t over the top. A lighter, easy drinking IPA. Definitely sessionable.

A great old-school IPA. Very hoppy, but not very bitter. Lots of citrus notes... I could swear there is orange zest in here. Malts are dry and take a backseat to the hops. The hops are smooth up front, crisp and spicy in the middle, aromatic and lingering in the finish.

This is a great IPA. Very drinkable. Also appreciate the fact that this one is lightly dry malted, making it crisper than other IPAs. Abv is not quite in the 7 range or higher. And due to alcohol levels can result in being on the sweeter side, and this one isn’t . Cheers!
Pours a bright orange/gold with a huge head that leaves lots of lacing on the glass. I detected grapefruit and pine notes. Has just the right amount of bitterness for an IPA.

Fair. Nothing special here. Although it is easy to drink. The hops are more subtle, so it might be a good started IPA for some. Plus, it’s beer and beer is good. Aroma is somewhat underwhelming, and the taste is somewhat better then where the aroma leads you...a dollar or two more would probably get you something awesome, though...
Draft, poured golden with white head, minimal lacing. Light to meduim body, not a big hop IPA, stronger malts, suprisingly good. Nice to see and taste AB hasn’t ruined this brand.

Pours a bright and clear golden with a white head that lingers for a bit. The aroma is citrus with some maltiness and pine underneath. Specifically, grapefruit, melon, orange, pine, and caramel. I find the melon and grapefruit stand out the most. As for the taste, melon and pine are dominant. There is a strong presence of grapefruit that is found deeper into the sip. There is some fruitiness as well which is some pear and apple. Aftertaste consists of pine, melon, and pear. Medium bodied, sticky in texture, with a high amount of carbonation. This one is a classic IPA. You can’t go wrong here.

Bottle. I appreciate the ’bottled on’ date, and this one is about 3.5 months old. Amber color (the website calls it ’bourbon’) with craggy head. This isn’t a big hop IPA, perhaps more malt forward. That’s OK, but I’d like a bit more bite. The hops that are there taste like Cascades. I don’t really find this all that memorable. Maybe there was an issue who handling for my bottle, causing a lack of freshness.

Re-rate: in a 16 ounce can this time, which is in its favor. Keeps it fresher too. Still, this isn’t an exceptional IPA.
Creamy white head, medium amber. Floral, grapefruit aroma. Medium body. Fairly bitter mid palate with smooth malty finish.

Crystal clear golden pour. Very clear. Medium white foam. Very earthy hop character. European yeast character. Very European version of ipa. Earthy hop flavor. Euro yeast character. 

---Rated via iPhone
On tap, it has an excellent citrus aroma. It’s very lively will good carbonation. There is an excellent citrus taste as this is an outstanding IPA.

Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Smells very grapefruity and grassy with a hint of sour fruit candy (ie. Sour punch straws, sour skittles). Taste is grapefruit and slight pine with a minimal malt prescence. Thin and very oily, smooth mouthfeel. Relatively high carbonation. Very tasty though it could benefit from some light colored specialty malts for a little more body. Kind of predictable for an IPA and nothing out of the ordinary, but still delicious and solid.

Poured into an English pint glass. Amber color with a cream colored head. Aroma is caramel malt with some grapefruit hop notes. Taste is similar with more biscuity malt flavors coming through as well as some earthy hop notes. Medium bodied with a slightly dry finish. Overall this is pretty good. Not nearly as hoppy as some IPA’s, but a good traditional example.

330ml bottle. Always interesting to have a beer you last tried 5 years before, when it wasn't so ubiquitous. This seems to have a more confident, sweet malt character than I last remember. Still hoppy, still flavoursome, but I guess I just prefer the malt toned down a bit nowadays.



Always reliable for a flavoursome beer, Goose Island hits the spot with this IPA. A great sniff of spicy fruits as you tip the glass upwards and take in the spritely hops and tingly zest taste.
Surprising balance for an inexpensive IPA, mostly bitter with bracing sweet and fruity flavors. Grapefruit and lavender. Long dry finish.
Bottle at Oluttupa Viisi Penniä, Helsinki. Originally rated 19082011. Colour is dark orange with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, citrus, hops and malts.

35,5cl bottle - Simply superb is selling Goose Island IPA short... by quite a mile! The aroma is spectacular, comparing strongly with Meantime or Brewdog IPA. Beautiful amber with only a very slight bubble, small forthy white head. One of the best IPA’s out on the market.

Bottle at Monks Porterhouse. 

Hazy golden/orange with a medium white head. Aroma and taste of light hops, citrus and malt. Also some toffee. Mild and not that bitter. The bottle was on the old side.

Nice all-around IPA. Pours orange-amber into the glass, with a frothy head that reduces to a thin ring of suds that leaves soapy lacing. The nose is spiced pine. Flavors have citrus, pine needles, spices and finish with a spicy hop. The medium body goes down smooth with soft carbonation. Very nice brew for summer.

Not too happy witht this one. Aroma contains some of the characteristics you hope for, fruity and all, but it’s not well-balanced taste, and it’s actually a bit thin. Refreshing, though.

Bottle. Poured copper with a creamy off-white head. Earthy aroma with a hop and caramel backing. The flavor found floral hops, caramel, and hints of toasted malt. Medium body, mild bitterness, and light toasted malt aftertaste.
One of the first few IPA’s I ever had when just starting out trying new craft beers.  Strong bitter, long lasting taste. Good, taste overall not my favourite IPA.
Strågul farve med gyllent skum som ligger. Lukt av honning og malt. God syrlig smak med bra bitter humle. Vinmonopolet.

[US West Coast Trip 2013] en bra IPA. Så rund och välbalanserad i smaken. Aroman är OK++ , kan man säga krämig/fyllig humle aroma.

On tap after Grandma’s Marathon. Pours a nice clear golden with small foamy head. Aroma is citrus and floral hops. Update:  Had a bottle of this, and it was nowhere near as good.  Way too sweet and sticky.

Appearance-Clear deep golden with an average off white head, nice lacing.

Golden in color with a medium head. Aroma is citrus and a hint of pine. Thin in body with good carbonation. Flavor is subtle, but quite good with citrus, malt sweetness and a but of a hop bite.

From a 12 oz bottle in a Corsendonk chalice.
Pours gold with a big head and lace.
Aroma of melon, lemon, honey, fresh bread.

Flavors of straw and floral hops, wheat, rosemary water, light herbal water. Overall tasty and refreshing.
OTHER RATING - Aug 13, 2013 on tap at Odelay Tacos in Denver.  Pours straw yellow.  Aroma of fruit rind, floral hops.  Moderate carbonation and strong mouthfeel.  Flavors of tropical fruit rind, straw hops, malt body, soap water.  Overall significant body but not an exciting hop profile.

Pours bronze with a thick, frothy foam forming on top. Aroma of exotic fruitiness, citrus and some pine - more varied than the usual grassy theme. Taste is medium bitter, fresh and crisp. Palate is medium bodied and very smooth, the carbonation just about right for a good drinkability. Not really any flaws in this American style IPA, easy to drink and rich in taste.

12 Oz bottle to pint glass, pours a nice golden amber color with foamy head and some minor lacing. Hops dominates the nose of this beer. It has all of the IPA qualities that I like, but not too bitter

12 Oz bottle poured into a pint glass, amber color with nice head and lacing, grassy hop aromas. Typical IPA taste not too hoppy not too malty nice balance. Kind of sad A.B. Inbev is linked to this company

Bottle.  Clean amber with one finger of light, fluffy, beige head and sea foam lace. Nose of pine, grass, caramel. Big malty flavor, some hints of citrus and grass as well as some fruit and candy, but mostly caramel malt. Medium mouthfeel, sweet up front and a slightly bitter finish.
Citrus, orange, apricot aroma.  Pours orange in color with a white head.  Soft palate, no very carbonated with medium body.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a clear deep orange with a two finger fluffy white head. Amazing head retention and lacing. I am quite impressed.

Aroma of pine and dank with a touch of orange thrown in. There is definitely an "English" quality on the aroma as it leans more towards the earthier hops versus tropical fruit. A light touch of caramel and toffee sneaks in too.

Pine and orange on the taste with a little bit of toffee. Some floral notes and sweetness very reminiscent of the English style. Even some yeasty esters seem to make an appearance. A little biscuit in the background but the hops remain pretty far forward. Moderate bitterness and a moderately sticky finish.

Overall, a good interpretation of the style. Doesn’t really stack up to the likes of Samuel Smith but for a widely available American beer, it’s a nice job.

355ml bottle, poured into La Chouffe tulip.

A: Golden, clear, large head, very good retention and lacing.

S: Hoppy citrus points to Cascade or similar hop being used also had notes of cork and farmyard.

T: Husk, grapefruit, pine, grain, apple. Bitterness came in at the finish along with a slight hint of molasses.

M: Light texture, well carbonated, crisp. Very easy to drink.

O: Had depth, balance and was very well crafted, they nailed this one.

A golden color with a white head. Aroma contains some pine, oranges, and lemons. The flavor is slightly bitter with some oranges, lemons, and tropical fruit notes. Aftertaste is bitter. Overall a nice session beer.

Cette bouteille née le 2/2/2013 contient un liquide doré qui fabrique un simple anneau de mousse.  Le nez est agréable et facile avec ses notes d’épinette et de fleurs qui se posent sur de légères notes de malts caramélisés.  Un goût qui se colle aux arômes.  Des houblons et des malts qui vont dans la même direction.  Rien de trop amer et rien de trop sucré.  J’ai devant moi une IPA construite pour plaire à tous.  La bouche est de moyenne densité.  Son corps est huileux et les bulles sont bien capables de nettoyer mon palais.  La finale est majoritairement florale, légèrement résineuse, peu intense et assez courte.  Classique, bonne et bien faite.
Appearance is clear copper with medium head.  Taste is of light grapefruit with medium malt.
bubbly amber, white head. not a particularly interesting or distinct aroma: citrus, caramel, cereal. medium bitter. medium-light body, thin feel. nothing notable about it. disappointing.

355ml bottle. Hazy peach color. Very small white layer. Aroma of leaves, orange and honey, with a touch of cotton candy. Flavour of honey and tough hops. Nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

During a time when IIPAs and IIIPAs are becoming more and more the norm rather than the exception, it is nice to see a beer that stays true to the English IPA style.  Pours a very light copper, somewhat brilliant with golden highlights, good head with decent retention and fine lacing.  There’s a distinct fruitiness that jumps out in the aroma which is slightly floral with a very light dose of citrus.  There’s also a slight ester from the malt that comes across as biscuit and light tobacco.  It tastes lightly sweet which quickly dissipates into a moderately dry finish.  Very satisfying and drinkable.  They’ve kept the body light enough to enjoy more than one pint.  There’s a chewy malt and fruity yeast characteristic which is unmistakably English.  A beautiful beer and a classic example of the style.
Draft in NYC. Very nice, classic medium IPA. Certainly on the maltier side but quite nicely balanced. Rich hops, some freshness. Would drink this any time.

Bottle: golden with a medium-sized white head pour. Aroma is caramel with some piney hops. Flavor is sweet caramel running into a bitter pine resin. Ok flavor but gets a little plastic-like with the hops; there are much better ipa out there.

Bought at Krogers on Broadway, North Knoxville.
Light amber. Well laced, white, long head. Aroma: Floral, citris hops. Flavor: Grapefruit hops, malt. Bitter finish. Nice.

A golden color with a white head. Aroma contains some pine, oranges, and lemons. The flavor is slightly bitter with some oranges, lemons,  and tropical fruit notes. Aftertaste is bitter. Overall a nice session beer.

pours a clear light amber with a thin white head, and good lacing.

Aroma : Citrusy piny and slightly spicy hops. Light grapefruits, some floral notes as well. Malty with light caramel notes.


Taste : Fruity grapefruits with floral and slightly spicy notes. Nice malt. Malty finish with grapefruits. Light resinous notes. Fruity finish. Moderate bitterness. 


Palate : Soft carbonation.


Overall : On the line between APA and IPA in my opinion. Nicely drinkable, nice hops and nice malt. Well balanced. Quite tasty, nice example of the style. Nothing outstanding but very well made.

Bottled 3/3/13.What, I never rated this?  This is one of my favorite beers to drink lately.  Being from the west coast, I love that Goose Island crafted a very hoppy IPA that is more floral and perfumy in character than bitingly resinous. It’s also a little lower in ABV which makes this more session able for me.  Shiny copper color with a foamy white head.  Well-laced.  Flowery hop aroma with dried citrus peel.  Taste is, as indicated, floral with perfume.  This bottle is served cold (and poured into a plastic cup at an airport) and does finish with a sharper juniper character than I recall from previous tastings.  It is pairing very well with the spicy sushi on my plate right now.  Tasty brew and a refreshing example of the style.
hazy orange color with medium head ; Hoppy fruit,citrus and floral aroma ; Sweetter hoppy taste with medium bitter finish ; Pleasant US IPA.

Appearance: Served up a bright, new copper-colored body, nearly clear, with a slim, near white head.



Smell: Pale malts, a bit bready, a bit biscuity, and with a lightly sweet-scented hint of wildflower honey. Hoppy hints of citrus, particularly grapefruit, along with spice and flowers.



Taste: Biscuit-toned pale maltiness with a honeyish sweetness to it. Zesty citrus fruits with floral, spicy English-minded hops. Moderate bitterness. Drying with a touch of citrus blossom on the smooth finish.



Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Very, very light creaminess.



Overall: I found it to a pleasant IPA.

Bottle. First time I've had this since the company was bought. Still an enjoyable  IPA. Not too crazy on the aroma, but it has a big hop flavor balanced by a nice malt sweetness. Nice lingering hop aftertaste with a pleasant dryness.

355ml. Very pale for an IPA with big head. Looked kind of like a hefe. Aroma was white grapefruit, floral and pine hops. Taste was much the same with a light, grainy malt. Refreshing body. Overall, very enjoyable, if a little different.
Nice thick rocky head with surging attack of surging beading. Some juicy slightly sweet bitterness with some gingfery peppery elements too. A fairly decent middle of the road IPA.

I love this beer from goose island.  It is one of the best mass produced ipa you can buy.  It is probably the best beer made by goose island. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
355ml bottle Waitrose.  A good beer. Pillowey head.Fruity and perfumed hop.Not too bitter, with good aftertaste.

Bottle @ home. Pours a clear, yellow golden appearance with an off white head. Sweet grapefruit, orange citrusy, soft aroma. Somewhat bitter, grapefruity, orange creamy, herbal, a touch floral flavor. Again, not hard to drink but kind of lacks inspiration.

Draft at Proof. Clear golden pour with a small white head. Aroma of fruity, piney hops with lighter pale malt backing. Flavor is similar throughout with mellower flavors and a mild bitter ending. Not bad.
Exactly what I’m looking for in an ipa. Deliciously hoppy but not to heavy so it’s extremely drinkable.

Bottle from ACME Hudson. Pours light orange with an inch of white foam that leaves little lacing. Slight fruity hops on the nose. A bit pungent on the tongue with a hint of malt. Lingers a bit on the finish. Solid.

Pours a golden yellow on tap with thin off-white head and moderate lacing. Aroma of floral and piney hops. Taste is mostly the piney resins with a touch of sweet grain. Clean finish, with a bit of lingering bitterness.  Nothing special, but a solid IPA.

Bottle 330ml from Sainsburys. Golden yello in colour thin white head. Hop haze. REsinous, grapefruit aromas. Very nicely blanaced hop character, between the hop flavour and bitterness. Dry finish, and slightly chalky mineral content.

Golden with a white head - very good hop aroma - good malt body to support the very nice hop bitterness with citrus and some pine - lingering hop flavours that is real nice and a little bit dry - this was very good
Bottle. Floral, fruity, fresh hops on the nose. Restrained malt lets the hops shine. Smooth mouthfeel, light to medium bodied. Crisp finish with resinous and bright floral hops. Really good.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Bright orange colour with thick tight head, produced splendid lacing, looked exceptional. Quite mild in flavour as American IPAs go, an almost creamy malt and pine hop flavour. Well balanced and drinkable, rather than an assault on tastebuds. Pleasant.

On tap, JFK airport, May 17. On the menu as Stone IPA but further investigation revealed it to be Goose. Interesting to taste having ordered another beer - I had thought it was a pretty crappy pint of Stone! Much maltier, caramel, a bit sweet, actually better as it warmed, I see that almost creamy interplay of caramel malt and oily pine hop. Pleasant.
On tap. Pours a nice medium amber color. Aroma is hoppy citrus, flavor is decently hoppy but nicely balanced. Not overpowering. Pretty solid IPA

Bottle 355ml, a copper beer with huge creamy head. Nose is very intense on aromatic hops, exotic fruit, lichee, pine, seems very sweet. Aroma is on honey, resin, slightly metallic, fresh oranges, low body, melon, less malty, relatively low bitterness.

12oz bottle, after reading these ratings, I was excited to try this brew.  After drinking it, I can’t see how hop heads could be satisfied with this one.  Overall, decent brew, average IPA at best, clean, crisp, drinkable, but not very hoppy.  A good start, but not quite there yet.
Bottle. Poirs golden clear with some white head. Aroma some citrus. Taste bitter, fruits, hoppy.

Pours yellowish amber, cloudy with small white head. Aroma of resin, pine, mango, some citrus. Taste is nicely balanced with a subtle sweetness at first before a relatively mild bitter finish that ends a bit abruptly. Light body, medium carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle courtesy of deanso.  Straw coloured pour with a broken white head.  Rich hoppy aroma leading to a malty hoppy flavour.  Strange aftertaste and no dry bitterness, so this is far from my farourite IPA.

Draft- pours clear honey gold w small white head. Aroma is nice but subdued. Def a more traditional IPA than the hop bombs of today. Aroma is sweet, hoppy, little tea. Fruity. Taste follows suit. Body is light/ medium & finish is fruity, sweet, w/ moderate hoppy bitterness.
From the bottle. Cloudy golden pour with fine head. Sour citrus with floral hints. Long bitter finish. High carbonation, perhaps a little too gassy. Not a session beer but overall very nice.

Clear golden pour, light frothy head. Pretty run of the mill IPA here, but done well.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at CJ Muggs (St. Louis, MO), again into a frosted mug, lol. Pour is golden orange with a small off-white head. Grapefruit, citrus, caramel, stale bread, and biscuit in the aroma. Taste is light orange peel, old hops, cereal, and grass with a medium bitter finish. Medium mouthfeel with high carbonation. Really unfresh and kind-of a letdown.
Stanley’s Beer Fest 10/6, BOTTLE. Pour is cloudy gold. Aroma of citrus. Mild bitterness but well balanced.
Sample @ SBWF 12. Golden colour with a small white head. Aroma is strong of hops. Flavour is also full of hops.

Bottle:
Vast creamy medium sized head which changes slowly into a thick vast creamy closed lacing on top of a hazy almost murky orange colored beer.
Smell malts, fresh cut wood/oak, vanilla, light citrus, grape fruit, peach, dusty yeast, plant extracts and stronger tea (herbs).
Taste is also malty with wood tones, some spices, bitterness, light hoppy, creamy, light citrus notes, dusty yeast tones, nettle, 
Aftertaste is thin but medium bitter with floral hop notes and some bitter grass tones.
Low medium carbo, soft almost silky mouthfeel with a spicy touch, medium body and a creamy texture.
Cloudy orange colour. Sweet grapefruit, pine and caramel malt on the nose. Nice blend of citrus and toffee notes in the taste. Dry, bitter finish. Solid, no frills IPA.

Bottle at home
Grassy aroma. 
Smooth taste nice barley hop mix. 
Grassy bitterness, even in the aftertaste. 


Bolton Brew Rocks !!

Nice IPA, good balance of hops and taste on tongue is great. Plan to purchase again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle.  Pours a light cloudy golden colour, with an off-white head.  Aroma has a whack of tropical fruit notes (including oddly, dried strawberries, and pineapple), pine, with some sweet malt.  The taste is also super fruity.  Fruit punch fruity.  It’s weird, and delicious.  There are also some woody notes, with some light sweetness underneath the hops, with more fruit, and green vegetable in the finish.  This is a really well balanced IPA, and not too full bodied.  Excellent!

Bottled at some pub in Glasgow, UK. Hazy golden colored, white head. Very pleasant hoppy nose, lots of  fruit, pine. Hopbitter flavor, fruity notes again, very balanced. Lasting hoppy finish. Very complex yet easy to drink beer, exactly how i like my IPA. A beer i could drink all evening (and so i did...).
Golden amber colour. Citrus-cascade hop aroma. Taste is hoppy with a bitter finish.
Pours slightly hazy golden with small white head. Citrus and fruit aroma, sweet fruity taste with some earthy pine and a dry bitter finish. Nice easy drinking IPA

Hazy yellow golden pour, with a small head. Nose is not distinctive at all, rather flat, with some hops. Taste is hoppy with some citrus and bittersweet. With the light ABV drinks rather easily. Finish is dry and like the taste bitter
sweet. Nice IPA but nothing special. Quaff Score 7 / 10
Pours orange with a white head and sweet hoppy aroma. Taste is sweet, of hops, pine, and citrus with a bitter, medium finish. Light mouthful and very drinkable, solid IPA
strong blond color. huge tropical aromas. grassy taste,fruits, with a bitter afterttaste. amazing ipa
Amazing IPA. Aroma hit you straight in the face, smooth easy very refreshing. brilliant!

Bottle share with JF on Southampton beer up - 09/09/12.
Pale golden with a large frothy white head.
Nose consists of pine, hops, caramel and citrus.
Taste comprises caramel malts, grapefruit, toffee.
Medium bodied with moderate carbonation and a smooth finish.
First time I’d had this since a visit to Clybourn in ’05 - forgotton what a decent no frills IPA it is!
Hazy dark blond colour. Sweet aroma with some tropical fruit. Plenty of malt softness in the flavour giving good balance against the fruity hops. Finish is creamy, fruity, dry.

35 cl bottle @ home. Pours slightly cloudy golden with a white head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is pine, citrus, and caramel malt. Flavour is along those lines with fruity and piney hops and some sweet malt.

Bittle shared with McTapps. Super sweety nose - similar to a Leffe or Duvel. Aroma of honey and ripe fruits. In the end end very dry. Interesting beer - especially for fans of that kind. I’m not. But still a good beer. Too dry and bitter in the end.
Bottle bought in local Sainsbury’s and shared with MichaelBruch. Special aroma of sweet coffee and barley. Taste of straw, marmite and malt. Very special and extraordinary.
Nose of hops and bitters with a good balance of hop flavor. I’m not a big IPA guy but this one was great. A new go to IPA for me.
Pours amber with a thick white head. Aroma of hops and citrus and a bit of malt. Flavour of citrus (grapefruit / orange) and hops. Bitter sweet citrus aftertaste.

Pours a orange amber with a medium lasting beige head with good lacing. Aroma and taste of caramel malt, bready, yeast with some good earthy piney hops and some mild citrus notes. Palate is a nicely balanced combination of sweet malt and hops with moderate carbonation. Finish is of caramel malt, yeast, some citrus flavors followed by some nice earthy piney hops for balance. Overall a very good, tasty and nicely balanced English IPA.
Pint at playwright. Clear amber. Reasonable white cap. Ringed lacing. good hop aroma with citrus. Balanced taste of same. Medium carbonation.
Hoppy and bit bitter in line with most of the Goose Island family. Solid IPA with flavor to back it up.

Keg @ some bar in Tribeca. The pour’s deep golden amber with a frothy white head. The nose is bright orange citrus, sugar cookies and fresh sweet orchard fruits. The taste is simple lively sweet citrus flavors with a supporting sweet pie crust-like malt base. Mildly hoppy. Medium body, active carb. Really well executed. Nice and clean, quality.
A pretty damn good IPA with plenty of citrus, pine and good hoppy flavor.  This is good stuff.  One of the better English IPAs I’ve had.

Bottle from Breeze Thru. Pours a clear pale orange with some off-white head. Leaves nice lacing. Aroma has pine and citrus, with a bit of skunkiness. Taste is of grapefruit and pine. Sticky. Going through the glass, the caramel malt presence begins to assert itself and some sweetness joins in. Fairly light. Finishes somewhat short and bittersweet. A decent IPA; nothing bad, but also nothing to grab you. Surprised I’ve not rated it before - but I would not say this tasting was much different than others of it.
Bottle to glass mug.  Pours a hazy yellow with a full white head.  Nice balance of hop bite & malt sweetness.  Hop flavors of citrus.
Stylistically very hoppy, but still refreshing. Citric and fruity, long bitter aftertaste. Great American-style IPA!

A-- poured a golden amber color. Off white head that settled to one finger. Good head retention on swirling and some thick lacking on the sides of the glass.

S-- Earthy hops, spice and Carmel. Very gritty smell to this.

T-- Once again very Earthy and gritty. Larger Carmel backbone but enough hops to say hello. More grapefruit centered hop wise I think.

M-- Pretty thick and chewy. The earthiness of it makes it feel heavier than it seems. More like medium bodied and medium carbonation. A lot of grapefruit tones with this as the main fruit followed by a lot of Carmel.

D-- Good solid summer beer. For the boldness of it, it is very drinkable. Well hidden ABV and very tasty beer. Good example of an EIPA

Pours amber in colour, clear with a small white head that dissipates quickly. Strong citrus hops and grapefruit aroma with noticeable pine scents as well. Mildly sweet with a reasonable bitterness through to the finish. Medium bodied, good carbonation, and a nice smooth feel on the palate. Strong IPA, an enjoyable brew.

Bottle. Clean clear crisp looking beer. Nice white lacing down the whole glass with a lovely citrus aroma. Nice and bitter that is refreshing. Excellent brew

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smell of hops and citrus. Amber colour, hazy. High white head. Fruity, aroma of citrus and hops, some herbs and spices as well.

Pours a liquid gold with a nice sized white head. Aroma is hoppy. Nice and creamy on the palate with hops predominate on the flavor profile, sharp but not bitter. An IPA lover’s delight. Pairs well with ham and cheese on rye.
Unlike other popular IPAs commonly found, this one continues to set a high standard. Hoppy fruity and lasting. Nice.

Pours a clear, golden color with minimal white head.  Aroma is nice mix of hops (citrus, pine & floral) and malt.  This sort of reminds me of a weak 90 Minute IPA in both taste and aroma.  Taste is similar with a nice citrus flavor along with some sweet malt and a bitter finish.  The body is light to medium.  Overall this beer is very clean and smooth but I prefer something a little more substantial.

Good ipa. Pours a pretty peach colour. Thick and cloudy. Fruit and sweet nose...a touch of spice too. Nice sweet malty, wheat flavours. Peaches, apricots, mandarin oranges. bitter citrus finish. Very drinkable. Quite nice.

12 oz bottle, slightly hazy light gold pour, big creamy white lasting head, good lacing, aroma of citrus and lets you know it will be crisp, light sweet malt, nice hop balance, on the grapefruit side, light to medium body does have that oily texture but therefore not all that complex, lowish alcohol % nice and drinkable, good for the summer to drink a few, more American than English though

Nice hoppy IPA with grapefruit notes.  Pours light gold with a thick frothy head.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled. Pours slightly hazy and golden with a medium sized off-white head. Leaving a fair lacing on the glass. Nose of flral hops an grapefruit and caramel. Sweet flavor with citrus fruit and caramel notes. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. Ends up and decent bitter.
Slight amber pour, off white head.  English malt, yeast, and hops on the nose in equality.  Medium sweetness.  Smooth malt body, very well balanced hops.  Nice finish.  Good Beer.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Pale golden colour with perfume smell. This beer tastes of hops and lots of them, beautiful. It has a very perfumy floral taste and a strong hint of grapefruit to it that is strangely nice. My first American beer, will try more.
Pours hazy orange to honey with a nice head, aroma of marmalade, litchi and orange, flavor of is bitter and crisp with lots of orange juice, malt and honey, medium bodied. Nice

Good head, mostly diminishing, good lacing.

Hop aroma

Sweet start bitter finish

Light to medium body.

Not quite as bitter as I was expecting, this is a good IPA
Smell of hops, pine and mild spices.  Beautiful light copper.  Hops are well balanced with a nice fruit and spice mix.  Outstanding.

4 of us drank this for the first time together. We all agreed that the floral elements in the taste outweighed any strengths. It was compared to a very floral light Alsatian white wine. Not an enjoyable drink but we all agreed that with food it did taste better. Could not drink more than one.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Wegmans Leesburg.  It pours a clear light amber color with a huge, lasting head of white foam.  The nose hits you from an arms length away.  Lots of pine and ripe citrus aromas.  The flavor has tons of pine, resin, and citrus.  I’m sure there is malt in there somewhere, but damn if I can tell.  This one is all about the hops.  Light to medium body with a dry but lasting, bitter finish.  Nice brew!
Pours amber with a white head.  Aroma is citrus, floral and toast.  Taste is sweet with medium bitters.  Solid.
Bottle. Pours gold with thick white head. Aroma is floral with grapefruit. Flavor is the same with some tropical fruit. Solid IPA.
Aroma of grapefruit and pine. Very subtle hops with light hopping and a malty finish. I don’t know why this is rated so high, and it’s really solid in all areas but it’s not that special.

Beautiful fruity and floral hoppiness stands out. Malting is caramelly sweet. Like this aroma a lot. Colour is like hazy honey. Short dense head leaves lacing.  Taste is like walking in a garden: flowers, fruits, parfym-like flavors. Gorgeous taste has nuances and lots of character. Fresh and perky, light with nice carbonation.

Arrived in India.Stop. Hot and excotic here. Stop. Luckily I have little bit of homeland in a bottle here with me. Stop. Hard being separeted, Victoria, miss you. End of message.

This IPA is one of the most delicious and balanced I’ve ever tried.  Right when you open it and pour, it welcomes you graciously to the party it has in store.  It has a wonderful golden color with a burst of bubbles and a light, hoppy head that kicks things off nicely.  There is no bitter burst of hops here, just a gentle, somewhat bubbly smoothness.  The beer itself is very sweet and creamy, and reminded me somewhat of Three Floyd’s Gumball head with its hints of candy.  There is a distinct presence of malt which balances out the hops perfectly, meaning that every sip you take a delightful and balanced.  More of a malty IPA with a note of hops than vice versa, which is how most IPAs are.  This is perhaps the easiest drinking IPA I’ve ever enjoyed.  Perfect representation of the city of Chicago.

For me, this is a classic Chicago beer that is really enjoyable. Nice golden pour that sticks all over the inside of the glass. Great IPA taste and smooth finish. Definitely a go to beer here in Chicago, nothing too special, but at the same time, a consistently refreshing taste.

Bottle. I?m so disappointed, I like a lot of their other beer but this one gets a meh. Light amber with foamy white dissipating head. Smells kind of floral and a little spiced. Tastes sweet and band-aidy and lightly bitter. Finish is both bitter and floral.

yellow orange, slightly hazy liquid. pours a white yellowish silky head. the aromascape is very standard IPA with added ginger sweetness, very well done. this is a prime example of an IPA, very balanced but not surprising.
nice session IPA. Balanced, but not hoppy enough for my liking. Solid, but not what I will go with when picking 6% IPA’s.
