One to any exponential power is still 1. I find the same can be said of the adjective "good." In other words, it doesn’t matter how many times and in how many different aspects you use the word "good" to describe something, since it doesn’t make it better than just plain good. I have a feeling I’m going to use that word quite often to describe Goose Island India Pale Ale. This is a beer that is good in so many ways, but not a great beer. It’s a case of a "good" being good enough if "good enough" is good enough for you.

APPEARANCE AND AROMA

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. This beer has all the makings of a good IPA right away with a slightly hazy orange body and frothy, off-white head (which leaves some lacing on the glass). It smells quite inviting with a citrusy aroma with notes of pine and some malty sweetness as well. It’s definitely an inviting beer.

TASTE

Goose Island IPA is the kind of India Pale Ale I’d recommend for beginners looking for a good "jumping on point" for the style. It begins with a creamy texture which is slightly dry and sweet and finishes with a prominent, slightly crisp, citrus taste. The dynamics of the palette here are quite interesting. The pale malts create for a mild sweetness and the combination of some British hops give the beer the bitterness you expect in an IPA.

As I drank on I noticed the flavors began to homogenize. The refreshing citrus finish began to dry out making the beer less refreshing than it originally was. The palette began to feel noticeably mild, although I also noticed a slight orange sherbet-like flavor in the aftertaste. For an IPA this beer is not all that bitter. In fact, Goose Island’s website indicates it rates only 55 on the IBU scale. That score is fine if their intention is to make a extremely palatable beer, but for hopheads like me I was left feeling only satisfied instead of genuinely impressed.

DRINKABILITY

While the overall taste to Goose Island IPA was good, it probably performed even better in the drinkability department. The mouthfeel is soft, medium-bodied, and it goes down smooth. As it warms it begins to dry out the mouth and the hops begin to linger for a few extra moments, but ultimately it’s still very palatable. 

At only 5.9% ABV this is actually rather light for an IPA. Beers of this style tend to be more robust and weightier, although the trade-off is here is that this would make a good session beer. It would also work well as a dinner drink.

FINAL THOUGHTS

While not the best India Pale Ale in the world, Goose Island IPA is still a good beer for its satisfying taste and easy drinkability. I’d prefer something more robust in many ways, but I don’t think this beer is intended to be anything other than a good IPA, and in that aspect the brewers succeeded.

I’m not really a massive fan of IPAs as a style but this is excellent. Beautifully hoppy with great citrus notes and a really pleasant sweetness with hints of caramel. Extremely good.

Bottle at Øldommerkursus.
Clear golden with a white head. Aroma heavy hoppy (citrus, pine). Flavour heavy bitter (citrus, pine) and sharp, light sweet (caramel). Medium body, light warmth from alcohol. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours a hazy pale straw yellow with a small white head. Decent lacing. Sweet, malty pine hop aroma with notes of sweet fruits. Flavour is citrus and pine hops with notes of dried fruits. Sweet, bitter hop finish. Overall a tad too sweet, bordering on being cloying, and could do with a bit more bitterness, but otherwise pretty okay. 17.08.10.
Boyyle. Pour is golden yellow with a soapy tight head. Aroma is malt and mild citrus hops. Taste is clean refreashing with a nice mellow citrus honey hops. Palate is clean bitter and finishes dry.

Bottle- Deep amber pour. A pillowy white head caps the beer. Pine needle and bready caramel malt nose also has grapefruit and perfume. Tastes of sweet caramel malts and grapefruit, resiny hops, citrus. Fairly bitter, with hoppy finish. Pretty good.
Bottled in Frape. Hazy orange color with avaerage white head. very weak hop nose. Aroma is hops with some underlying sweetness. Flavour is hops which gives space to lots of very bitter hoppy finish.

Source:Fresh 6 pack purchased from Kroger in Danville.

Glass:Poured into a Sam Adams Perfect Pint glass.

Appearance:Clear gold pour with a finger of soapy white head that quickly dissipates into a scum on the top.

Aroma:Aroma is mainly very fresh, spicy hops.  A faint hint of flowers and a bready nose are present.

Flavor:Up front is very spicy.  This fades into a lingering bitterness and some bready malt.

Palate:Medium/light body with solid carbonation.

Overall:This is excellent fresh.  I can imagine that once this fades, it would probably not be any good, but this sixer was a week old!
Draught at Stoney’s.  Bright golden color, medium white head, massive lacing.  Aroma of wet grass and citrus.  Taste is plenty hoppy with just a touch of bitterness.  Nice balance and character.

[355 ml bottle, Beers of Europe, King’s Lynn] Dry hop aroma with some spices, extremely drinkable citrus and pine hop flavour. Pours dark golden with a peaky, fluffy head and some rising carbonation. Hoppy and fruity aftertaste which becomes bitterer on the far finish. For an above-average session on an above-average strength beer, you can’t do much better – only a few American IPA’s top it, in my opinion. [05/05/2009]

Bottle. Pours somewhat clear but hazy yellow orange with near white head. Moderate amount of aroma; piney and grassy hop aromas overlying some grainy, sweet malt. Hop flavours, grassy and piney are there. Body, light-medium and simple coupled with medium-high bitterness, though not all that complex lingers through the end for a medium dry finish with a lingering hop presence. It’s all about the hops for this beer, the body takes a back seat, which is evidently a personal choice when it comes to ipa’s. Love the hop presence in this one though.
strong hops in the aroma. Nice crisp taste of hops but had a slight metallic finish. Disappointing end to what should have been a very good beer.

Pours golden/amber with a white head. Aroma of Caramel Malts, some hops, grapefruit, pine and citrus. Taste has Caramel Malts, yeast, some hops and citrus. . The body is okay for a pale ale. High carbonation.

(Bottled, sampled 2010-03-23) Slightly hazy golden with a smallish, lacy head. Fresh citrus in the aroma, along with some more exotic fruitiness, and slightly woody hops. Crisply fresh flavor with high bitterness, a bit harshly hopped with some fruitiness missing - yet quite ok. Quite light body, hign on CO2, slightly thin but refreshing. A decent IPA, that is balanced and refreshing, despite the lightness.

On tap.  Pours clear orange with a nice white head that fades slowly.  Aroma is of citrus.  Nice orange and grapefruit scent.  Flavor is pine, some citrus, and sweet malt.  Well balanced, and very enjoyable.
Pours a dark amber with a large head.  Aroma is orange and piney hops.  Taste is orange and citrus at first, followed by a hoppy bite on the finish, not too bitter.
Enough hops aroma to realize it must be an IPA.  Flavor is not overly bitter but good hops taste.  Enjoyed this one.

The aroma is not pronounced as many of its fellow IPA’s tend to have, but it does have a bit of resiny hops, floral esters, and some alcohol and very faint caramel.  The appearance is a clean yellow-caramel with a thin white head, that creates a nice lacing down the glass.  The taste is a nice balance of caramel, bread, resiny hops, and some alcohol.  The palate for an IPA is super smooth.  It maintains a medium body, with a thin, semi-oily texture, with a bit of a fizzy carbonation, and a long minor burn from the hops.  It is a very good brew, could easily become my favorite "session" IPA.  The major disappointment is that it’s not available in our state.  Hopefully, that changes.

Had on draft at Goose Island Brewery, Wrigleyville, Chicago, IL.  Pours a hazy orange color with a think white head.  Taste is grapefruit, pine, and caramel.  Nice easy finish.  Another great goose beer.

12 oz bottle from Stateline. Poured a good looking burnt orange hazy body underneath an impressive large frothy super long lasting head. Aroma was a little sweeter then expected with motes of honey, flowers, grassy hops, toffee and bread. The body is spot on with a medium to Fuller mouthfeel, average carbonation and a on lingering aftertaste that comes on after a nice bitter finish. The flavor isn’t as sweet as the aroma and the hops are a little more apparent. Notes of resinous hops, grapefruit, dry bread crusts and honey suckle flowers. Pretty good on this 100° day in MD.

Bottle.  Pours clear orange and copper with a frothy 1-finger beige head.  Aromas of sweet pine and citrus, pineapple, brown sugar, and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor is a little bitter: fresh pine with earthy bark and resinous notes, and a nice tropical fruit finish.  Crisp, and very refreshing.  Really nice.

12oz bottle pours hazy light amber/orange small foamy head. Nice mellow aroma heavy on grapefruit, with pine, soft floral. Taste nice pine/woody taste into bitter with a spicy after taste. A very decent IPA.

Wow!  Well done, Goose!  12oz bottle available all over the place packs a fantastic IPA.  Pours a cloudy pale orange with yellow edges and a thin resiny head.  Aroma is that inviting grapefruit/pine/bread combination found in many others in the style.  Flavor is where this brew separates itself from other common shelf bottles.  Creamy texture at first brings a great amount of malt (caramel flavor) to balance the moderate hop bite and citrus acidity.  As those flavors evolve, the texture dries out and leaves a pleasant finish.

From bottle. Great fresh piney-resin hop aroma with good fruity notes. Rich sweet malt, too, but mostly fresh hops. Hazy orange amber with pillowy foamy white lacing head. Medium body with medium-high carbonation. Starts with medium sweetness of malt, ctirus fruit and apricot, followed by great fresh grassy-pine hops. Great balance with mild bitter finish, fruity. Nice IPA with awesome hop flavor but muted bitterness.
Really bitter for goose. Great summer refresher. Magnificent hops selection.

This is a fabulous everyday IPA.  Pours a light semi-cloudy yellow with a thin white head.  Aroma is citrus and hop.  Taste is a nice light balance of hop bitterness and malt and citrus.  Nothing is overpowering, the flavours all strike the palate at the same time and is really quite pleasant.  I would drink this everyday if I had the opportunity.
Pours a darkish golden amber. Smells of sweet grapefruit hops. Tastes of grapefruit and slight hop bitter. Medium mouthfeel and not much of a linger on the tongue. Very nice session IPA.
Pours a deep golden color.  Aroma is full of pine and hops.  Flavor has hops, coriander, bark, and pine.  Nice hop finish.

Pours a slightly hazy amber-orange, with nice frothy head.  Great head retention on this one through the entire pint.  Aroma & taste is typical IPA citrus & pine, with nice balance.  
Very smooth.  An excellent IPA.
Got on draught. Pours a slight golden hazy color. Smells very fruity like pear and berries. Has a very fruity taste with a hoppy bitter finish. Aroma is very tasty!

Poured from bottle to pint glass shows a light orange/honey color. Light head w/lacey residue. A smokey orange like malt aroma. Light and citrus taste with a leaning to grapefruit flavor and a light grapefruit after taste.
This would be good on a warm afternoon after going to a Cubs game.

comparing it, unfortunately, to the Daisy Cutter I just had...night and day...the DC tasted like an IPA; this does not...more like a pale ale at best....
Aroma....nice nose / not too hoppy
Appearance...nice amber color; good sturdy head...hazy color
Taste...that is the problem...enough for a IPA but huge
Palate...medium body; a little thin; not quite bitter enough at end
Overall..a good session IPA....
Part of phaleslu’s 20 pound box.  Hazy amber pour with thick creamy head.  Sticky like a mofo.  Nose high sweet sharpness of hops.  Taste is light and thin, but with a warming sharpness.  Sweet.
12 oz bottle nice light golden pour with a nice head. Hopps Hopps and more Hopps. This is a good one to try!

Bottle, Moderate malt note of caramel, moderate pine and grapefruit for the hops, light soap for the yeast with cherry and pepper in the background. Head is small, wispy, white with some lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear amber. Flavor starts lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is on the lighter side of medium, a little oily and has a lively carbonation. This has all the components of an excellent IPA.

Poured from 12 oz bottle.  Aroma is of a standard hoppy IPA, taste also very good.  It’s great for a standard IPA and can see this as a gateway for non-craft beer lovers to get into trying things other than mass produced lagers.

bottle shared with some london area BTers. copper with a white head. nose was small compared to the other pales that were served along side this. the flavours were balanced with all the normal american ipa aspects showing up where they should. solid session style ipa.

Ah afraid this one was a disappointment from a usually reliable brewery. Had it some while back and can’t remember the full details. Sweet and smooth but there was just something unpleasant about it. Will be back again for a full review.
Pours a medium to dark golden brown with a thick head.  It has a slightly hoppy, almost metallic aroma. The flavor is pretty smooth, with a lot less of a bite than most IPAs.

Appearance is a slightly cloudy/hazy golden color. It has a nice frothy head. This IPA has a nice floral hop aroma. This is a very well balanced IPA with just the right amount of maltiness, not too bitter with a nice finish. Has a nice smooth and silky mouthfeel. Not very much carbonation, but not a bad thing with this one. I really like this one. One of my new favorite IPA’s.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-16-2009 23:46:12

Dark blonde cloured, pours out with a dense white head, good lacing, lots of carbonation. Strong hoppy aroma, also some fruits and flowerish and herbal. Bitter taste, some carbonation. Fresh, like grapefruit and oranges. Long and bitter finish, also some ginger. NIce one.

Cloudy to mostly clear golden, honey color.  Thin white head that dissipated rather quickly.  Although, it did leave some lacing on the glass as I sipped.  Very prominent, fresh, floral, perfumy hops in the nose was the first characteristic.  Had a very slight hint of fruit underlying the floral aroma.  The taste had a very pronounced bitterness with a sweet flavor.  Very punchy with the bitter aftertaste.  Really hangs around on the palate.  I Like It!!!  Had a mostly thin mouthfeel.  To me it was light, crisp and smooth.  Easily drinkable.  Reminds me of the freshness of spring.  Love the bitterness of this brew and the smell was possibly the best aspect of the beer.  This beer goes well with the warm spring and summer days.

Very smooth and easy to drink. Not a great deal of bitterness, although the beer was refreshing and crisp.  Didn’t beat me over the head with hops either. Glad I picked it up, but not something I will keep in my regular rotation.

Pours pale yellow orange with small white head.  I get no pine notes from this one.  It’s all resin and fruit, like peaches and cantaloupe.  Maybe I’ve rated too many in a row.  But this just doesn’t stand out.  I was hoping for more citrus pine nose and a more bitter finish.  This is great compared to most supermarket offerings, but it definitely leans toward the more bready malty English style instead of the West coast style that I am in love with.  Still, it’s decent.

Bottle. Spiciness, grapefruit. flowers and peach aroma. Medium white head that lasts. Slightly hazy golden amber colour. Medium to heavy bitterness. Medium bodied, lively carbonation. Long crisp bitter finish.

I think too many people forget that this is an English IPA... The breadier aroma and taste balanced by the less bitter hop varieties that they use creates an amazing beer for the style. Pours a beautiful color, has a big nose for the style, complex with 3 or 4 hops in there, the toasted caramel malts, and a subdued yeast character. May be the best English IPA I have ever had, and its from Chicago!

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Pours a cloudy honey gold with a finger-thick eggshell white head with nice retention and some light, sloppy lacing.  Aroma of herbal hops, grapefruit citrus, pine, honey, and floral notes.  Flavor of mild herbal hops, pine resin, a few different citrus fruits, pale and caramel malts- such a mild bitterness to go along with the sweetness.  Light-medium bodied, with low carbonation for an IPA and a sweet, fresh, juicy mouthfeel.  Nice aftertaste.  Easy to drink, great warm weather beer, and easily sessionable.

Bottle from Vinens Verden, Odense. Best before at december 2010, but already seemed a bit old to me. Weird and quite unpleasant flavors of jelly candy, black currant, cat pee (!) and caramel. A little sweet and lacks the proper bitterness for an IPA. Should try this one again since this was probably and old or bad bottle.
Fruity, floral nose. Citrusy, hoppy, sweet caramel, bread loaf, and toffee for flavors. Pretty good. Nice, well balanced mouthfeel.

I just didn’t like this one.  IPA’s are not my favorite style, but this was in the multipack I bought and I wanted to try it out.  I really like DFH 90 min IPA, but not this one.  It was bitter and offered little enjoyment to me.  In fact, I drank half and poured the rest out.

This was from a green bottle in a 6pack, pours an IPA color in its purest form, so delitcate with rich hues and strong tan and shade undertones.  Taste is impeccable to the exteme, a smooth, low key hop taste at first settles with wonderful thunder with the after taste.  Small head that sticks around through the whole brew, that makes it easier to go back and endulge more.  Great beer.

Had this in NYC, at Joshua Tree bar, I was surprised this was so good.  It pours gold color, decent head.   It had floral, caramel aroma, slightly bitter hoppy tones in the taste.     A smooth beer overall, I would drink this regularly on tap.

Pours clear pale amber with a thick, creamy white head and excellent lacing.  Aroma is oranges, candy sugar, and hops with floral notes.  Body is medium full with a complex hoppy taste balanced well against subtle caramel and orange peel.  finish is tingly and bitter with some lingering sweetness.  Nice!

This poured a darker yellow to orange color with a white head. Aroma was a decnt nose of light citrus hops and some lemony character. Flavor was a nice mix of bittering and citrusy and a bit dank triple C hops. A little less than I was expecting but I think this might have been a bit old.
On tap at Clayborn pub. Burnt Amber clear pour with medium lasting white head. Lots of citrus and resin in the aroma. Medium bitterness, nice full body with lingering hoppy finish.

Goose Island India Pale Ale--Goose Island Classics--2005 12 oz. Bottle.  5.90% ABV.  58 IBU’s  (4.25 / 5.0)  Mild lace head.  Bottled Conditioned slightly hazy bright dark golden color.  Earthy floral hop front.  Rich smooth creamy malty caramel mild sweet body.  Earthy spicy citrus hop end.  Bitter balanced English? Hops.  Mild fruit.  Sampled 9/3/2005
35,5 cl bottle, pours a clear golden with a tiny head, medium bitterness, pretty light drinkable and decent beer.
It exists to be enjoyed.  Beer that is.  I mean hops are really fucking cool.  Seriously.

12oz bottle. Poured a lightly hazy, effervescent golden orange with a medium sized, lasting white head leaving a fair lacing. Lovely fresh, green hops aromas of grapefruit, pine and marmalade backed by a pleasant sweetness. Hops seemed more muted on the tongue than the aroma implied, beginning with lemon and orange and finishing on a zesty, mid-bitter hop note. Not overdone, restrained and enjoyable. Quite dry and crisp on the palate with a medium length, balanced finish.
Aroma is fresh hops with a sweet malt backbone.  On the palate, it is lighter than the aroma let’s on.  The taste brings out a grassy, floral, citrus hop.  Nothing special and a little watered down.
bottled. pours a light amber with a minimal offwhite head. Smells of citrus and floral hops. Flavors of grapefruit and bitter hops. It is a medium body which finishes strong with hops. Decent beer.
Pours a lacing, beige head with an amber-copper body.  Aromas of pine and a hint of citrus.  Flavor is pine, caramel malt, some citrus.  Finish is bitter.

Pours a two finger cream head that fades quickly to a thin layer leaving some lace. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied.  Cloudy amber color.  Nose is light grapefruit hops.  Flavor is grapefruit hops with a lingering bitter aftertaste. Malts stay hidden. $1.95 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.

Pours a hazy amber with a generous white head. Aromas of fresh hops, citrus and roasty malts are present. The taste is very forward with hops, sweet caramel and bread malts. A light sweetness and bitterness are very pleasant on the palate. This meduim-bodied, but full flavored brew leads to a well balanced, smooth finish. Nearly a great IPA.
All i all a pretty decent IPA pours golde with an orange hue and clear with a small white head aromas are of hops and and malts flavor  of grapefruits,malted barley
12 ounce bottle-a orangish pour-off white head-nice fruity aroma -taste of fruit some floral-big bitter finish -this one is ok not great
Draft. Nice dark copper body with a sweet smelling hoppy head. Flavor had a nice mix of sweet hops and malt.

Bottle. Pours a very lively, fizzy clear orange body topped with a dense, thick, white head. Looks very appetizing. Smell is intense hops with both grassy and fruity notes. Taste is a nice blend of fruity American hops and what feels like more grassy, floral European styles. Well-rounded bitterness all through the drink, with an extra little bite at the end - perhaps a bit too much for my liking. Nice stuff all in all, but somehow still not outstanding.

(bottle, 35.5cl) Hazy, pale golden colour with a blond and firm medium-sized foamy head. Fresh and fruity hoppy aroma, slightly piney and spicy with a mild pale malty blend. Bitter-sweet flavour, quite light bodied according to its abv, moderately carbonated mouthfeel. Soft pale malty base with fruity (citrus, pine apples) and spicy/piney hops, lingering into the light to moderately bitter and fruity finale. Clean and easy-going IPA.12.IV.10

Draft at Celtic playwright in NYC. Pours amber body with thick off white head and lacing. Strong pine hop aroma with some citrus following through. Decent malt character present as well. Mouthfeel is medium; notes of grapefruit, caramel, bread and citrus hop.

bottle from Bierzwerg. Clear deep golden colour, mid-sized white head. Fruity-spicy hoppy nose. Medium- to full-bodied. Intensive malty background with lots of citrusy and resiny hops. Spicy, fruity with lots of citrus character in the middle, the lingering hops in the aftertaste are resiny. Very nice!

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle at Brixie’s Spring Tasting in Brookfield, IL., with a clear, golden color, modest white foam to the head, and clingy spots and streaks of lacing. The nose was a nice balance of citrus, pine, and malt. The citrus was more as ripe grapefruit in the flavor, along with smooth malt and a moderately strong hop bitterness. A very good style introduction IPA.

Bottle.  Pours a 2", white, foamy head.  Lasting and lacy.  Clear, golden-orange body.  Moderate hop aroma dominated by citrusy American hops.  Mainly grapefruit and mandarin orange.  Flavor contains white grape, pear and the aforementioned citrus.  Biscuit and bready malt underneath as well as some cereal.  Hops have an almost vegetal quality, but avoid being offensive.  Medium body is somewhat sticky and resinous...distracting.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall a pretty solid beer.

On tap at Sweeney’s in Satin Paul, MN. Pours a clear orange with lots of pale yellow/gold swirling around, too; not much head and little lacing. It seemed too transparent, which, to me, is harbinger for a lack of robust flavor. Aroma is pretty faint -- just some vegetal hops. Carbonation is fine, but this beer is generally boring on the palate. Dominated by grassy, vegetal hops that lack any distinct characteristics. The malt was pretty absent, too, and the balance between bitterness, hoppiness, and sweetness was off. Mediocre, in my opinion.

On tap at the Winking Lizard Crosswoods location. Clear orange pour with a medium off-white head. Nice citrusy and piney hop nose with some sweet malt, but the nose is a bit more faint than I’d like. Grassy hop flavor up front mixed in with some pine and sweet malt before a citrusy hop finish. Great character in the nose and flavor, but could use a bit more of each.

12 oz bottle. Pours a light pale golden with a creamy frothy white head. Aroma is a beautiful bouquet of spicy, piney and citric hops, all melded together perfectly over a sweet toasty caramel malt backbone. Flavor starts sweet and creamy with a nice fresh citric fruit character, the hop resins kick in and add a layer of more earthy and piney hops before a soft bitter finish. Medium creamy body and a soft carbonation.  A great hybrid of american and english ipa’s that is very drinkable and refreshing.

Pours deep gold into a shaker.  Fluffy white micro head top hats as it recedes to coat surface leaving spot lacing. Orange resin aromas. Crisp with upfront orange pith turning to resin in the lasting finish.
Nice strong taste.  Bitter, with a bit of aftertaste.  Doesn’t seem to dominate the palate too much.  All in all, a hell of a way to start off my 21st birthday!
On tap at GI.  Pour is rich copper color with a thin white head.  Aroma and flavor are light hoppy (most pine and resin) with a nice balancing maltiness.  Solid all around IPA.

Bottle.

A - Slightly hazy copper amber with decent sized foamy white head. Decent retention and a fair amount of lace left over.

S - Good hop smell, with a good amount of citrus (orange and grapefruit) as well as some floral/herbal smells. Faint caramel malt.

T - A lot of varieties of hop flavors are abundant. Citrus (orange and grapefruit), a good amount of herbal/floral tea-like hops. Also a bit pine and pepper. The background has a bread/biscuit and slight caramel malt taste. This provides a base and balances the hops a bit.

M - Medium body and decent carbonation. Crisp and fairly smooth.

D - Pretty good. Fairly balanced beer with hops being the center of attention. Body pretty good for drinkability.

Notes: Pretty balanced hoppy beer. Not an amazing beer, but a good beer for a hop centered beer but not a really bitter or heavily hopped beer.

The look is very clear, a light orange color. Not much head, but lots of carbonation. A little hazy actually. Looks just about right, quite normal. 

Really nice grapefruity hop smell. That bitter grapefruit becomes sweeter on the longer drag. Smells very bitter and really quite good. 

The taste is very strong and bitter hops. The malt is nice and bitter, but also dry and biscuity. Very nicely balanced. The yeast is also another good added dimension. 

Feels thick and also very dry. Has a biscuit/yeast base, but also has a clean finish. It’s well balanced overall. Dry and bitter; bitter in both the hops AND the malt. A good, serviceable IPA.

Growler from Big Z Beverage.  Pours a clear orange with a thick, fluffy white head.  Aroma of citrus, rich hop oils, tropical fruits, grapefruit, and melon rind.  Flavor of plenty of citrusy hops, rich caramel malt, grassy and garlicky hops.  Very tasty, superbly drinkable.  This one surprised me since I never really heard anyone mention it as a top IPA, but I found it to be quite good.
8/4/8/4/15 [3.9/5]

Small white head, steadfast, lasting with a nice lace. Hazy yellow/gold color. Nose is nice, fruity, melons, citrus, has that juicey aroma. Med/light bodied, moderatly resinous, good carbonation. Juicey hoppiness plays of some faint malty notes, notes of ink, pencil shavings and light malts are well balanced and enjoyable. Dry, snappy finish, good hop flavors. Good bitterness, nice balance, easy quaffer. Surprise!  Bottle procured @statelineliquors.
desde PR.  lastima que no nos hemos juntado ultimamente porque esta le va a gustar mucho al aleman y ramenend

12 oz. bottle.  Pours an orange color, with reddish and gold hues, and off white frothy head which lingers for awhile.  Aroma is citrus heavy hops, a grapefruit ipa.  Taste is grapefruit hops, which are evened out by some malts on the finish.  This is a straightforward IPA, not trying to do anything too crazy, but it does everything quite well, would be a good selection for any occasion.

Nice fruit, the best IPA I have tasted so far. 
It’s somehow more enjoyable then other IPA’s. 

Any day!!

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours slighlty hazy golden orange color with white head. Citrusy aroma. Flavor is grapefruit, oranges and a touch of malt sweetness. Medium body with average carbonation. Thanks Peter.

This beer pours a dark orange color with a pretty nice sized white head. Lacing around the glass sticks nicely and doesn’t fade to fast. Smell of citrus and hops sticks out. Flavor of hops and malts. Slightly bitter but very good.
Unclear amber of color with a off white head. An aroma of grass, hops, citrus, bisquit and malty notes. A flavor of grapefruit, hops, grass, bread and malty notes.
Very nice hoppy beer. Clean fresh tasting citrusy hops really stand out, and thick feel to it carries nice.

Sampled at Central New York Brewfest, Syracuse NY. 06FE10.



App.:  Slightly hazy deep golden with a rim of white.
  
Aroma:  Really piney hops, earthy, floral, a little citrus, some caramel maltiness.
  
Palate:  Medium body and sharp effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Lots of pine hops, plenty of caramel, peachy esters, floral, earthy tones; off-dry with reasonable bitterness.



Nice IPA.

Bottle, 5.9%. Good caramelly and grassy aroma. Clear dark golden colour. Good stable white head. The flavour is a lot like the aroma, with a caramelly sweetness and a good grassy hop flavour. Mild bitterness, not so strong, but clean. Well-balanced. Good mouthfeel.

355ml bottle. Porterhouse, Dublin.
Deep gold body, thick persistant white foam.
Aggressive hop aroma; lots of pine and grapefruit.
Full body, sticky texture, high carbonation.
Even more brutal hop on the body, spicy woodiness, citrus rind, very aggressive bitterness making a highly dry finish.
Full on IPA, that lacks a bit of malt backbone.

Tap at RNH.  Pours a light clear copper with a nice lasting frothy head.  Aroma is clean grassy herbal and light citrus hops- doughy malts, light caramel and toffee and fairly fruity even for the style.  Flavor is light citrus - mostly clean overall, toasted malts, light crystal, slight Amarillo tropical note, light pine and more citrus as it warms with some extra fruity hints as well- finish is pretty clean- well balanced and nice standard IPA.
Pours orange with white head, aroma is citrusy hops with some bready malt.  Taste is fruity up front with orange and lemon, leading into a biscuity and bready malt that finishes bitter.  Nice IPA.
Bottle, Pours a pale gold with a one finger moderately creamy head, aroma is hops and cereal malt, flavor is clean and matches aroma profile, finishes clean with dry hops

Hazy peach pour with a small, though nicely lasting white head. The aroma is juicy pine, earth, citrus, lemon, orange, and sappy resin. The flavor is fruity orange, tangerine, and apricot with definite backnotes of sappy resin, earth, and some sweet malt. The palate is medium bodied for the style with a lively caressing effervescence and a clean, flavor retaining finish.

Slightly hazy peach pour with a smallish but lively frothy white head. Aroma holds lots of citrus hop, notably orange, pink grapefruit, and lemon, along with touches of earth, floral, and piney notes. Flavor is quite solid; more citrus notes, but with an increased earth and evergreen presence in the form of moss, spruce, and some resin. Palate is pretty standard for an IPA of this caliber; medium bodied, with a lightly bitter finish. Above average IPA for sure.

Aroma is moderately hoppy with a strong floral scent. A nice golden color with noticeable haze upon opening. Taste is definitely the beer’s best asset. It goes down smooth, hoppy, and bittersweet, never too hoppy, sweet, or heavy. It’s just right. A personal favorite and one of the best IPA’s I’ve had

Pours a opaque yellow-amber color that reminds me of passion fruit.  Head was thin and white, but pretty stable throughout the entirety of the drink.  Smells of citrus fruits and some hops.  The taste had less fruity overtones and more floral hops and spices, although there was a slight citrus bit to it.  Decent amount of carbonation and kick.  As my first IPA, I was definitely impressed and will look forward to trying others.
355ml bottle. Golden colored body with white head. Floral and citrus taste and body. Mild bitterness and aftertaste.

Pours light straw gold with a decent white head. Nose is incredible with plenty of spicy hops, citrus, pine, grassy with hints of light malt. In the mouth, initially hops, but very well balanced with some light malt, and a lingering hop bitterness. An amazing example of an IPA... The best one I’ve had.
Pours a strawberry blond color with a creamy head. It has a nice floral hop taste and smell. It has a slightly mild butter scotch aftertaste.

Bottle:  Dark straw color with a lot of haze.  A finger of thick, creamy off-white head and heavy lacing.  Straightforward aroma is floral, citrus, and caramel.  Rather sweet.  Big impact right away with the taste.  Full of hoppy pine resin, florals, and citrus.  Caramel malts.  Rather intense and syruplike body sticks to the mouth.  Nice finish is hoppy and lingering.  Nice.

Bottle at the Relentless Thirst Tasting on 08/29/2009. Clear golden body with a medium creamy white head. Big floral and citrus hop aroma. Big floral and citrus hop flavor. Medium body with moderate carbonation.

Golden brown beneath a foamy white head. Lemony, herbal hop aroma. Clean bitterness, grainy malts, light citrus, some pine and a lingering soapy flavor. Spicy herbal hop flavor lingers on past the finish.

355 mL bottle.  Clear orange-gold with a small, quickly dissipating, white head.  Lotsa citrus hop in the aroma with a little spruce and sweet caramel underneath.  Flavour is relatively well balanced.  The malt profile is simple and a little "thin," but it makes enough of an impact to prevent this one from being one-dimensional.  Hops in the finish, but they don’t linger, which wouldn’t be a terrible thing.  Pretty good, though.

Hazy yellow golden pour covered by a creamy white head. Wonderful citrus hop aroma. Flavor is initially sweet, but quickly gains a terrific grapefruity bitterness that lasts and lasts. Medium to full bodied, the beer builds some foam in the mouth, and this is the weakest part of an otherwise near ultimate American IPA. It has been a reference American IPA for my part for the last couple of years.

Bottled 12/04/09, consumed 12/17/09. 

[A] Orange, lemon zest, spicy earthy hops, sweet malt backbone.

[A] Calm pour shows a golden amber color with one finger of white head. Quickly recedes to a slight foam with soapwater bubbles and decent lacing down the glass.

[F] Sweet pale malt, biscuity, seems to be upfront with fruitiness, juicy hops in the middle, and malty finish complimented by a resiny pine linger. 

[P] Nice feel. Decent bite. Good balance. Fairly sweet.

[O/D] $6 a 6 pack is a steal. This is a good brew, even if not the greatest IPA. Pretty damn fresh, too. I could drink quite a few out of bottle without noticing. Always something good from Goose Island.

Bottle  Pours a yellowish copper with a good white head.  The head lasts well and laced okay.  Has a good hoppy aroma of citrus, pine, and floral.  The carbination is good.  Flavor is good hoppy but not over the top.  Has an oily texture.  The body is light to medium.  Not a bad finish and a good aftertaste.  Not a super harsh IPA but real drinkable.

Pours a yellow orange, more yellow, pale color with generous white head. 

Very fresh floral and orange on the nose. Very tempting. 
On the palate is a seriously hopped melody of flavours that are still balanced with malt. Simple story executed beautifully - assertive hop character but still balanced and very, very drinkable. 

Among the best IPA’s I’ve ever had.

Pours a yellow/copper with a rocky off white head... Aroma of grapefruit, some slightly sweet malts, orange, some pine/wood... Piney/spicy flavor, not near the punch of citrus hops i was expecting, malts are more defined that the hops... Medium bodied/mouthfeel, quite drinkable... Decent, but not near the hoppy profile i expected....

Pours copper with a decent amount of white head and some lacing.  Excellent hoppy aroma.  Medium body.  Tastes of citrus and hops, but I would have liked a little more.  Not quite as in your face as the aroma is, but still a pretty good IPA

I’ve had IPA’s that were very sharp, harsh, perfumy and snappy bitter - too much so. This one is different. Everything seems right on. The Aroma is all hops. Appearance is dark gold/amber with fine bubbled foam. Taste and mouthfeel are wonderfully hoppy, smooth and soft with a dry finish. Not astringent at all. Hop flavor is flowery and lingers on the palate. This is an IPA and hops rightly dominate and overshadow malt.  Finest IPA I’ve ever had.

Bottle at about 6 weeks old. Amber orange with an off white head. Big hoppy aroma, with piney, spicy, and citric notes. The flavor is relatively well balanced, with some grassy and citric hop notes and a light malty swetness. Very nice.

Pours a yellow golden hue with a lasting white head. Aroma is very hoppy; floral, pine, and citrus fruits. Tastes of floral and pine hops, bisquits, grapefruit, and citrus with a bitter hoppy finish. Light bodied with medium carbonation. Very good IPA.

Bottle. Golden color, lasting white head. Piny hop aroma. Bitter hoppy flavor with grapefruit and biscuity malts. Dry finish. Medium-full body, medium carbonation. Not a bad beer, but just not my thing.

( 12oz bottled on 7/22/08 reviewed 6/4/09 -  thanks to bobby91w and sprinkle) Pours a beautiful orange color, full 1 finger head with thick oily bubbles that recede quickly, but coats the top of the beer most of my drinking session. Lacing on the glass is pretty nice as well. Smell is absolutely delicious. It’s floral, very citrusy, but the hop notes have subsided quite a bit. Taste is not even as hoppy as a pale ale at this point, but still a very good beer. Nice sweet malt backbone here, notes of hops are there but no bitterness whatsoever, even some caramel malt here because the hops are so subdued. Body a little thinner than expected, decent carbonation, not enough creaminess or oilyness that I prefer in an IPA.
Pours a nice orange/red with a thin white head. Smells of pine, citrus, and other fruits. Taste is of citrus, but also get some pine as well as some wood. Nice bitter finish makes this one nice IPA.
Bottled in May 09. Drank 11/1/09. Yellow orange pour with white lacing head. Citrus, pine, and slight floral aroma. But flavor has seemed to decay, slight hop and malt flavor. need to try this fresh!

bottle from bierkoning amsterdam. Pours a orange beer with a very good head. Head stays there for a long time. Strong aroma with hints of different types of fruits. Taste is very nice with sweet notes. The aftertaste is bitter. Very good beer. To bad its from USA so I can’t drink it everytime.
chiara buona schiuma piuttosto persitente naso luppolato un po erbaqceo intenso in bocca malto medi opoi luppoli intensi buona secchezza

31/10 0.355 l bottle courtesy of ogivlado, great thanks for sharing! It poured slightly hazy golden orange body with tiny head. Cascade hops (citrus fruits) and some malt in aroma, not too strong though. Flavor is bitter, but not too much, it’s pleasant orange fruity, high quality hops are felt in every aspect. Biscuit malt is rounding the flavor. Medium bodied with average, biscuit sweet and herbal bitter finish. Simple but nice beer, I liked it more than I liked Two Hearted ale, although I admit that one is a bit better in quality.

An extra from Eithcubes on our recent trade. Pours a light and dull orange color. Nice hop profile that evolves a bit as you drink through the beer. At first you get intense grapefruit bitterness. Later on down the road it changes to a more pine and resin stickiness. Aroma is mostly citrus. A bit of a sweet caramel working in the background. Pretty tasty for a straight IPA.
Bottled 355ml. -From Bierkonig, Amsterdam. Hazy orange/golden coloured, small white head, citrusy nose. Malty, citrusy hoppy and fruity with bitterish hoppy finish. Typical and good American IPA.

35.5cl bottle. Best before 2010-06-15. At Patricks. It poured a golden orange colour with a small white foamy head that vanished quickly in the glass. The aroma is hoppy with notes of fruits. The flavour is gentle and smooth for an IPA. notes of hops, malts, spices and grapefruit. It has a short aftertaste.

From the Bottle at the Smithfield Hotel, Manchester 18/07/2009
Hoppy aroma. Golden coloured fruity and hoppy with a little dryness and bitterness in a crisp malt finish.

Bottle that ogivlado shared with me and heavy (thanks!)
 Poured a slightly darker golden body with a medium sized white head that went away at a medium pace.  Strong fruity citrusy nose, sweet and nice. The taste is very agrumey, lime, lemon, really nice, solid hoppy bitterness, some fruity maltiness. Balanced and a quality IPA.

Tap. Amber with a white head. Aroma is pine/grassy with some citrus. Flavor is bitter with a lot of citrus and pine.Bitter finish.I’m not big on IPA’s But this one is ok.
Nothing special. my rating is low because of the fact I dislike IPA’s, but it’s pretty good for what it is. Nothing special though.

Poured from bottle into Tulip.

Semi-hazy orange with moderate head that dissipates a little too quickly.  Some nice lacing.

Relatively mild (for an IPA) floral and citrus hop smell, with some grainy malt.  Smells more like a Pale Ale to me.

Fairly grainy, slightly fruity malts with some citrus and pine hop taste.  Bitterness at the end is relatively low for an IPA.  However, there are some very strong pepper notes at the end that are a little distracting.

Pretty high carbonation for an IPA, with a light to moderate body and dry finish.  Not nearly as smooth as other IPAs I enjoy.

Pretty light American/English hybrid IPA that is great drinking for a summer day.

(bottle - 12 oz) Amber pour with a fluffy white head. Aroma is very mild with some citrus and piney hints. Flavor is bitter with a lot of citrus notes. Some flowery notes come through at the end. Rather juicy and citrusy. Alright, but nothing special.

Pours dark gold with a thick off-white head.  Nice tight lacing.  The aroma is malty with weak resin and pine.  A light tropical citrus comes out in the flavor which combines with a lot of malt and just mild bitterness.  A decent beer but I expected a little better.  The bottle is about 5 months old so perhaps it’s just past it’s prime.
Bottle. Hops, grass and soil in aroma. Golden amber colour with white head. Fruity and hoppy flavour. Surprisingly sweet with only moderate hops bitterness.Liquorice and wood in aftertaste.

6 pack from Richard’s Grocery in Plattsburgh, NY.  Born on 8/28/09.  Aroma is very pleasant with hints of pine and some slight citrus.  Definitely some C hops, and perhaps some simcoe.  Lightly husky.  Transparent copper color with a strong white head that leaves good lacing.  Spicy, peppery, and herbal hop flavors to start.  Some pale malts and a little earthiness is in the middle.  Finishes with a little sweetness.  A bit metallic, too.  A very serviceable, and clean IPA.
Not as strong or dry as other IPAs.  The hops do not give off as much aroma as Sierria Nevada PA or IPA.  It is a good beer to drink anytime. A bit above average but not great.
DØE Valby 09. Pours yellow with a white head. Aroma is light malt, grapefruit, citrus and peach hop. Flavour is light caramel, light bitter, light hop, grapefruit, citrus and grape.
bottle - very nice IPA - really enjoy Goose Island beers.  Solid IPA - smooth with strong characteristics.  hard to beat a good IPA.
Decent brew.  Citrus aroma (grapefruits, orange) with some graininess.  Flavor similar.
Lightly cloudy yellowish color.  Citrusy aroma dominates.  Flavor is very hoppy but not crazy bitter.  Decent malt bill too.

[First rating - 7/10/2009 -355ml bottle at the Oakford Social Club, Reading - RB score 7/3/6/3/12 (3.1)] Pours a surprisingly thick amber-gold with a thin white head and slight fizz.  Strong floral aroma.  Floral hops dominate the flavour with a biscuit-y malt behind.  Fleeting hints of juicy citrus in the middle (this needs to be souped up a bit) with a dry piney finish.  Bitter, but less so than I expected.  Left a little sulphur behind.  Not up to what I was hoping for, but OK. [2nd rating - 21/1/2017 - bottle that Jim shared, cheers - RB score 5/3/4/3/8 (2.3) Caramel and cardboard, Dirty pine. Poor by today’s standards.  Overall rate is the average of all rates.
Dark yellow and hazy. Has a clear hoppy aroma, citrus, crisp bisquit notes. Flavor starts light sweet and moderate bitter, finish is heavy bitter. Dry texture.
An excellent IPA!!  This beer has a wonderful hop taste, and not too bitter!  Smooth and clean, but enough bitterness to make you take notice.  This is one of my favorite IPA’s!
Light yellow pour with a white head. Aroma of spicy hops and nice malt. Nice malt flavor- hops balance well with it. Spicy hop flavor is prevelent in aftertaste. Lacing on the glass.

Bottle. Pours a nice light amber color with a medium head and lingering thin lacing. Light/medium body. It has a nice light aroma with some fruit. The flavor has a good amount of hops, but not very bitter for an IPA. The flavor is balanced, with a little malt and citrus. If anything the flavor is a bit understated, except for the loud hops. This is an above average IPA, but the flavor doesn’t have enough complexity to make it an exceptional IPA.

Bottle. Pours a clear, light amber with a towering, tan head that has good retention and lacing. Aroma is buttery biscuit, some lemon, light citrus, tropical fruits. Taste is similar with lots of bready malt, lemon, fruits. Not very bitter. Buttery, rich on the palate. Not bad but fairly mediocre. A lovely session beer, but I would put this more as an amber ale than an IPA. But maybe this is just what a normal IPA is like rather than a enormous hop-bomb. I would perhaps use this as a starter beer for those just getting into the craft beer scene.

Cloydy, light yellow beer with medium white head. Aroma is quite very fresh and aromatic, full of tropical fruits, peaches, mangos and grapefruits also lots of fructose. Flavour is quite similar than aroma, fruits, peaches, mangos and medium bitterness with grapefruits that dryes the aftertaste nicely. Pleasant to drink, quite low carbonation and surprisingly sticky and almost full bodied. Fruity hops dominates to Goose Island IPA, but even more hops would be great, because a strong body could be handle that easily; great and enjoyable beer.

Bottle.  Pours gold with a large, frothy white head.  Sweet, citrus aroma.  This is also the dominate inital flavor before eventually turning slightly more bitter-hoppy at the finsh. Softly carbonated with a watery texture.  A well balanced brew that doesn’t try to kill your palate with bitterness.  I would say this is a good choice to introduce someone new to the style.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Pours an orange golden with a medium white head and an aroma of hops, cookies, citrus, grapefruit, sweet malts and grass. The taste is bready, with salty notes and notes of fresh citrus fruits. The aftertaste is really hoppy, but not too sharp or bitter. Really nice.

Pours clear orange with whiteish head that leaves lacing. Grassy hops aroma. Hop taste is most prominent midway through the tasting. Touches of lemon accentuate the taste. Some bready notes. Not very intense, but definitely a good session IPA. Doesn’t leave that hop aftertaste in your mouth like some beers do.

Pour from 12 oz bottle. Slightly cloudy tawny colored brew with a nice aroma of malt, butterscotch, bitter hops. Pleasant swallow with a fine IPA character, though a bit restrained in the flavor. The only downside ot this brew is that there is nothing here that is really distincitve -which is more of a commentary on how wild many other IPA’s have gotten. Overall, this is one fine brew.

Sampled at DØE Beerfestival 2009, Valby. Pours a clear yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is hops, citrus and orange. The flavor is hoppy, and leaves a bitter palate. Overall a good beer with a pleasant hoplevel.

Pours a vibrant deep orange with small white head. The perfumy aroma is intense but well-balanced with prominent notes of grapefruit, honey, and orange. Flavor is hoppy with some lemon, honey, orange, and spice. Very well-balanced. Soft mouthfeel with a low-moderate level of lingering hoppiness. I expected this to be more in-your-face, but it’s surprisingly delicate.
Bottle at Beer Temple. Orange body with medium head. Hoppy nose and taste. Some bitterness and citrus. A bit watery. Pretty good IPA.

Pours a straw color.  Fluffy white head that stuck around with some nice lacing.  Small hop citrus aroma.  Bitterness is almost the first thing I taste but it’s not an overpowering bitterness.  Mouthfeel is nice and light.  Has some sort of dirty taste in finish.  Very mild IPA in my opinion.  Easy drinker.

Surprised to see I have not had this one before... Picked up at SL. Drank at home. Nice orange color, decent one finger size head. Good aroma of citrus hops. Taste is nice. Slightly fruity... piney nice little hop bite to it... Nothing mind blowing, just a solid IPA... Medium body, easy drinker at less than 6 percent.

Hazy orange look with a decent offwhite head. Aroma holds lots of grape and citrus with some sweeter orange notes aswell. Medium bitter very refreshing flavor with a medium sweet caramel backbone. Nice.

Appearance: Pours an orangeish amber color and looks very hazy with a thin white head. Leaves a little bit of lace on the edges of the glass. 

Smell: Heavy pine hops with rapefruit, orange, and lemon citrus smells.

Taste: Starts sweet and turns sour. Heavy grapefruit taste and there seems to be a bit of caramel to it too.

Mouthfeel/drinkability: Feels creamy in the mouth with active carbonation and a medium body.
Bottle. Hazy yellow color with great head. Hoppy and some citrus and licorice.
Pretty tame for an IPA- more balanced than I normally like but an easy drinking beer with a little hop kick at the end

Location: 12 oz bottle that jcos brought back from Cleveland, 9/10/09




Aroma: Citrus aroma, grapefruit, some floral hops


Appearance: Slightly hazy amber-orange color, lasting white head, decent amount of lace


Flavor: Nice, uncomplicated citrus hop flavor, some sweetness


Palate: Medium body, nice relatively long duration


Overall Impression:
This is a really solid, simple, but good, citrus IPA.  Not in-your-face, not overly complicated, just a nice, easy drinking, tasty brew.  Something that would make a perfect session beer &#40though it’s a little high in ABV for the true sense of the phrase&#41 for someone with similar preferences to me.
Pours a clear golden color.  Floral, sweet and grassy aroma.  Taste of floral hops with a slightly sweet, citrus finish.

Bottle - Amber with a slight chill haze. Fresh aroma with hops, grapefruit, pineapple and some spicy malt notes. Hoppy and bitter taste with pine, grapefruit and hints of peach. The finish is bitter with a slightly sweet element.
Bottle. Clear golden golden colour with a medium white moslty lasting head. Rich aroma and taste of floral hops and citrus with a nice bitter finish.

Goose Island India Pale Ale is a hazy golden beer that leaves a white ring around the glass.  It has a hoppy citrus aroma.  Pine resin is detected.  It smells slightly sweet and floral.  It has a lively, smooth medium body with a crisp finish.  It has a nice piny bitterness that’s well balanced by a light sweetness.  It tastes so fresh and so good!

Bottle. Pours clear golden coloured with a nice white head. Aromas of pine, citrus fruit, malt and floral hops. Crisp and clean flavour with notes of lemons, resin, sweet malt and nice semi bitter finish. Very refreshing. Great.
355ml bottle. Slightly hazy golden yellow body with small white head. Flavour is hops with notes of citrus.

Bottle from MGM Mankato, pours with a golden browncolor, foamy white head that lasts a few minutes.  Definite hop smell with some light floral and fruity notes.  Flavor is definitely dominated by the hops in a good way, with the citrus flavor sneaking in.  Lingering bitter finish that keeps the hops on your tongue.
soft mouthfeel and flavor, but very tasty. buttery maybe. I love IPAs and this makes no exception.

RBESG Sheffield 2009, day 3, Smithfields Hotel, Manchester. Bottle. Golden/amber color with a medium creamy head. Fruity hop aroma with a sweet malty background. Bitter, citric and piney hops. Very well balanced. Great !

Draft at GI Clybourn in June.  Not sure what’s really left to say that hasn’t already been said.  Pretty good IPA, nothing super spectacular, but like others said:  very refreshing.  I could’ve drank this all night.

12oz Bottle. Compared to other IPAs, this one is pretty mild, making it refreshing. Due to the fruity aroma and slight malty sweetness, this beer taste sweeter then IPAs I’m use to. I personally love the hops in IPAs, and wish more was in this one.

28.05.2004, 0,355l Bottle. Clear yellw colour with white head. This beer smells really nice with citrus and wheat. Very bitter but not so much malt. I think the body is a little to thin. Taste is refreshing and I really like the strong bitterness.

The nose was earthy and floral hops.  The appearance was true to the style, red/gold color, white head.  The flavor was a mix of citrus and earthy hops, slight taste of metal.  The finish is entirely citrus hops, again witha slight taste of metal.  Relatively thin mouthfeel, not sticky. Excellent overall.   Very nice and refreshing on a hot day.
12oz bottle into a pint glass.  Not a bad entry from one of my favorite Chicago brewers.

Pours a nice clear orange with medium white head, decent lacing.  Aroma mostly of citrus hops, slight floral, and some light fruity notes.  Flavor matches well and leaves a nice hop bitterness behind.  Slightly slick mouthfeel, but a nice IPA anyway.
FCBF 09  Too much hops for me.  Overpowering in the aroma and flavor.  Others might like that though.
FCBF 09.  Big floral nose along with lots of pine.   Astringent mouthfeel.  Typical of the style.  I am getting so I have difficulty telling these apart.

Bottle. Light orange, 5cm white head, good amount of lacing. Aroma is very fruity. Mango, sweet orange, some resin and some malt sweetness. Nice. Flavour is pretty much the same notes. Body is medium to light, carb is refreshing, but not too harsh. Not complicated or exciting in any way, but a solid representation of the style. Nice and sessionable.
12oz - Nice palate, color and lacing, a bracing scent of hops on the nose.  The flavor on the first sip seemed a little sweet, but subsequent sips were a solid, fresh, bright IPA.  I liked it.

I’ve been drinking some great IPAs recently and this offering from Goose Island stands of reasonably well. I had it tap at the Waterstone Grill on Stone St. in NYC. A nice light red coloring and a subtle, fine head. Mild aroma of citrus and pine from the hops. Taste reinforced the hop sensation with a slight bitterness and a smooth finish. Aftertaste seemed to be a little off but I’ll bet it was the tap and not the beer per se. Overall a tasty beer and highly drinkable.

Bottle at Chicago airport.  Very citrus aroma with plenty of pine and a nice lightly sweet malt aroma, as well.  Rather bitter flavor.  Pine, grapefruit, and citrus with a little malts to support it all.  A very pleasant way to spend my layover.

Bottle from Chevy Chase Wine & Liquors in DC.  Bright, clear golden-amber appearance with a medium white head.  Great aroma of citrusy/piney hops with a little bready malt.  Flavor is well-balanced with caramel and pilsner malts with slight graininess and lots of pine and citrus hops.  Medium-bodied and crisp.  Really good.
Bottle.Golden colour with medium white head.Aroma is bitter and fruity of pine and citrus,bitter hoppy with long well balanced mouthfeels and dry finish.

12oz bottle.  clear copper under a large creamy white head.  not particularly potent aroma but enough peachy, orange, citrus hoppiness to keep me interested.  body is bit thin in this one.  flavors of bittering hops, mostly citrus, and very light biscuity malting...a bit too light though.  nice lemony, citrus finish.

Bottled 355ml. It pours a light amber beer with an average sized off-white head. Decent hoppy nose. The flavor is okay with a slight hint of rice sneaking in. Balanced. Not really my kind of IPA but still rather enjoyable.

RBESG Sheffield 2009, day 3, Smithfields Hotel, Manchester. Bottle. Light hazy golden colour, creamy white head. Aroma of toffee, fruits, hops and citrus. Flavour is sweet, fruity, caramel, sharp green hoppy finish. Medium bodied. A sweet IPA.
Poured a clear amber with medium white head. Aroma is hops and citrus. Thin bodied, but still had some solid bitter hop flavors to keep me interested.

Bottel, Rehills, Newcastle. Extremely fresh hop aroma, you can almost taste the hop leaves!!. Lime and orange flavours evident. Becomes faintly chalky and grassy, clean tasting. quite a smnack of bitterness, leaving a sharpness on the back of the throat.
Bottle. Pours tangerine, with wispish head. Aromatic aroma, almost of perfume, of very sweetly spiced hops. Similar on the palate, with little carbonation, and the hoppiness more to the fore.

(Bottle, 0.355 l, at Olutkellari Helsinki on 2009-07-11) Golden and almost clear. Small and quite quickly disappearing white head. Grassy and fruity aroma. Medium bodied and dryish palate with medium carbonation. Fruitiness, citricness, lightly grapefruit, malts and bitterness in taste. Fruity and bitter aftertaste.

bottle.
Pours a clear golden orange color, nice inch of thick off white head that lasts well and leaves plenty of lace.  Good looking brew.  Nose shows plenty of spicy and earthy, floral hops, some smooth biscuity malt.  Good aroma, if slightly muted.  Flavor starts with a clean, crisp punch of spicy bitterness, moves into some light floral notes, bits of clean citrus.  Clean, dry malt backbone.  More light bitterness on the finish.  Palate is crisp and clean, medium carbonation, with a lightly bitter finish.  Overall a very good IPA with a somewhat unique hop profile.

On tap at Goose Island Wrigleyville.  Pale amber/gold with frothy white head.  Aroma of pine, citrus, and grass.  Taste a bit of citrus, hops, pine, mild caramel malt.  Medium mouthfeel, crisp and quenching.

12 oz bottle. Pours a relatively clear golden orange color, with a medium white foamy head. Aroma is floral hops, slight sweetness, pine. Flavor is a medium hop, lightly bitter, with a creamy, refreshing finish. Extremely pleasant IPA. I enjoyed this one.

Pours a golden amber with a frothy white head that retains fairly well and leaves decent lacing. Aroma of earthy, floral, hops and a good dose of English malt. Flavor is not very strong, but a balanced blend of said malt and a floral hop that leaves a fair amount of bitterness. Has a light, sharp, mouthfeel. An IPA representative of the original ales that defined the style. Not bad, but I do prefer the latter American counterpart.

12 oz. bottle. pours a thin head of short duration, with some lacing, over a clear honey colored (SRM 10 ) body.....nose is mild grapefruit, pineapple, ginger......taste is initially light roasted malts (toffee, bread), then light hop bitterness with some grapefruit tones, which linger......mouth feel is a bit light, carbonation is medium. A fairly typical American IPA.
(bottle). Pours a clear, light copper color. Medium off white head. Hop/citrus aroma. Hop flavor with light bitterness. Avg duration. Slick texture. Good lacing. Soft carbonation.

Somewhat cloudy golden in color with a white head, decent lacing.  Pine aroma with floral and citrus hints to it.  Definite hops in there and in the taste as well.  Starts out bold and continues you throughout.  Light citrus taste underneath the hops.  Bitter finish turns me off a bit, admittedly though, I am not a big IPA fan.  That being said, its a pretty decent representation of the style.

Pours a moderately cloudy golden with a medium white head. Floral aroma on the nose with citrus and caramel. Nice hop flavor up front, but not too bitter. A slight sweetness in the finish. Not one of the hoppiest IPAs I’ve had, but still a very solid offering.

Pours an orangey copper color. Moderate head. Aroma is floral and citrusy. Flavor is not bad, some hops, citrus and a good bitter to it, but doesnt stand out by any means. Good beer for drinking on a hot day.

It is a warm golden beer with a creamy head. The aroma has notes of mango, citrus, peach, spruce needles and caramel. The flavour has a light sweetness and notes of fruit, mango, citrus, spruce and caramel. It is very well balanced and charmingly uncomplicated.
On tap at Rattle N Hum (NYC): A solid IPA. Fruity aroma coupled with a flowery bouquet of hops flavor refreshes the palate with each taste. Pleasing and wonderfully simple. #003 on 14062009, DG.

a good but not great ipa - a little bit of sourness and that chalkiness you get really bad in porters - but nice hoppiness - could be sweeter, but probably not unless it was also hoppier and more alcoholic - I think I just like my ipas a bit more bigger in every way.

12 oz bottle. Pours a relatively clear golden orange color, with a medium white foamy head. Aroma is floral hops, slight sweetness, pine.  Flavor is a mild hop, light bitter, with a creamy, refreshing finish. Extremely pleasant IPA
On tap at Wrigleyville Goose Island. Poured a clear gold with a white head. Aroma consisted of piney hop notes, nothing too complex. Flavor was nice w/ a good balance of hop flavor throughout.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with large creamy white mostly lasting head. Hoppy aroma. Fruity and bitter flavor. Creamy palate.

Bottle from Wholefoods in Kensington, London. Amber pour with a smallish head. Pleasant aroma of hops and citrus fruit. Quite bitter, fruity, hoppy. Nicely balanced IPA. Not as complex as some but fine for an IPA and good value.

Bottle at Apotek, Turku. Golden to light amber, firm foamy pale head. Quite sweet honeyish nose, good flowery hops, mineral notes, that sugary sweetness disturbs a bit. Simple bitter flavor, citric zest and little flowers, clean sweet maltiness, long citric bitterness. Light to medium bodied, strong spritzy carbonation. Didn’t offer much, not even that refreshing because of the sweetness.

Bottle, 29-MAY-2009.
Slightly hazy a little light with orange hue and white head.
Nice nose of hops.
Very grape fruity, and very bitter.
If only one kind of IPA existed, I could live with this one. It goes well with food, and also alone. It is just a nice beer, and although I have had better IPA’s, I will come back to this one.
Birthday present from Morten, thank you.

Thought this one was great. Nice and affordable as others have said, and along those lines as well it is also moderate in alcohol. I’d imagine I could drink a six pack of this stuff and neither tire of it or be too off kilter. That’s hard to find. But onto the beer.

Bright citrus bouquet of hops--orange, flowers, and lemony. The color is bright orange and not at all amber. There was a very full mouthfeel that was nice, considering this beer’s small footprint. I wish more places sold this one. This is the stuff go-to beers are made of.
pretty solid ipa, very clean and refreshing taste. Still has a nice hop taste while not being overly strong. Not the best IPA but I’d have it again.

One of my favorite IPA’s and it’s pretty affordable at that. Great aroma of spicy, floral and just a hint of citrusy hops. Flavor is nice and malty but balanced well with a very clean bitterness. Palate is very nice... It’s easy to put a few of these away.

Smooth and oily textured ale. Light amber golden body with small head. Beautifully touched by strong orange and grapefruit flavor with floral hop bitterness. Fruity-perfume smell. Dry bitter-fruity aftertaste. Medium carbonated.

Lots of frothy white head. Pours golden amber and clear. Flavor is bready, but balanced with hops. Probably the best example of a balanced IPA out there. The dryness from the malt combine with the hops to make a nice floral dry IPA.

Large, frothy head - appreciable lacing. Clear, sparkling amber with a thin, slightly oily body. The nose brings perfume, citrus and pine hops with a cookie-like malt backbone. The flavor is similar, earthy, herb hops with a hint of citrus and resin. Not bitter what-so-ever. Very smooth, sessionable IPA. Not the finest I have had, but the most enjoyment on the cheap, certainly.

(This is a hopheads’ review. You may find this slightly more bitter than I would. :D)

Bottle. Nice golden color. Thick white head. Aroma is really floral and fruity with plenty of fresh hops and a balanced maltbackbone. Taste is fruity and floral with some grape in there aswell. Good maltbalance to it all. Finish is bitter. Really tasty considering the 5.9 %.

Pours dark gold with a thick white frothy head.
Aroma is herbal hop and grapefruit citrus.
Flavour is good hop bitterness, some pale malt showing through and a bit of a thinning out towards the finish, though a nice lingering dry-ish bitterness.
Very drinkable
Hophead beer, realy a hops lover dream but a very hard bitterness some fruit aromas and liitle bit to strong carbonation, the hops rests long in the mouth
Bottle.  Pours a golden orange body with a white head.  Nice citrus and pine notes among a light caramel hoppiness.  Grass and a mild hoppy finish.  Needs more IBU’s.
Bottle.  Pours a deep golden color and a medium white head.  Citrus, hoppy aroma and a similiar tatste.  A good malty balance to this IPA, smoother and sweet than other IPAs.
This is a little thin for me.  It is worth drinking if you want something to slam.  Lacks the big hoppy flavor of a real Northwest IPA.

bottle thanks to swalden28.  poured a light gold with a nice white head that left some lacing.  aroma of pine, butter, and pineapple.  flavor of pine, grass, and pineapple.  light body and high carbonation.

Pretty solid IPA. Very floral aroma and taste to it. Crisp and refreshing finish. Bit of a change of pace from the usual IPA. It’s just different. I can’t quite put my finger on it. But it’s in a good way. Worth a try.
For the hop lover and once again this fairytale from a basic IPA. Nice starting aroma, but not during only during. Botlle
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are rich hops, flowers and malt. Average finísh.

cloudy orange, thick meium sized offwhite head. looks real nice.
aroma can be detected far away from the glass. strong aroma of sweet pine, sweet grapefruit. quite dry. but also sweet. great simple hoppy aroma.
flavor is hoppy, malty sweet, hops are sweet but not fruity, beer is quite dry. malts and hops balance nicely. aftertaste is dry and slightly malty sweet. truly impressive given the alc %. very nice IPA.

It pours a remarkably light-color, the straw shade of a cream ale. This is a bit strange, as pale ales tend to have caramel malts to provide a bit of sweetness in order to balance the hops, and caramel malts add those rich reddish browns. It is fairly clear but there is certainly a bit of haze. The off-white head is creamy and strong, but not very voluminous. The nose is strongly of Pacific northwest hops: the floral grapefruit and orange character that defines American pale ales.

The flavor is at once creamy and sweet yet robust and bitter. Strong hop bitterness leads the way and doesn’t let up, providing a throughline that the rest of the flavor dances around. The hops aren’t content to be a bit(ter) player, though. Herbal, earthy, almost vegetal flavors intermingle with serious grapefruit, mango, and citric hoppiness. Notes of light malt come through: a clean and malty, almost bready, flavor. This contributes a bit of sweetness that is frustratingly evasive. For a moment it almost seems balanced, then the bitterness rears its beautiful head.

Bottle. High creamy and lasting off-white head. Slightly hazy peach coloured body. Pleasant hops dominated aroma with fruity notes in the background. Flavor with a good balance between the malt and the hops. Dry bitter and long lasting. Low carbonation. Alcohol level seems just right.
On tap at 123. A nicely hopped ale. Better than most in the style.  I have yet to try a GI i didn’t like
Flaske: God kraftig bitter duft. Blomstret smag på en meget bitter øl. Rigtig fin IPA men ikke speciel.

Bottle. Pours a hazy amber with nice white head. Aroma of some pine, pineapple, and some malt. Flavor of some malt, hoppy pine, nice small bitter that lingers a bit. Mouth feel is medium body with high carbonation. Over all, pretty good IPA, easy drinking and tasty!
Pours copper with an egg white head.  Taste and aroma are good hops, citrus and sweet orange flavours with a good bitter-sweet finish.  Very lttle alcohol apparent.  A good beer.
Orange pour with a white head. Pleasant aroma of hops and sweet malts. Very easy to drink. Great hop flavor throughout but not overly potent. Very balanced and sessionable.
Bottle. Pours deep brown, hazy with a minimal white head. Strong hoppy aroma. Powerful taste, starts quite sweet malty. slightly bitter mouthfeel.

On tap at The Hairy Monk in NYC.  Poured a nice orange yellow color, crystal clear with lots of carbonation.  Aroma was mild hops and malt.  Flavor was a bit hoppy, but nothing extreme.  Perfectly serviceable session beer, if a bit high on the ABV for a good sessioner.

bottle 33 cl. Small thick beige head that mostly diminished. Fair display of lacework. Clear amber color. Aroma of light sweet grass, light floral, caramel, toasted malt. Over the palade came light grapefruit, sweet fruity notes. Modium bodied, average carbonation, light dry texture. Moderated sweet and bitter flavor. Light dry bitter amd fruity sweet finish.

Pale yellow with white head and faint citrus aroma.  On the tongue, the hops step up in flavor and blend well with the malt.  Finishes clean and makes for a very nice brew.  On tap at Pour House in NYC

Tried from the bottle via utobeer. Tried this last week and when reviewing my notes the words sweet and soapy jump out at me! Smells ok, lemongrass and citrus has a light body and not to much bitterness unfortunately...i’ve had better APA’s to be honest!

very mild for an ipa quite smooth.not very hoppy. I once again I taste unsweetened ice tea. perhaps it is only my palate, but I  frequently find less hopped IPAs to taste this way. very drinkable but lacking the citrus I expect from an IPA.

This was from a 12 oz bottle and poured a cloudy orange with moderate head and good lacing. Big citrus nose and a smooth mouthfeel.  Flavor is bitter and show pine notes. Long  bitter finish. Very nice drinking IPA.

Consumed at fifty degrees. A nice surprise. Pours light orange with thin head and almost suspended carbonation. Smells of faint citrus and slight pine. Hops up front and bready out the back with surprising balance for the lack of abv. An enjoyable ipa, but nothing outstanding.
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Fantastic flowery powerfull aroma. Heavy bitter flavor. Long powerfull hoppy bitter finish. Creamy palate. Very good IPA.
BOTTLE / TAP: slightly hazy yellow pour, citrus hop aroma. Mouthfeel is somewhat malty/creamy, very pleasant, with a very well balanced malt/hop taste. Very good IPA.

Dark orange pour with light amounts of sediment. Aroma of tough hops. Taste is biting on the initial, with a decent amount of hoppy bitterness. Lingering bitter aftertaste. Would like more flavors than just hops.
Pours a clear golden woth white head and lacings. Sweet with some dryness. Quite hoppy with aromas of grapefruit and slightly citric hops. Soft carbonation. Medium body. Quite dry finish.

Spicey shoe leather, lemon with eraser adn cheap wine. This medium yellow beer with a white short-lived head is nothing if not interesting... Flavor is pleasant, bitter and sweet with something original in the middle. Citrus and pine in an old suitcase, Very drinkable, but the finifsh makes you want somethin else, so you take another sip to get rid of the plain bitter and dust. I bet a lot of people like this beer a lot!

Botella. US rating no. 400. Deep golden orange colour. Aroma of hops indeed with citrus and some ripe fruit. Very good mouthfeel. The flavour has a very pleasant fruity hoppiness with some citrus and little pine. Dry long lasting hoppy fruity finish. Nice!

Draft. Included as part of a sampler at the brewpub. Tried many of the GI offerings over several visits to the brewpub while living in Chicago. I remembered liking pretty much everything but do not remember specifics. 

3/10 - They now sell this in bottles on the east coast so I got to retaste. Upping the score as it is a pretty solid (though nothing spectacular) IPA

Bottled on January 6, 2009. Sampled at O’Hare. Pours a cloudy orange with a good head. The aroma has suggestions of citrus, lemon drops. It’s fairly bitter, but not strong per se. The flavor is woody and lemony sweet. I don’t find a lot of hop definition, but a pleasing level of bitterness is imparted. Think session level IPA. Clean, bitter enough, sessionable IPA.
Not as hoppy as I like but still a great IPA. It has a sweet aroma and flavor.  Mild Bitterness.  Pours a dark gold color

12 oz bottle at Stockholm Beer Festival 2008. Copper orange color with creamy head. Sweet aroma with strong hoppy tropical fruit scent featuring mango, apricot and lemon. The flavor is hoppy and firmly bitter with tropical fruits and hints of honey. Soft and very drinkable, excellent.

Bottle into Tulip.  Good but not spectacular aroma, good color and lacing throughout.  Medium-bodied; citrus & piney notes.  An above average India Pale Ale.  Good bitter finish and very enjoyable.  One plus is it is the only IPA at our WM Supercenter, so Cheers to that when I need an IPA fix and am among the masses!

Bottle.  Bottled on date:  01/02/09.  Pours a hazy amber with a smallish light-tan head.  Predominantly grapefruity aroma with some hints of caramel.  Medium-bodied with above-average carbonation.  Fair balance with some caramel biscuitiness upfront.  Finishes with lots of piney, spicy grapefruity dryness.  Fairly harsh at the end.  A solid IPA.

Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Clear amber/golden - nice white head. Nice hoppy aroma - american IPA. Toasted, knækbrød (swedish flatbread), citrus, peachy, abricot, grape, earthy, grassy, nice balanced malty sweetness. Medium bitterness. Bitter/sweet finish. Nice.
Overall a very nice IPA. Good hop character on the nose. Nice malty citrusy palate. Low to medium dryness, less attenuated than most of this style.

12 fl oz bottle.Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Peachy and grapefruit hops aorma, mild wooden tone. Flavour is sweet, smooth mouthfeel and with a light peachy and grapefruity note following. Bitterness into the finish holds a light pinewood note. Lasting sweet caramel malt impression.
what a nice beer. a little too frity of an aftertaste. the head fades too quick but overall a well above average beer. recommended.

Golden hazy hue. One finger of quickly dissipating head. Very small bubble lace that is also quick to disappear. Nice steady lemony hops aroma with some citrus in both the taste and aroma. Creamy medium body mouthfeel. Nice sweet maltiness to balance the hops. Very steady avg IPA. May be a good session beer

Bottle from The City Beverage Co, Old Street. Pours amber with a small white head. Nicely balanced bittersweetness, a touch of fruit and a dry hoppy finish. This is the kind of beer I could keep a stock of, extremely drinkable and great with a variety of foods. In all honesty, it prolly would’ve scored higher if I hadn’t had so many double IPA’s as of late.
Bottle. Thanks Nnudd. Clear yellow body with a meduim white head. Grassy and hoppy aroma with fruity notes. Lots of exotic fruit, hay, hops and malt in flavour. Long bitter aftertaste. Medium bodied.
From a bottle poured amber with a fair amount of head.  Nice hoppy flavor with a lingering finish.

Pours a clear pale color with champagne like bubbles and plenty of fluffy head and lace. Aroma is good lots of fresh hops very piney and grassy. There is a good bitter flavor fresh spicy hoppiness balanced by a mild roasty pilsner like maltiness. The palate is sharp, this is considerabally better than I remember.

This is a very good IPA.  Extremely well balanced between bitterness and taste.  The aftertaste of this beer is delicious as well.  I usually go back and forth between this beer and Dogfish Head  90 Minute in a night.
really tasty IPA. lots and lots of hoppy flavor combined with some fruity accents.

Bubbly pale orange with a sustained head.
Sweet and floury aromas.  Honeyed sweetness on the tongue. Very smooth with a buttery thick finish. A little sweet for an IPA. I know my score seems harsh but I drank this straight after a Stone IPA and there really is no comparison. 2.7

Now, having had this alone I have to say it is rather lovely.  The hop notes are so green and fresh. It reminds me of a Thornbridge Halcyon on a not-so-intense scale.
This beer has some really nice aromas of citrus and pine from the hops.  Lots of differing flavors of grapefruit, pine, and mild grassiness.  This is a very nice go to beer.
Bottle. Muddy yellow brown body. Small white head. Sweet hoppy aroma, much fruit. Strong fresh fruity flavour. Well-balanced bitterness. Medium bitter finish. (Lorry, Oslo, 07.07.08)
bottle pour- mellow citrus, pine and just a bit of honey aroma.  strong, punchy hops with a mellow bitter aftertaste.  I like it alot.  also, great relative value at $7.49 a 6 pk.

tap at goose island clybourn... nearly transparent orange brown pour with a medium to significant soapy white head.... aroma of light, clean citrus hops... citrisy hope flavors, a good portion of it grassy, and finishes off on a sweet/earthy bitter note. quite palatable and goes down easy.
Cloudy golden with medium off white head. Hoppy aroma with citric and piney notes. Somewhat dry and hoppy flavour with piney and grapefruit notes. This one finished bitter.
hoppy, spicy aroma; taste is balanced between fruit, herbs, and hops. A good IPA.
Drank from a bottle. Poured a cloudy, copper-like color with a small head. Smelled of hops and slight citrus. Really well balanced taste with a little bite on the tongue. Very good IPA from Goose.
