Tap...  Poured clear orange-amber with a frothy head.  Floral aroma with hops and malt.  Thick palate with a nice sizzle on the tongue.  Flavors of sweet juice and floral herbs, leafy hops and malt for balance.  Great, solid IPA.

Pours a light, murky orange with a small white head. Aroma is of hops, citrus, malt, and pine. Taste is of slightly bitter hops, with citrus and pine. Nice caramel malt backbone. Not overly bitter, but very sweet. A very drinkable beer.

hoppy citrusy armoma -pous a slightly hazy copper orange with a white head.  nice lacing on the glass- flavor is citrus and hops with a nice balance of malt - very nice flavor - this is not the best IPA but is a good one.  I really enjoyed this.  This is a fairly mild IPA and is very drinkable.

12oz bottle.  Lively frothy carbonation.  Filtered deep golden color.  UK IPA style, full of hop flavor.  Pleasant fresh grapefruit hop aroma.  This is a really well done IPA.  A very clean example of a world class IPA.

Bottle.  Pours coppery orange with smooth frothy head that lingers for a short while.  Smells sweet and floral and citric, with some pine and grass.  Tastes very smooth, sweet and hoppy,  citric fruits present.  Finishes smooth with a piney aftertaste.

Courtesy of gillard.
Pours golden blonde with white head.
Aroma, sugary, hoppy fruity (grapefruit) and nice grains / malts.
Taste, nice caramel malt, hoppy floral / piney.
Very well balanced between malts and hops, doesn’t have the high bitterness of the west coast ipa’s.

I first tried this at a live theater, on tap, from a plastic cup. I was pleasantly surprised. Next time from a bottle with a proper glass, deep golden,off white head. I like the strong hops. I have a friend bring me a 6pk whenever he visits from Naperville, IL.

Pours a golden color with a white head.  Tastes of citrus and hops.  Really a great IPA

Draft pint at Brazenhead in Dublin, OH

Bottled. Aroma has citric and flowery hops, some malts. Clear, golden-yellow coloured with a white head. Taste is bitter, slightly sweet, has citric and flowery hops. Quite mild in the style. Not a bad thing.

Bottled. Clear golden color, short head. Nice aroma of fruity and flowery hops, lavendel.
Taste of bitter berries (gooseberry?), quite bitter.

bottle poured a golden in color with a one finger frothy white head that retained fairly well. aroma has citrus and pine hops, juicy fruit, sweetness, and grapefruit. fairly hop hefty with a nice resinous tone. lighter mouth feel with average  carbonation. flavor is hop centered. bitterness gets hold over a citrus, pine, and grapefruit medley. plenty of sweetness and just enough malt to hold it together well.

(10/9/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Clybourn, Chicago. Clear golden to amber color. Floral hops in the nose with some grapefruit and some tropical fruits. Flavor begins slightly malty and turns into pleasant citric hoppy bitterness. Medium-bodied. Nice.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a nice goldenrod color, nice pearly head with good lacing.  Aroma is a bitter hops, some spices.  Flavor is hoppy, and ends on a musty note with currants.  All in all it’s an okay IPA, not quite enough flavor for me, however.
good full bodied pour with full white head, full smooth palate, light citurs backgrounds and mild bitterness

Pours slightly hazy, wonderful golden colour. Medium, but enduring head. Resin, stonefruits (peach, dried apricots), pale malt and hints of honey and spice on the nose. Quite good gypseous mouthfeel. Aroma in the mouth follows the nose with a pleasant, mellow bitter finish and well balanced discreet malt sweetness. Quite long. Overall a very well composed, delicate, elegant and drinkable IPA.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Pale yellow gold with lasting head and lace.  Fresh citrus hop aroma.  Very mild honey sweetness (even warmed up) almost nil fruitiness, followed by a bracing hop bitterness and dry finish.  Somewhat out of balance, but I like hops like the next guy.  Medium body and somewhat medium high carbo add a little unnecessary bite. Not bad. And a rarity for Long Island, it’s fresh.  Extra points for readable date code.
Decent IPA.  Very nice balance of sweet and bitter with a lingering bitter finish.  It’s no Two Hearted, but it’s one I’d get again.

Aroma: Strongly coniferous, hints of ripe fruit. Appearance: Hazy caramel color with two fingers of off white head.  Leaves thick rings of lace all down the glass.  Flavor: Piny and citric hops at the fruit.  Notably fruity-sweet malt body, finishes grassy with apricots and biscuit, lingering floral bitterness.  Palate: Juicy mouthfeel, lively carbonation.
Just an average IPA.  Not enough hops for an IPA.  Palatable, more malty than hoppy.
From bottle. Part of May Dayton Beertasting event.  Pours golden amber.  Piney hops dominate the nose.   Crisp taste with caramel malt finishing off.  Nice effort.
Clean piney hoped nose. Deep amber golden color, minimal light head pretty decent fingers. Earthy, grassy hops throughout. Crisp palate with lingering hops

I’m not a big fan of this beer.  It smells intoxicating, but the taste is ...soapy.  I know I use that a lot to describe this kind of beer, but thats what it tastes like to me.....nice color, great foam.....and the taste isn’t bad...but its just something off-setting to me!
bottle. Colour is orangey amber,nose is floral wit a hint of sherbert.  a mildly toffe hint to the flavourwithout being cloying. very pleasently surprised!

12oz bottle. Pours hazy amber with a thin, whispy white head, some lace. Smells of faint, ripe citrusy, very slight nutty scent. Tastes earthy, slightly nutty, slightly astringent, semi-flowery and citrusy hoppy. That’s right, I said it. Soem sweet malt flavors linger. Medium body, good carbonation.

Bottle, light golden in color.  Slight haze. I have seen this IPA really extolled in a lot of Mags, which makes me wonder.  it’s a nice IPA but no way best in class. Modest Head, very little malt or flavors overall, no Hops odors, more like an APA.
8/19 on tap at GB, Raleigh Airport

Pours a lightly hazy deep amber with nice golden highlights and a medium foamy off white head that laced.  Aroma of floral and citrusy hop notes, caramel, toffee and nuts.  Flavor of fig newtons, toffee, caramel, nuts, floral, light pine and citrus.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear dark gold with one finger white head.  Nose is caramel malt and light hops.  Taste is sweet malt upfront with a mild hop finish.  Medium mouth feel.  Meh, not one of the better GI offerings.
12 oz. bottle.  A very good beer that I can find nearly anywhere.  Not the best, but better than most.  A good burst of hops that doesn’t linger very long.  Easy to drink.
Tap.  Very nice hops with a citrius aroma.  Appearance is very nice brown color and nice head.  Flavor very nice.

12oz bottle... poured nice golden color, decent head, decent lacing.  Wonderful aroma of citrus.  I wasn’t overly impressed with the flavor.  It started off strong with big dose of hops, but didn’t hold well and finished abruptly.  I was looking for a little more body out of this one.  This is a refreshing beer.

Pours a nice dark amber in color.  There’s about three inches of head atop the beer.  Smell is piney hops.  Taste is more of the piney, grassy hops.  There’s a little bit of a juicy, citrus hop flavor as well.  Very good, biting mouthfeel.  This is a good IPA.

On tap in manhattan. Pours a clear maroon color, very attractive looking right from the start. Aroma is very very hoppy and floral with a little citrus and pine. Taste also reflects the high hop character and is bitter but balanced out by sweet citrus. Palate is smooth given the bitterness. Solid domestic IPA.

One of my go to beers. Goose’s IPA is a nice, easydrinking balanciado of pleasant citrusifruit hoppage and malt just light enough to avoid disturbances. Very tasty and easily my favorite of the Goose six-pack selections.

I’ll be honest. I have always been a big fan of Goose Island.  They may not be considered one of the best micros in America, but I believe that their beers are all extremely well-crafted and very true-to-style.  Of the many IPA’s Iv’e tried, this one has long been one of my favorites for it’s high drinkability and awesome balance.  It pours a neat, appetizing rustic orange color with a medium to small head that quickly dissipates into nothing.  The aroma is fresh and curious; full of orange marmalade, citrus, spruce and pine.  The beer screams "Drink Me!" from the first sniff.  It has the utmost hint of toasted malt and a fuzzy, charming tongue-tingling mouthfeel, shining before the bitter, drying, ultra-appetizing finish.  The taste is blustery, spicy and peppery and has a whole lot of orange peel, citrus zest, chives, and a woodsy, minty, coppery palate.  I love to pair this beer with some aged swiss, cream havarti, or smoked gouda.  It is, in a word "stupendous."  The finish is very long, leaving a pleasant, lingering orange-flower taste on the tongue.

Draft at Goose Island Clybourn brewpub.  A clear pale gold, little head or carbonation - seems to be a trend here.  Lovely aroma of... well... of marijuana.  Lovely fresh hop flavour.  And there’s that weed again.  This is wonderful stuff.  The star of the show at Goose Island this evening.   They are out of the Imperial IPA - I can’t imagine what that would be like.  Hard to top this.

Pale gold color, nice head, frothy and lots of lacing.  Mild aroma of grapefruit.  Flavor was a tad weak and disappointing, as hinted by the pale color, I guess.  This was more of a pale ale than IPA.  Not bold or assertive in any way.  Good, but not to style.  Refreshing, that’s about it.
Good hoppy American IPA. Sweet aroma with a good solid hop flavor which I really enjoy. Thick white head slow to disintegrate.
Awesome IPA. Lots of hop aromas than reflect beautifully in the flavor with some hints of sweetness and a solid bitter finish. great beer.
Unclear orange and creamed head. Nice hoppy fruitaromas and also very wellrepresented with hops in the flavor. Dry and crispy in the finish.

Poured from bottle (8/2008).  Lotsa hop in the aroma, as it should be.  Cloudy amber, thin head persists.  High amount of hops in flavor, but not overwhelming, and a great blend with the malt.  Creamy feel.  Good finish.  Another great IPA made in the USA.
Pours a dark yellow, almost orange color with a small head that lingers for a long time.  Sweet hops smell with a taste that is even sweeter.  Nice bitter finish.
draft at brewpub- a nice and tasty beer with a fine crisp dry finish that I always enjoy in this style. Although far from the best in class, I would go to again.

Pours a clear copper amber with thick white head that dissipates to a bit thinner layer. Aroma is strong caramel and hops. Flavor is solid hops with caramel undertones. Pretty standard IPA nothing amazing to note. Body is light the high carbonation.

Crushed a lot of these last weekend at pitchfork music festival at Union Park. Really everything you could want in an IPA: nice strong hop taste, good caramel backing. But, honestly, in the 90+ degree heat, it’s hard to drink a lot of these. I still did, but it was hard. But, you know, I’ve always believed hard work reaps big rewards.
Amber colored with a modest aroma for an IPA.  Great hop/malt balance and not as much floral bitter as most IPAs made with the american hops.  Good IPA.

On tap at Quintons.  Nice and hoppy aroma, citrus lemon mostly.  Came with a decent small sudsy white head, ok lacing, blonde orange in color.  Taste is nothing really too crazy but good, alot of fresh citrus hop, some GI style roasty toffee-caramel type malt, good finish, slight spicy hop bite, medium to light feel.  This beer will always be dear to my heart, especially in IC.

12 oz bottle into tumbler.  Light bronze pour with a minimal white head.  Soft citrus hops define the flavor.  The is no alcohol presence at all.  Light carbonation and body.  Refreshing and drinkable brew.  Great for hot summer days/nights.  Overall: very solid.

just poured a 12oz bottle of this into my trusty beer glass. It has a nice orange/amber color. The aroma is a little weak for my liking. And then the taste; It’s a bit on the weak side for my tastes, It’s almost between a good pale ale and a mild IPA(which is kind of an oxymoron)
But I would buy it again, if the price was right
Cheers!

12 oz bottle from HyVee.
Aroma: Hoppy, citrus, not too complex.
Appearance: Orange, slightly cloudy, kind of thick coming out of the bottle. Head is small and looks carbonated. Goes away fast.
Flavor: Good amount of bitter hops, but not too much. Good carbonation and really smooth.
Palate: Medium body. Crisp, clean, smooth, bubbly.
Overall: Very drinkable. They serve it on tap in steins at DC’s in Iowa City, which made me very happy in school.

Bottle, at home with renffisch, 25th June 2008. Golden with a small white head, this has a good nose of honeyed hops. Flavour wise, it’s hoppy but with a lovely perfumy sweetness. Good palate with a lasting hop taste, but not too fierce either. A good IPA.

12 oz bottle. Poured clear amber with a medium sized off white head that left a nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus and floral hops and also fruity.  Flavors of caramel malts, slight citrus hops, floral, fruity esters. Medium bodied and a pretty smooth drinkin IPA. Not bad.
Golden in color with scents of citrus hops that dominate.  In the mouth it was medium-bodied and very well-balanced.  To repeat, the thing that strikes me most is the balance.
bottle. sweet citric hop, honey and nettles in the nose. Hazy golden colour, lacy white rim. well balanced bitter sweet. nice but not remarkable,

As a new beer drinker, I enjoyed the citrus and berry at the first few sips.  Aftertaste was not overpoweringly bitter but nicely hoppy and went down very nicely with a pork chop dinner.  Would most certainly buy again.

Pours medium amber with abundant white lacing. Nice floral and grapefruity aroma. The taste is a nice balance of citrus, hops, and malt. Medium body and not overly bitter. Final taste is warm grapefruit and nice malty sweetness. A most enjoyable IPA!

Copper-colored with loads of citrus for the nose.  More citrus than pine on the palate but distintcly un-balanced towards hops, just the way an IPA should be.  Completely under-rated here IMHO, this is my favorite straight IPA.  Thank you Goose Island.

This was the very first IPA I ever tried and it is still one of the best. Pours brown with a large white head. The hoppy taste is good on the palate. Goose Island knows their beers and this is one of their bests.
back to an old favorite. Aroma is leafy foliage from the hops clean and a touch of copper. great finish that Is bitter but also sweet malt. Copper color and not much head.

brown with large white head.  flavor initially of some crystal malt before a nice hop bitterness and flavor.  the malt aspect may not be as well balanced as some of the better versions of the style, but a decent representation overall.  not bad

Appearance: Dark golden, creamy foam/head.
Aroma: Fruity (again...).
Taste: Hopsy, very bitter.
Info: 355ml bottle, 19/9-2005, 21/300

Draft:  Light copper color with a fluffy white head...notes of light pineapple and mango hit leadoff and are followed up by a wonderful floral hop tone.  Medium-light body...flavor consists of a nice floral-citrus to start and finishes with a nice, bittered pineapple bash.  Good stuff, wish I could get this more often.

Bottle courtesy Gillard. Pours a clear copper with a one finger white head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of citrus and floral hops with a sweet malt backbone. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a moderate amoun tof bitterness. Very good.
12oz bonus from trading.  Pours orange with a tan ring.  Nose is slightly citrussy.  Taste is sweet and lightly hopped, eh.  Ok.  Shared with Cyn

12oz bottle. Pours a golden copper color with 1in. off white somewhat sustaining head that left good lacing. Aroma is spicy and fruity hops. The flavor is dominated by the fruit and spice and balanced well with a nice dry malt in the middle. Medium body with excellent dry texture and lively carbonation. An awsome tasteing well priced IPA. I will certainly enjoy more of this brew.

Bottle, courtesy Gillard. Golden straw pour, fuzzy white head, tons of lacing. Big hops in the nose, tea, citrus, vanilla, some smooth pineapple. Big hop flavors, soft and creamy citrus, vanilla. So smooth and drinkable, very crisp. Could drink a dozen of these.

Pours hazy hazy golden with a solid white head that stays until the first sip.  Great lacing on the side of the glass is left by the head.  Great bitter hops aroma of what smells to be fuggles and a slight fruity undertone.  Flavor starts off bitter of fuggles and moves into a great sweet malty flavor to finish.  Great IPA.

Pours kind of a smoky peach color, with 2 fingers of a fluffy white head. Floral hop aroma with a hint of pine. Well balanced flavor, very limited initial hop bitterness followed by a very nice sweet malt flavor. Nice smooth and creamy beer with a sticky and oily palate. An easy to drink beer, but a step below the top tier IPA’s in terms of complexity and flavor.
very light in body for as hoppy as it is.  moderately out of balance, bitterness stays with you a little too long.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. This beer poured a hazy light amber color with a small beige head that fades slowly. Some light lacing is left behind. The aroma is fruity, citrus hops along with some light toffee notes. The flavor consists of orange, grapefruit, and some lightly sweet malts. Very nicely balanced for an IPA. The mouthfeel is light and slightly watery. Light to medium-bodied. A solid IPA from Goose Island.
Bottle. Seemed like a pretty standard IPA. Good amount of hop bitterness which was supported nicely by a pretty strong malt backbone.

Golden pour with a red tint.  Thick fluffy white head.  Piny dry hop aroma with lots of roasted malt and fruit.  Sweet fruity start with hints of citrus and peach.  Hoppiness takes over.  There’s a surprising amount of malt.  Nice easy to drink balanced beer, though very weak for an IPA.
Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a white creamy head. Fruity hoppy aroma - mango, orange & peach - nice & inviting. Very dry & bitter taste with some caramel. Crisp & nice!

Inexpensive beer brought from Trader Joe’s.  Nice, easy drinking IPA with great citrus especially grapefruit aroma and flavor.  A bit too little hop bite, maybe a bit too much malty sweetness for me, but very nice.  I’m coming to understand I like this sort of beer more than the general rater.
Cloudy orange with a small white head. Caramel pine and citrus in the aroma. Dry with some malt flavour. Limited bitterness and hop flavour, but a tasty easy drinker.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a golden amber with a medium head.  Aroma is strong grapefruit hops with perhaps even a little lemon.  Flavor is at first dominated by grapefruit and other citrus flavors with somewhat low bitterness for an IPA, but unfortunately there are also some more grassy notes that throw the flavor off for me.  I enjoyed this at first, but it turned out to be a bit of a miss for me compared to where it started.
This was  a nice refreshing ipa with a good and crisp hop presence and a nice malt finish and a little bit of bitterness.CHEERS!
Bottle out of a variety pack.  nice refreshing India Pale Ale.  good amount of hops and bitterness.

courtesy of Toni Flükiger - pours a hazy dark orange colour, pale beige foam and a nice lace; robust flowery hoppiness with notes of cream and a touch of apricot; medium-bodied, quite oily with a moderate carbonation; solid but not aggressive bitterness; long bitter flowery finish - very good
Draft.  Golden orange in color.  Light hoppy aroma.  Citrusy, grapefruit flavors prominent.

Bottle. A hazy orange beer with a beautiful white head. The aroma is light - especially for an IPA - but there are some hops to be detected. The flavor is sweet grassy - quite nice - and with a dry end.

This was my first micro beer on my trip back from Japan to the States! I have to say after being stranded in Japan for 6 months it was nice to have a good American IPA for once. Bought this guy right in the Chicago airport on my way to Minneapolis. Pours out a deep amber color with a really nice and thick off-white head. Grapefruit hops and pine resin all over the place on this one. I could smell the beer as I was walking to my seat to enjoy it. Flavor is very much citrus oriented and is backed by caramel and toffee malts. However, I didn’t think that the hops really took away the sweetness that much. I know some people like their IPA’s a bit sweet, I’m not one of them. I like it hoppy and balanced this one was just a bit too sweet for me to really boost the rating, this being said, this is still an excellent IPA.

12 oz. bottle; bottled on 02/23/08. Nice citrus aroma. Golden amber color with a beige head. Medium body with mild, slightly fizzy, carbonation. Flavor is a lot of citrus and/or grapefruit hop over some light caramel. Good stuff. Nice bitter finish. Some floral aspects develop as time progresses.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear light amber color with a good sized white head.  The aroma is citrus (mainly grapefruit) and pine with a moderate sweetness.  The flavor is very much the same.  Enough malts to balance a bit.  The finish tends to the dry side with good bitterness.  Decent midwest IPA.

I was a little dissapointed with this....I think cause it was waaaaaaaaay past its best buy date so i think some of the flavors and aroma were off. not bad though I’m sure a fresh bottle would be outstanding!

Bottle@Home. Strong sweet fruity aroma, mainly grapefruit, light floral. Light amber color, beige head, good lace. Sweet, pretty bitter, grassy, grapefruit, some yellow sweet fruit as well. Quite full with a dry finish. Flavorful, easy drinkable, guess it has all it needs for an IPA.

this is better then two brothers heavy handed and red hook long hammer. i bring that up becuase ive just drank all three in a short period; ive had the goose IPA many times over the years but these recent sessions have brought it into perspective. for what it is -- a ’mainstream craft’ brewery with a non-imperial IPA -- this is above average. it is more bitter then its peers in the least subtle of descriptions, and furthermore just has ’balls’. im usually not so terse but this isnt the most complicated brew. however in its own microcosm of non-complicated brews, it seems to excel.

Bottle, so cheap it’s unbelievable.... The flavor is beautifully hoppy, citrus, and floral. I love this beer. It’s far from my favorite IPA, but for the price you can’t go wrong. This is a great summer BQ Beer.
Hopps prevail in this IPA, color is a little cloudy but a deep golden brown with a medium head.  Full body with strong taste
An extremely hoppy IPA. The hops can be smelt from a mile away and as soon as it hits your tongue, it won’t be forgotton. A true beer for hop lovers with a full body.
Bottle. Amber with a light white medium head. Flowery hops - not as strong as I hoped. Strong lasting bitterness with minimal malt to back it up. Good full body.
This beer poured a little lighter orange colour with a very small white but pleasently aromatic head. Taste was moderately hopped, but nice finish with a classic citrus tone that lingers for a while.

Tap: Clear copper color with a weak aroma and taste.  I was really disappointed since I was expecting a bit more from Goose Island.  I am surprised to see it rated so highly.  It just seemed like an average IPA that didn’t stand out in any category.  Call me crazy, but I’ll pass this one up next time.

I really like IPA’s and this is deffinately up there on my top IPA’s. It has great flavor , taste, aroma and appearance.
I will deffinately buy this beer again.

There are much better IPA’s in my opinion but I still enjoyed this a lot. The smell let it down, slight clorhine (sp?) kind of smell. Lacks knackers for a too high rate but drinkable enough for sure. A little bitter for me but I’m in no way slating this as I thought it was very nice.

Bottle, Ale Cellar, Darlington. There’s a goose loose in tha hoose...Pours a warm golden colour with thinnish white head. Citrus hop aroma, piney grapefruit hop flavour balanced nicely with maltiness. Superb hop bitterness to finish.  Very drinkable.

Goose Island India Pale Ale is a slightly hazy amber color with an off-white/creamy colored head. The aroma is of spicy/mild hops and the taste is very light yet nicely bitter. This is a very easy to drink beer with a great taste.
Pours a golden color with white head that falls slowly.  Smells of spicy hops.  Taste is all hop with a hint of licorice at the end.  Medium body with mild carbonation.  A good pale ale.

Bottled at Monks Café, Stockholm. Pours out in a clear orange colour with copper hints. The foam sinks quickly. Really fresh and airy hop aroma of flowers, wet grass and dried oranges. Clean resinous, but not overly bitter flavour of orange-peels, flowers and minerals. Medium bodied. Long medium bitter finish of orangey and minerally hops. A well-balanced US IPA, well-made but lacks the bite.

This beer really embodies what an American-style IPA should be.  Great balance between the malts and hops.  It pours a copper color, not brilliant in appearance.  Comes with a good head that lasts till the end.  This is a pleasant beer that can be drank for awhile.  Out of the tap it pours much clearer, and has a more noticeable hop aroma.
A Tasting at Three Cellars Milwaukee. Yet another good beer from Goose Island. This is a little lighter than most IPA’s. But is very good none the less.
At Three cellars tasting. Amber with sweet hoppy aroma. Somewhat fruity tasting, decent hop finish though a little light for an IPA.

Cloudy orange in color, head dissipates quickly.  Hop pellets on the nose.  Aroma and taste are consistent, balanced and consistent flavor throughout- evenness of hops.  Mouthfeel is surprisingly creamy / heavy / suspended vs being sharp.

Golden amber body with white head and lacing.  The aroma is wonderfully citrusy and floral.  The flavor is similar with plenty of flowery hops, but is nice and clean on the palate.  A nice balance of malts and hops.  However, as an IPA, it’s not too striking.
Decent hop presence, not a knockout, but definitely there. Good bitterness and nice malt undertone. Could have a better aroma, but overall, not too bad.
Tap @ Wriglryville.  A nice brew.  Moderately hoppy.  Great lacing.  Very drinkable.
pours dark gold with a quickly dissipating head.   the nose is hoppy.  the flavor is hoppy and bitter but much too simple and mild to be a righteous IPA.  not a bad brew, just not an interesting one.

One of Goose Island better general beers.  GI is a solid if unspectacular brewery, but this one’s quite nice.  A hazy gold with a nice white head, decent lacing.  Floral aroma, nice bitter hop flavor, plenty of malt.  It’s a standard but well done IPA.  Quite drinkable.

A solid IPA.  The hop complexity is low, but its not thin, for sure.  There is a solid bitter presence as a backbone, which I appreciate.  Could use some more aroma hops.  Overall, its pretty well balanced and drinkable.  Nothing offensive I can find about it.  Enjoyable.

Pours a hazy amber-orange with a loose, frothy, off-white head and a jellyfish-like, cloudy yeast formation at the center of the glass. The aroma is of biscuity malt backed by floral and lightly fruity hop notes. On the light side of medium-bodied and silky-slick, the mouthfeel finishes with a moderately bitter, tongue-squeezing finish. It’s a bit thinner than many IPAs, but it is also amazingly quaffable for the style. Pale malt with a light biscuit note, backed by bitter, floral hops. This is a nice, hoppy treat and is extremely drinkable. I was fairly impressed by this one.

Bottle. [thank you, Yngwie]
Pours a nice hazy pale amber with a 2 cm thich creamy white head on top. Wonderful lacing in big blotches. Aroma is strong, with lots of pine hops, mixing with caramel, grapefruit, light roastiness. Low to medium carbonation and a rather creamy feel. Flavour is relatively sweet at first, lots of caramel and herbal hoppy sweetness. Middle is dry and pine-like hoppy, before a long lingering dry aftertaste of fruity hops mixed with that light roast that appeared in the aroma as well.

A hazy pale amber beer with a lasting white head. Hop aromas are grassy and slightly spicy. The malty aroma is of fresh sweet wort. Both play a big part which is great. a very creamy mouth feel, the carbonation is pretty much perfect for the beer. Awesome balance for my palate at least. Distinctly american but also tradtional in many ways.

Clear gold with a frothy white head. Excellent hop aroma with pine, apricot and mango. Pleasant tropical fruit hop flavor with some grassiness detracting. A little thin in body. Also, there is a distinct metallic note in the finish. Not a bas IPA but not one I would seek out.

Pours  honey color with small off white head. Very sweet aroma of citrus and malt.
Moderate hop bitterness throughout with a long finish. Other flavors of strong maltyness and fruit. Light to moderate body with a dry finish. Descent IPA.

Pours a very lightly hazy orange-gold color.  A frothy, off-white head leaves behind thick, sticky cobwebs of lacing.  Aromas are very malty, with buttery toffee laying the sweet groundwork for orange citrus hops.  There’s a touch of creaminess and a fresh floral element to the nose as well.  Flavors are again malt dominant, yet sufficiently bitter from the citrus hops.  Toffee and butter really shine here, right up until the sharp bitter finish kicks in.  Medium bodied and slightly syrupy, though not cloying.  This is a pretty nice brew, but nothing to get too excited about.
nice golden color with a nice head that slowly dissipates.  extreme hop on the nose along with fresh cut grass.  hops are all over the flavor.  love it, but don’t  try if you don’t  like bitter hops.
Pours a light golden color with a frothy creamy head that stays for a while.  Nice hoppy taste with a little bit of a sour hoppy after taste.  I will buy this beer again.

(bottle) Pours light copper with a white head.  Aroma of canned mandarin oranges and light pine.  Taste is decent, with a nice balance between the sweet caramel malts and the bitter hop finish.  Medium mouthfeel, not a bad IPA.
pours copper in color,nice white head,hoppy grassy aroma.Malt notes up front hoppy bitter finish.Nice Hoppybeer.

[Bottle] Pours amber with a decent off-white head. Aroma is decent. Hops really aren’t too overpowering with a good amount of caramel malt and a lot of grain in the finish. Medium mouthfeel. A decent IPA, but didn’t overly impress.

Pours a slightly clouded amber with a creme head that doesn’t really stick around but leaves lots of evidence (that means lace) on the way down. Nose is very piney and sticky hops. Seems a bit salty as well. Flavor is hoppy of course. Tangy tones rule on this one. Minor bitter hop edge is there as well. Feel is nice. This is a smooth and well balanced IPA. I’d love to see a cask offering.
12oz bottle. Orange with white head, Aroma is  hops and pine. Taste is the same. Bitter finish. Nice IPA.

Even though I live in Chicago, I haven’t had a Goose IPA in a while.  The beer pours gold and has a very thin head that quickly disappears.  The aroma is of strong pine hops.  The flavor tastes the same and has a strong lingering bitterness to it, more bitter than most IPAs.  Not that well balanced, but still a decent beer.

Bottle.  Pours clear golden, lighter than normal IPAs, which hints at the flavor profile.  Flavor is much spicier and sharper than I like in an IPA.  Needs more depth, the malt is almost non-existent.  Seems a little harsh.  I’m a big fan of goose island, but this is one of my favorite styles and i must say I was disappointed.  Finish, however, is very clean.

Beautiful hazy golden colour, full floral hop aroma. The flavour matches the aroma with lots of floral sweetness and a lingering hop bitterness. Beautiful stuff. I order it by the case but wish it were more easily available here in Nottingham.

Pours a  light amber, a bit lighter than the average IPA I would say, with a thin, quickly dissipating white head. The aroma is nice piny hops and a bit of sweet malt. The flavor is mostly bold, bitter piny hops with a sturdy backbone bone of syrupy malt. This beer isn’t quite as well balanced as the top of the line IPAs but all the right flavors are there, even if they are are blended perfectly. The mouthfeel is pretty good for the style. Overall solid, inexpensive and very sessionable.

Pours medium amber with a full off-white head.  Nice lacing is left on the glass as it is drank.  Floral hops and spice dominate the aroma.  Nice, full, creamy mouthfeel leads to a perfect example of how an IPA should taste.  Hops, caramel, pine, and more hops.  Finishes slightly bitter, which is no surprise.  A great beer at a great price.
This was a very hoppy beer like it should be, both in the aroma and in flavor.  I really liked this beer.

out of a bottle this smells like lightly fruity hops and some spicenes .tastes like it too.verry good finish of hops.for 5.99 a six pack with a rateing of 90 this is to good to be true.drink this beer.

Decent over-all IPA.  Aroma of strong hops and taste of strong hops and aroma of pine, strong hop, and very light fruit, perhaps peach.  A good beer overall and a very decent IPA.  Would buy again in a variety pack and maybe even on its own.

Bottle. Nice copper color with a fluffy white head that lasted and left a nice lacing. Wonderful hoppy aroma. Superb flavor of malt, with a touch of sweetness, dominated but, not overly so, by the floral hop flavor. Excellent mouthfeel makes this beer a keeper

Bottled. Poured clear and golden with a fine, off-white head. Citrus, floral aroma. Flavor is citrus (grapefruit), pine, caramel, and floral. Finish is nicely hoppy. Medium mouthfeel with low carbonation.

Shared with toddbates: aroma was floral and slightly grassy.  the beer poured a darker shade of gold than a pils, with a big head that left a lot of lacing.  flavor was grass on the front of the tongue, with floral and citrus qualities more on the back of the tongue.  mouthfeel was medium bodied.  An alright beer, but once again nothing really stands out about it.
I was looking for something to really stand out with this beer but nothing really did. It was hoppy but not nearly as hoppy as it would lead you to believe

Poured a nice attractive orange/amber color with decent white head that stayed for a while.  The aroma was was of citrus fruit.  The taste was hoppy but well-balanced by the maltiness.  The mouthfeel was good and the drinkability of this IPA was way up there.  I liked.

Bottled 355ml, from Sainsburys, Banbury. Dark amber with white head. I was prepared to be blown away, but wasn’t, sure there are hops in there, but they lacked some character and the malty sweetness is a bit odd for a true IPA, it masked much of the hop. There is bitterness in the finish with a fruity note, quite like Chinese gooseberries. A reasonable beer without being exceptional.

Pretty good size creamy head; fairly pale in color. Aroma: was expecting some American intense bitterness, but the nose on this is soft and floral with a tinge of grapefruit. I want to say roses are in there, but I could be pulling that out of my ***. The body is again, thinner than I expected and typically like, but actually was quite refreshing and enjoyable. Enough hops to keep me satisfied for an IPA, but also incredibly drinkable.
tap.  Copper with a thin head.  Nice piney hop nose.  Flavor of resins piny hops,  citrus,  and caramel malts.  Nice and bitter,  light carbonation.  Very nice!

Bottle at home ... light copper ... that oh so typical american hop nose ... lots and lots of hop character ... too bitter ... some sweetness ... some citricness ... some pine ... some hop resins ...3.4



Bottle at home crisp golden amber ... bubbly white head ... that soft creamy malt nose ... juicy orange fruits ... light pine hop .... sweet fruits ... juicy malts ... big citrus and pine .. theres a little of teh creamy malt. but no t as much as in the aroma. Stick on 3.3

Sampled via 12-oz bottle at 10th Annual Ice Cold Beer Festival in Minocqua, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-hazy caramel amber brew with a thick and creamy off-white head that has some good retention an lacing. Aroma of strong grapefruit zest that over-powers any caramel malt aromas or any other scents. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation with a less than intense grapefruit flavor than its aroma. Still, the malt flavor seems to be absent. Finish is quite bitter, citrusy/pine aftertaste that lingers around. Definitely a west coast caliper IPA.

Murky orange pour...medium head. Aroma is intense, and I mean intense.  I poured this puppy and was overwhelmed...so much that I took it across the room and could still smell it from 20 feet away!  Grapefruit and other citrus hops are the dominant aroma. Flavor seems weak compared to the aroma, but still pretty damn good.  This is one of the more drinkable IPAs I’ve had in a while!  The hops aren’t over-the-top for a non-hophead and there is some malt flavors waiting in the wings to keep this from being one-dimensional.  Flavor is citrusy hops up front, then some malt sweetness, followed by a bitter aftertaste.  Super easy to drink with a very good mouthfeel for a beer of this ’intensity’ (e.g., not comparing to an Impy Stout).  Great ’regular’ offering by the folks at GI

bottle phams- pours hazy copper with large foamy head. smells citrus, grass, bready yeasty, tastes gorgeous very well balanced sweetness with a clean hoppy finish that lasts ages. flowery citrusy, and it has a nice syrupy mouthfeel. great ipa. one of my favourites.
Bottle: Very drinkable IPA.  Pours yellow with a thick head.  Aroma of hops, but not too strong.  Could be a little more hoppy, but not bad.
Bottle.  Light orange with tight white head.  Mellow hop citrus aroma.  Soft on the palate,   with a hop and toasted malt finish.  Good balance.  Kind of reminds me a smaller Great Divide Titan.

12 oz. Bottle - Pours a golden yellowish with tons of fluffy off-white head.  Smell is strong of hops, citrus, more fruit.  Taste is similar starting citrusy sweet hoppy and quickly moves to the bittering aftertaste.  Not the best IPA I’ve ever had - but one of the best easily attainable for cheap.

[Had at brewpub, will rerate from home]  
Nice hazy dark orange pour.  Fruity aroma.  Hops jump out right away, little bit of pinetree, little bit salty.   Crisp palate that suits the big hop taste well.

(Bottle, White Horse, Parson’s Green, London, 1 Dec 2007) Pale amber colour with frothy, beige head. Fruity nose with orange peel and apricots resting on a fairly sweet malt foundation with hints of toffee. Fruity taste with notes of citrus (orange, grapefruit), some underlying malt sweetness and hints of toffee, leaving with a whiff of floral hops in the finish. Nice balance, good beer.

Pours a slightly hazed light honey gold with 3 finger eggshell head fading quickly and leaving a thin layer for the remainder as well as decent lacing. Aroma is citrus hops, pine, some planty floral notes, hints of grain, straw, salt water taffey and caramel. Flavor is nice sweet orange blossom up front, sweet grain, dry straw, sweet grasses, caramel, berry blossoms, some melon and grapefruit. Finish is mild grapefruit, sweet grass, light caramel, white bread and a sweet floral fade. Palate is body, dry feel and sharp carbonation. I bought this to re-rate, expecting myself to knock it down from it’s original rating, it was one of my first ratings. I was kind of gushing about how great it was because it was my standby beer for quite a while and I really liked it. I still love this beer though, it has been probably 10-12 months since I have had it and I have to say I missed it a little. I am knocking the score down a little (4.2 to 4.0) but this is still a great IPA and a great value.

12 oz. bottle from Quinton’s (Iowa City, IA). Poured a light orange gold that was hazy. Smelled of fruits, namely ctirus. Taste is sharp, of hops and dry malts. I almost detect some piney notes but the beer mainly holds a dry citrus hoppiness that dominates. Not the best IPA out there, but certainly a formidable beer. A very inviting brew that I will drink again.

Bottle.  Poured a cloudy gold, bordering on amber with a small head.  Aroma was hoppy and grassy.  The taste had a nice bitterness with a good malt balance.  Ranked it third against 60 Minute (1st), Harpoon (2nd), and Avery (4th).

I have always really liked this beer.  Locally grown and available year round, it doesnt get any better than this as a fallback.  Wish I could find it on tap more often.  It may be a little thinner, but it has no trace of that medicine flavor that dogs down the style.  Crisp and very refreshing, even more so since lately I am on a winter beer kick.

Bottle.  Poured a cloudy sunset brown with a small off-white head.  Sweet malty aroma with lots of spice notes to it.  Strong sweet malt flavor with slight roasted notes.  Finish is smooth and malty.  Richly spiced.  Plenty of bitter hops in the finish.  This is an excellent IPA.

Bottle, november 07. Great, striking, citric grapefruit aroma with some piney touches. Interesting bittersweet flavor, balanced with an evident hoppy note and some spicyness. Medium mouthfeel, tasty and refreshing. Clear golden color with a nice, bubbly white head. Nice, hoppy, spicy and balanced IPA.
Amber colored, pours with a white head... aroma is very fruity, tastes slightly bitter with plenty of hops... some notes of citrus towards the end...

Orange with good, foamy white head / Pine and pineapple nose / Light body, some malts and modest hops, with good finish / Simple, cooked flavor of pineapple with pine and caramel on the finish / A fine but not stellar effort.

Coutesy of Gillard. Pours a clear deep copper with white head. The aroma is grapefruit hops and a stream of sweet malts. Nice hop representation in the nose. Smooth flavor of grapefruit hop mild bitterness and sweeter hop flavor. The malts contribute nicely with sweet malts and mild caramelization. This is a nicely balanced IPA. Into the finish is even grapefruit hop bitterness.

10-27-07 bottle.  Hoppy aroma - but want more of it - a bit lacking.  Only slightly soapy up front - finishes clean (no soap).  Nice flavor and great balance.  Almost creamy as it finishes.  Nice - would love to have again.

Nice brilliant golden color. Dense white head with minimal lacing. Nice aromatics with notes of citrus, pine and some maltiness. Crisp finish that makes this IPA incredibly drinkable due to it’s balance.

Mild,but still fragrant hop aroma still has the traditional English style caramel malt backing,same goes for the taste,not hoppy enough to be a Hop lovers dream as mentioned in description,but hoppier then it used to be. For those who like a slightly more balanced IPA,this is nearly perfect

Mostly transluscent honey colored pour with a nice whitish head.  Smell is mildly hopped with some sweetness showing in the nose as well.  Taste is somewhat mild hop bitterness and flavor, with a smooth, creamy tart sweetness following.  Almost more American Pale like to me, but it makes for a very nice drinkable IPA.  A bit unique, and friendly at the same time.
This by far is my favorite from Goose Island.  A very smooth IPA.  A huge head which lasted throughout most of my glass.  A fantastic IPA

Pours a cloudy orange with a stark white head. Smells fruity and hoppy. Initial flavor is hops and carbonation, but has a bit of spice to it. Finishes nice with a nice mouthfeel. This is a good summertime beer, maybe the best IPA I’ve had.

Pours a mid gold with a billowing thick white head. Aroma features big bold raw hop aroma, slightly dusty earthy hopsack note. On the palate there is biscuity sweet malt, tangy grapfruit and a smooth ballanced finish. Im sure I remeber this as being more bitter in the past.

12oz Pour
$5.00
Goose Island Clybourn

Goose’s IPA was served in a straight tulip style glass. Poured a dark golden hinting at copper with a bright white one finger head. As the head fell to a thick cap it left sheet lacing down the glass. After every sip more sheet lacing was left leaving the whole glass opaque as the beer was put to bed.

Goose Islands IPA had more of hop presence than expected. There is a solid biscuity malt with a touch or two of caramel showing through but the hops do manage to ease them from the picture. The hops come throgh very fragrant with floral overtones and citric undertones. Very nice aroma.

Flavor runs right along the lines of the aroma. A semi-sweet pale and caramel maltiness start things off and just barely manage to keep some balance in the flavor. The hops aain are the showcase. Vibrant floral and citric hops with a touch of the resinous-ness (Ha-Ha) take over and create a very welcomed hop profile.

Medium bodied with a carbonation on the sluggish side of moderate. This beer works through on it’s own to let the vibrant hoppiness show through.

I honestly could session this beer with no problem at all. If I didn’t have other things to do today I would probably still be sitting there drinking IPAs.

A great IPA from Goose Island that, to me, seems very underrated. I have sampled bottles in the past and they weren’t quite as vibrant as the fresh tapped version.

10/20/07

Orange with a small, persistent white head. Grapefruit and passionfruit aroma. Very thick textured, there is a little bit of grapefruit in the flavour, but the taste is mostly a hop hit. Curiously I also detect a small amount of honey sweetness. However that is probably just a psychological association with the colour and viscosity.
delicious.  one of the few brews produced on such a large scale that does not advertise hop aroma but still has a lot of it.  smooth, great finish.  well balanced.

Bottle... Clear golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. Excellent retention. The nose is very much like that of instant Lipton® iced tea with lemon. Medium toffee sweetness followed by moderate citrus peel bitterness. Medium-bodied with a 2%-milk mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Bitter-sweet and then astringent, drying finish. Kudos to Gillard for sharing the bottle!

Pours a clear orange, with a small white head.  Smells of citric hops, some grapefruit, and some musty malts are there too.  The flavor was a mix of hops and citrus fruits.  Grapefruit was the most prominent fruity character noticeable. Pretty nice little session IPA.  Easy drinking and enjoyable.  Mot surprising with this brewery.

Tampa RB Gathering Beer #12....dark amber body with a small, diminishing white head....nose of pine cones, floral hops, grapefruits, tangerines and lemons....flavor is big on the hops, but well balanced by a caramel sweet malt backbone....medium bodied, oily resinous palate....medium length, bitter, piney finish....good IPA

Very interesting aroma of floral, fruity and herbal hops. Pours a dark golden color with a medium white head. Robust flavor of fruity, herbal hops with malt with a dry, bitter finish. The body is medium with a creamy texture and soft carbonation.

A very good hops aroma from the start. A slightly orange pour with a light white lacing. A beginning flavor of decent malt not much on the finishing bitter until you rub your tongue around in your mouth to wake it up. A bit of a hay flavor on the finish. Palate is thin but carbonation is good. A very odd beer in that it didn’t have any bad flavors but it was odd. I didin’t score it low because the flavors were not really bad just odd to me..
Fruity and grassy hops in the nose.  Nice malty taste quickly followed by the dry bitterness.

After finishing off this beer, I was intrigued with the idea of being able to buy a great amount for an every day beer because this really did fit that bill. Easily sessionable, hoppy enough to keep the juices flowing with a sweetness well balanced by the hops. The beer pours out a cloudy, dark orangish/yellow hue with a very thin head. I couldn’t even get a head to form. Aroma is nicely hopped with a dose of grapefruit, some bitter orange peel, and some apple juice (must have been the malts). Flavor was equal parts easy bittering (citrus with a touch of floralness) and sweet malts. No overpowering carbonation, nothing to make you grimace while drinking. Clean, crisp finish, smooth from start to end. A nice IPA.

I found this IPA to be very....average.  It smelled a bit hoppy, but the taste was a not very exciting balance of hops and more maltiness than I expected.  Still, this isn’t really a flavor-packed IPA, and maybe more extreme IPAs, APAs, and DIPAs have made too cynical for this beer.  Yet, it also didn’t seem to be an "English-style" IPA/bitter. I also found it to be a bit watery in mouthfeel.  Not quite sure what drawer to put this beer in in my mind, which combined with uninspiring messages from my taste buds left me feeling a bit unsatisfied.

Bottle courtesy of Piscator34: Poured a deep hazy beige color ale with a nice foamy head and good retention. Aroma of bitter and floral hops is dominating and quite enjoyable. Taste is a nice mix between some caramel malt with some floral hops and a medium bitter finish. Good carbonation with full body and well balance for the style.
Pours a golden yellow color with a small white head. Nice caramel malt and citrus hop aromas. Nice bitter grapefruit/citrus hop bite and nice bitter finish. Nicely balanced.

Slight hazy iced tea color. Had a creamy almost yellow head initially but it fades rapidly. Barely any aroma, quite surprising for an IPA. Usually they let you know they are IPA with their pine or floral hop smell. If I smell hard enough there is a some clean orange hoppiness about it. Initial taste is strongish APA or mild IPA. Some odd fruitiness with each taste. What can I say about a style that has become so numerous?  Bitter medicinal finish. As expected for this harsh ill mannered style. I’m the wrong guy to look to if you want to build IPA ratings. Let me tell you, I wasn’t excited about this when I was given a bottle. Will not acquire again.

On tap at Goose Island Clybourne. This blonde ale poured with a modest off-white head, eliciting a flowery hop aroma. It is nicely hopped with a slightly sweet body and a slightly bitter finish. This is a very tasty IPA.

[bottle]
Massive US hops aroma--bitter grapefruit--, which eventually gives way to some spicy, toffee-ish malt.  Hazy coppyer with a white cover that quckly drops to almost nothing.  The flavour is spicy melanoidins and toffee malt buffeted by big hops that sort of disappears into an empty void.  A little sweetness peeks its head out just before the anticipated body and bitterness never arrive.  Too thin a body, moderate carbonation, dry-ish finish that makes this beer out of balance.
Pours very nicely with a golden finish. The aroma is great with a hoppy taste which makes this IPA a must have

Pours a golden color.  Aroma is very piney with a hint of citus.  Very bitter up front, carbonated, and hoppy.  The palate is slightly malty and nutty.  A bit too bitter for my tastes but still done well.

Brewery: Goose Island Brewing Co

Date: November 09, 1997

Mode: Draft, Nitro

Source: Brewpub

Appearance: dark yellow, thick creamy head leaving nice drippy lace

Aroma: sweet citrus hop aroma

Flavor: solid hop flavor from the beginning to the lingering bitter finish, lots of grapefruit essence

Overall: the flavor exactly matches the aroma



Brewery: Goose Island Brewing Co

Date: September 18, 2002

Mode: bottle

Appearance: light amber, big fine white head leaving lots of lace

Aroma: fresh hop aroma

Flavor: lots of hop flavor leading to a long bitter finish, just enough carmel malt backbone to stand up to the hops



Brewery: Goose Island Brewing Co

Date: December 12, 2012

Mode: bottle

Source: tmac kennesaw

Appearance: clear copper, frothy off white head, heavy icy lace

Aroma: lightly sweet malt aroma, floral hops

Flavor: rich malt flavor, bready, balancing hops, floral with a touch of citrus, crystal and caramel sweetness, light bitterness, lingering bitter finish



Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20

Rating: 3.2/5.0
Drinkability: 8/10

Score: **+ /4
The first thing that grabbed me was the aroma.  The heady, unmistakable IPA aroma just knocked me out.... in a good way.  Then I tasted it.  Wow.

[558-20070823] 12floz (c/o jerc). Light medicinal aroma with a bit of woody bandaid, light citrus hops and weird but good fruit. Hazy, orange brown body with a quick foamy off-white head. Dry grassy hops flavour has light bandaid, grapefruit and non-sweet pineapple notes. Dry medium-full body. Interesting hop aspect. (6/3/7/3/13) 3.2



[6099B-20131214] Bottle. Light peat poop and house yeast aroma. Clear, pale orange body with a quick foamy white head. Bitter and grainy flavour. Medium body. Average. (6/3/6/3/11) 2.9

(@ Abraxas, Miami, FL)

Copper body, off-white head, spicy and floral hop nose. Spicy body, slightly limp mouthfeel, nice dry finish, decent malts.
Would rather have a Pere Jaques, Matilda or even a 312.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a nice amber color with a thick foamy white head, very appetizing-looking.  Aroma is full of fresh hops, but not overly-hopped.  Balanced and very drinkable.  Especially great for the price... I think that this may be a regularly-stocked item for me. =)

12oz bottle.  Pours a golden/orange color with a relatively small but firm foamy white head.  Very good lacing.  Wonderful citrus hop aroma.  Peach, oranges, sweet tangerines .  A great smell.  Nice, bitter, balanced taste with a noticeable malt background.  Finish is pretty short and sweet. Creamy mouthfeel. Doesn’t taste quite as amazing as the aroma but it’s still good. This beer is not going to knock anyone’s socks off but it is an incredibly well-made, every day IPA.  I wouldn’t mind drinking this all the time.  And at 5.99 a six pack, well...

2013-12-14. Quick notes - Grainy, relatively bitter but not a ton of hop character. Bottle sample at Abraxas, Miami


2007-08-24. Orangey body with a moderate white head. Aroma is interesting with notes of spice and resin to the hops. Flavour is less hoppy than I was hoping for, light caramel malt, resin, some sweet orange citrus an incongruous sweet spice from the aroma. It is a bit odd really. Not unpleasant but am not loving it either. Either a wonky bottle, or a different take on an IPA than I am used to. 6/3/6/3/12 Bottle from Rozis, Cleveland.
Pours an orangey copper with a thin white head.  Smells of citrus, pepper, caramel, some dough.  Taste is initially bitter with peppery splashes, sweet malt and hints of citrus.  Decent.

On tap at Clybourn location.  Amber color. Small white head, excellent lacing.  Very hoppy yet extremely drinkable.  Not as woodsy as the Rye.    Overall excellent beer for drinking.  Highly recomended.
Copper body, off-white head, spicy and floral hop nose. Spicy body, slightly limp mouthfeel, nice dry finish, decent malts.

Bottle.

pours like a transapaerent gingery brown, relatively dark. nice little fluffy head.

Palate is more spicy than i expected and a spicey ginger taste runs through the beer. Really refreshing and nicely hopped.
One of the best amerocan ipas i have had.
Smooth body and nice bitterness that kicks in just when you wan it to!

recomended

Orange with an impressive rocky head. Big hoppy citrusy/spicey aroma. Quite light bodied. Big bitter flavour, a little sweet. The finish is long and, you guessed it.... bitter. A very good, no-nonsense IPA.

Bottle.  Big rush of grapefruity Cascade resting on a layer of caramel.  Citric and hoppy.  Clear orange body with a full, thick, rocky, lacing off-white head.  Taste is a strong medium bitterness, woody and dry with a big fat bready component, full body with a smooth feel.  Can feel it stripping grease and fat from my tongue.  Fruitiness (that beautiful hoppy grapefruit and lycheee with some pine) nice and complimentary but definitely second to the dry woodiness.  Alcohol is hidden to the point I’d consider this a session by taste, though somewhat of an obese session.  Usually, I’m pretty lukewarm on Goose Island’s stuff, but this is a really refreshing, non-resin-soaked IPA.  Superb summer sixpacker.

Pours a light burnished copper with a loose off-white head.  Light citrus spice and earth in the aroma with mild malt characteristics as well.  Very earthy hops flavors--loam, dry needles--with some crisp malt notes.  Light-bodied with good bitterness and  a clean finish.

Pours a dark golden colour with quite a large amount of white head. Citrus smell that quite powerful and definitely opens the nostrils. Very peppery-hop taste with notes of orange and cloves and a warming alcoholic kick (actually tastes slightly stronger than 5.9%). Nice warming bitter/sweet aftertaste. A really nice beer, I’d love to try more from Goose Island, unfortunately I think only this and Honkers are imported to the UK. I think most of the best IPAs are made in the States.
Taster at The Mondial de la Biere 07.Amber coloer with a beige head. It has a bitter dry hoppy taste, with flavors of citrus. Overall a good I.P.A.
Bottle. Golden with a moderate off-white head. Aroma of resiny pine hops. Flavour of citrus and elderflowers with a lengthy dry finish. Very pleasant.

Highly disappointing IPA, especially after its wonderfully classy citrus/pine aroma that does not overwhelm or lie resident in your nostrils for the better part of the week.  Flavor is confused, hopped yet chalked, and it sits on the tongue like you just licked a blackboard.  Too bad.

Nice IPA but alittle disappointing as it lacked the strong hoppy flavor I prefer.  It also lacked a dry hop aroma and a strong initial taste.  This beer did have a decent hoppy aftertaste but not as good as the better strong American IPAs (particularly from the west coast).

Bottle.  A good IPA, the bitterness was on the lighter end of what I feel a IPA should have, but the hops were all flavor and aroma.  The initial taste there is a slight hint of coffee.  I might have had a bad bottle but there was a slight taste of wet cardboard, like a oxidized beer.

Bottle courtesy of Piscator34- thanks Kris!
Pours out a nice light hazy orange. Slight white head and lacing. Nose is of spicy earthy hops.  Taste- hops at the front of the tongue- not a huge hop bite, slightly oily, heavier on the bitter side.  Bitterness slides into a solid malt backbone.  Good balance- finish is woody and dry. Nice mouthfeel and good carbonation.  Classice american IPA stylings. Nice combo of traditional british IPA and left coast American IPA.
Murky dark orange pour with a nice white head. Not a ton of hops in the aroma, as I was expecting.  Flavors were sweet with a nice hop base. Very nice dry end.
Commercial, but very pleasant IPA. Lots of hop, kind of short in taste, almost green in colour, easy drinkable for an IPA. Dies quite fast in the glass. Drink fast!

I don’t go for this style of beer. I like things a little on smoother side. While this is a well crafted beer I just don’t care for many Pale Ale’s
Grapefruit notes for sure.

35,5 cl bottle at Patricks in Kristiansand, Norway and at home the day after. Unclear golden color, nice off-white head (small head at Patricks). Fruity (tropical), hoppy, caramel malt. Good, but a bit watery compared with my favorite, Nøgne Ø.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden color. Pungent piney hop aroma. Extremely light taste. Bright hop flavor is fruity - passionfruit, citrus rinds. Solid malt backbone. Bitter finish. Excellent. Completely to style.

Yellow-amber colored with a thick off-white head.  Lots of citrus in the nose.  Grapefruit twinged bitterness is accompanied by a toasted malt and caramel.  A nicely balanced IPA, but it won’t be your cup of tea if you are looking for a West Coast hop-bomb.

On tap at Union Hall. Clear amber  in color with a nice white head. Citrusy floraly hoppy aroma. Malty and hoppy flavor. Grapefruit and grassy notes.Hoppy tasting.  Full bodied. Nice bitter finish.  Clean tasting. Crisp and refreshing. Nice. Very drinkable.

Pours a medium neutral, light amber.  Beautiful aroma’s of pine, floral and hops notes.  Little to no head foam.  Flavor is of full bodied malted hops and pines.  Has a grapefruit character as well.  Pretty good IPA.  A bit higher than middle of the road beer.  Good stuff!

Thanks to theisti for this great IPA. Deep copper color with thin white head. Good lacing. Nose is great hop resin with some pine, caramel and light grapefruit. Flavor is a bit more subdued, good malt vs. hop blend with tangerine and grapefruit finish. Less bitterness at the end than I would expect, although nice hop flavor....which makes it finish pretty clean. Good IPA example.

(12oz bottle): Pours a huge head, light tan, big bubbles, lasting, good lacing. Very clear, light amber body. Very bitter hoppy aroma., just lots of bitter acid. Surprisingly balanced taste. Malty with a little hops. Cleaner and sweeter on the end. Not very complex or overall flavorful. Okay but more a pale than an IPA.

Bottles.... hicup.   I brought some of these along with me to carboration day, friday before the Indy 500.  I met up with a group of guys that do this as an anual man day, including homemade ribs, wings, and crawfish.  This little IPA was the icing on the cake.  I brought along a six pack and it did me right.  This one is nice and hoppy, citrusy and a little dry in the finish.  I could even drink these warm.  Well balanced and you can get ’em anywhere.  Well not anywhere but....  Thanks to my buddy Doug Sneddon at Reno’s Music for recommending this one.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  This beer poured a hazy light amber color with a small beige head that fades slowly.  Some light lacing is left behind.  The aroma is fruity, citrus hops along with some light toffee notes.  The flavor consists of orange, grapefruit, and some lightly sweet malts.  Very nicely balanced for an IPA.  The mouthfeel is light and slightly watery.  Light to medium-bodied.  A solid IPA from Goose Island.

Bottle at Mondial 2007.


Clear, light amber gold ale with small creamy white top. Somewhat sad looking IPA.


Aroma got much more life and character. Strong green and citric hop accents . Bitter-sweet.


Stiff bitter front, grassy wet leaf with lime in it. Hop character seemed a bit rough on me. With its potency more malt would do well here. Soapy finish, overly rough.

Bottle. This is a very sessionable crisp, fantastically hopped beer.  Is bronzy orange in colour with a nice white had givig  good lacing. Aroma is of grapefruit, pine, grassy hops and slight orange/citrus peel. Reminds me a bit of of sweute in mincemeat with fern leaves.  Light with adeuqate grassy cirtusy hops and grainy malt.  Good medium body with refreshing carbonation. Very nice ipa

(Bottle) Pours hazy orange with a white head. Great mixture between the malt and the hops in the aroma with tones of pine, resin, syrup, caramel, light flower and light grapefruit. Also some other fruits like tangerine and apricot. Maybe some hints of boiled eggs. Malty, caramelly flavour with some nice hoppy tones of pine, light grapefruit and light orange peel. Also some flowers in the background. Light to medium, syrupy sweet and medium bitter. Medium mouthfeel and body. Nice.

Definitely a solid IPA.  Smells quite floral and citrussy, as expected.  Good hop aromas while pouring, with a nice sized head with good lacing.  Taste is pretty crisp and clean, not too complex, but just enough malt to balance the choice hops.  The spice is noticable, cant put my finger on it though.  Nice refreshing finish, not bitter enough though.  This beer needs a little more ABV, and a little more IBU’s and it would be superb

Clear golden body with a very smell off-white ring.  Typical citrusy aroma.  Slightly toasted caramelized malts.  Hops flavour are half-orangey half-pine-tree.  Caramel flavour dominates the bittering hops.  Oily body with a carbonation that is too soft.  Feels lifeless.  The mild bitterness that is about as assertive as a clumsy new-grad on his first day at work.  Considering the excellent brewery I consider this to be either a disappointment or a bad bottle.  At beast, an average IPA.  I’ll try it again, I’m sure it can be better.
in my opinion one of the best ipas for the price. pours dark amber with spicey, hoppy smell. thick mouthfeel. well balanced with abundant malt and strong but not overwhelming bitter finish.

12`oz.bottle from Tanaka.  Golden in color with very little head.  Very floral aroma, citrusy.  Nice malty flavor, with a good hoppy finish.  Bitter, but nothing over the top.  Crisp finish.  Good beer, but nothing special
Robe blonde très claire surmontée d’une mousse jaunâtre épaisse en dentelle. Arômes de houblon fruité. Saveurs de fruits et de houblon aromatique.
Bu au Mondial 07. Bonde peu foncée, petit collet. Arome d’houblon légé, peu fruité. Petit goût d’houblon, mais pas assé. peu amère.

I’ve never heard of this Yank brewery before, but supposedly it’s well acclaimed and I can understand why.  A very nice pale ale.  Tastes absolutely  nothing like an IPA (in the proper English non-bastardised sense), which it purports to be.  Light amber in colour and very bitter sweet.  Very spicy in taste - almost something of a Belgian there.  Very enjoyable!

Rated 3/23/06:  Wow! This is a well crafted IPA in all aspects. Pours a burnt orange color into my glass. There is a thick foamy head that immediately forms and eventually simmers down to a fine creamy film. Carbonation is slightly visible, and a thick lacing forms all the way down the glass. This beer is very aromatic, a bouquet of spices, malts, and bitter hops fill my senses. This is a very traditional aroma that is well balanced. The mouthfeel is thick and full with a very nice finish. The flavor is outstanding. Spicy and citrus flavors from the hops immediately hit followed by a smooth maltiness. At first the intensity from the hops overwhelm my palate but after a few tastes this beer comes together in wonderful fashion. Well rounded and outstanding in all categories, well done.
Bottle. Poured a golden yellowish color. Aroma of hops is nice. Taste is very balanced with hops all through your mouth.

A wonderful  citrus - hop aroma, really punchy, little head (had to use a red wine glass) an apple-hop-brandy-caramel flavour and a delightfully charming apple schnapps finish, lovely and I am so delighted I can get it in Ireland!

faun head that stood its ground, beautiful amber body, sweet! as advertised dry malt with a big hop finish. That said it, still had a nice balance with a little fruity flavor. I would have this one again.

A nice looking IPA with a big foamy head.  Plenty of retention here, too.  Aroma is full of pine.  Flavor is clearly tart, as expected, but is also surprisingly sweet as the malts show up.  Definitely the best American IPA I have tasted.
Quite unbalanced.  Good perhaps for hopheads but not for me.  Little if any backing malt noted.  Mostly resinous bitterness and extremely dry.
bottle.  clear copper with white frothy head.  moderate citrus hops, carmel malts, earth aroma. dry hop, mild malts, pine.  peppery bitter finish.  a bit watery.  I was disappointed.
Nicely hopped. Great citrus aftertaste.  Thanks to Pisctaor for the sample.  This would be my new favorite IPA (if we could get it here)

A wonderful  American IPA. Full of floral hops with distinctive lemon character. 
Full of flavour one of my favourite beers.

[b]12oz. bottle[/b] - pours lightly cloudy, pale gold with a bone white head. Aroma is typically citrusy for an American IPA, but with a dose of sweet malt as well. Smells balanced. Flavour...tastes balanced as well. Fresh orangey hops, caramel malt, some earthy notes, all leading towards a mildly bitter finish. Classic IPA, in the English character/tradition. Certainly not a US hop bomb. Finish is actually quite sweet, presumably coming from the malts. Nice stuff, very drinkable.

Bottle: poured a medium amber orange gold, some bubbles on top with some lacing, lot of pine citrus floral fragrance with pale malt and sweet aromas, faint caramel fragrance, hop bite with a malt sweet taste, citrus and pine needles taste, a citrus grapefruit juice lingers in the after taste, the mouth feel is a little thin, I thought it could be a little better, a good IPA.

Desent IPA. Strong hoppy aroma with some malty caramel notes. A bit cloudy, just coarse filtered? Small head. Finishes a bit too much on the sweet side, I would prefer a drier, more bitter finish for my IPAs.

HAD TO GIVE IT A GOOD SCORE SINCE I HAD IT FROM THE CASK AT STOUDT NYC. NICE IPA GOOD FLAVOR.FLORAL, PINE AND GRAPEFRUIT WITH NOT A VERY INTERESTING MALT BASE. 6$ FOR A HALF PINT ? COME ON NOW. THANX FOR THE FREEBIE VEGAS! OH! NICE GOLDEN BELGIAN TYPE LOOK TO IT. YOU OFFICIANADOS SHOULD REALLY LIKE THAT.
Pours a hazy light amber, with a head that fades to lacing quickly.  Nice hop flavor, not too much of a finish.  Decent IPA, but doesn’t compare to most of the others I’ve tried.

April 7, 2006; 12 oz. bottle.  Cloudy orange pour; what little head dissipates quickly. Sparse lacing. Citrus aroma with notes of malt. The long-lasting dry bitterness on this one garnered an extra "palate" point, although the finish is a tad thinner than my favorites of the style. Pretty decent IPA. 



Re-rate on July 3, 2007:  Exceedingly well-balanced, with a welcome malt bias.  A winner.

I have been drinking nothin but IPA’s for the past couple weeks, and they are all starting to blend together for me. This one was really good too, nice amount of hops for this hop fan. Not to fruity. To many ipas claim to be the "hop lovers dream" though.

A good example of a traditional American IPA.  Has a piney, citrus hop nose with a predominantly bitter pine finish.  The malt backbone is slightly sweet and the carbonation helps dry this sucker out.  A very quaffable lawnmower beer.
Pours a golden yellow straw color with a white head.  Aroma is malty with some bitter  citrus hops.  Flavor is malty with grassy citrus hops.

Pours with an orange body topped by a thin head with little lacing.  It bitter and hoppy with piney notes, a slight floral note and a little grapefruit with a touch of malt .  Medium bodied and a bit warming.
Amber pour with white head.  flavor is quite bitter with some fairly heavy malt and caramel flavors.  Some citrus and fruit.  A decent IPA.
bottle. London.  pours amber with a substantial white head that lingers.  nice hops flavor, but not over powering like some craft IPAs.

Pours a light copper color into pint glass. Decent head and decent lacing. Aroma is overwhelming hops. Very strong aroma. Taste starts bitter than envelops you with a sugary sweetness and then the hops come back in for a bitter bite as it goes down. Finish is a little cloying. Definitely gets better closer to room temperature than fridge temperature. Very drinkable IPA, up there with Bells Two Hearted for very sessionable IPAs.
nice ipa good strong hops and not much fruity sweetness good stuff here guys grab one today smooth and tasty
A very nice NW-style IPA with a nice hop-to-malt complexity.  I wish it was sill available in Oregon in bottles.  Great green labels and awesome grapefruity piquancy.  Try it if you can.
Draft.  Yeah, some guy had to leave cause his girlfriend was under 21, but he paid for his beer anyway.  So me and alexanderj reaped the benefits.  It was an average IPA, decent floral hops.

Got this for free after some patron bought his beer and left.  Split it with golubj.  Flavor and aroma were ok for an IPA, but generally it was a bit disappointing.  Aroma and flavor were dominated by a floral and some citrus hop presence.

Fluffy-headed golden tulip. I’ve only sniffed it and it’s already Beer Of The Evening. A seductive, encloaking fog of sweet floral hoppiness, pine and succulent mandarin. Silky lace clinging to the glass. Quinine bitter hop dryness in the finish. Hugely smooth, fruitily refreshing and absolutely drenched with perfumey tangerine and Turkish delight flavours. A lip-smacking bottle of hops more than worthy of the tulip treatment.
pours orangish yellow, thin head. floral and citrus aromas. pretty hoppy, with citrus and pine. Its okay but doesnt really stand out from alot of the IPAs Ive had lately.

good ipa
light aroma
good apperance
good flavor
low head
had it on tap in naperville

From a 12 oz bottle from a Goose Island sampler pack.  pours a small head; nice orange, slighty caramel color; nice flowery hop nose. Has a good bitter hop finish (not as strong as other IPA’s).  Not the best IPA, but a good standard IPA that is very consistant from Goose Island.
This beer pours a light hazy color with little head. I has a pleasent aroma good mix of hppy and citrus. Good IPA

12oz bottle (thanks to shigadeyo) poured a clear orange color with a small white head. The aroma was floral citrus with some pine and caramel malts. Taste was well balanced with a small push toward the hops. Good malt profile make this beer a nice treat. A big change from all the west coast IPA’s that are normally around.

An old fave: Creamy IPA with a head that lasts until the last drop. Cloudy golden pour that exudes aromas of stone fruit, honey, bready yeast and pine all intertwined in a balanced symphony of olfactory nuances. Following not too far behind is the flavor, contributing more of the same. There is a distinct British flavor, which must be the yeast. A very mellow IPA, in the sense that while it is plenty spicy and fruity, the distinction between hop and yeast flavor/aroma/bitterness are blurred. That’s what I like. Very well balanced. Nothing crazy, but just different enough to be considered excellent and a benchmark for the style. Again, the finish is slightly bitter, slightly fruity, subtly sweet and sensuously creamy; all in balance. Excellent.

I’m sorry. I don’t care about the history. I don’t care about the American tradtion of enjoying this bitter pine needle-tasting swill.  
This ale tastes like soap.

12 oz bottle, via KingpinIPA.   Nice golden amber color, very mild hop aroma.  The flavor is somewhat fruity and refreshing, but this is an IPA that’s definitely lighter on the hops than im used to.  Kind of reminds me of a nicely hopped Pale Ale.  Not bad, but not in the same class as other IPA’s.

Approximately 4 oz. sample from a 12 oz. bottle at an American IPA tasting hosted by tennisjoel. This was the second of ten beers that we tried. Light aroma, sweet and malty by the standards of the style, but still primarily hoppy. Pours a brass color with a small amount of beige head. Hazy with fine suspended particulate. A beer novice in the tasting group was complaining about the lack of clarity in the liquid, but I have no problem whatsoever with a little sedimentary opacity. Subtle flavors. Well balanced between the hops and malt, but is an IPA really the right style for balance? Light on hops by the IPA standard, but a floral hops flavor is evident nonetheless. Light bodied and drinkable. This is a subtle, easy drinking beer, suitable for sessioning (although, at 5.9% abv, it is too high in alcohol content to count as a true session brew). The sum is better than the parts. This beer shouldn’t blow anyone away, but it certainly is a welcome refresher. This ranked sixth on my list out of the ten IPAs in the tasting.
good beer. big foamy head and pours a caramel color. tastes very citrusy and has an extremly bitter aftertaste. Tons of malt but not enough hops. Just ok, use to like it but my tastes have evolved...

Yum YUM Pour a perfect light orange color with nice head and great lacing.  Aroma was of strong grapefruits and other citrus hops.  Flavor was much the same, very refreshing not overly bitter very very good ipa.

Pours a hazy light amber with a thin white head.  The aroma is hoppy and citrusy, with some malt coming through.  Taste is refreshing and grapefruit like without the sour, plus with a good malty profile around it.  I like this better than most pale ales, it is quite a good example of an IPA in my opinion.
Disappointing hop aroma and flavor. I expect more from an ipa. There is a good level of bitterness though that lasts nicely. Not bad.
33 cl bottle, Fargo. Hazy light amber colour, lots of nice hop aroma. Good level of carbonation, nice bitterness that lasts long into the finish.
Strong citrus overtones.  Strong hoppy finish: bitter, yet pleasing.  Not astringent Decent amount of malty body support this good IPA.

Very good brew. Pours amber color, only slightly cloudy. Nice foam head attatched.
Smell is good, nothing fancy, but solid. Taste is full of hops, and a slight pine taste. Very drinkable brew for it provides, thanks for the chance to try it kc.
bottle, gathering at highlandlad’s 06. golden with a modest head. grapefruit aroma with some doughiness. fresh and really drinkable, light toffee, pine, pretty bitter

12 oz bottle.  Pours a nice amber color with thin white head and light aroma.  Interesting hops taste, but not as enjoyable as others have rated.  I typically love the strong hop taste of an IPA, but somehting about this one puts me off.   Not bad, just not that good.

Solid IPA, at times i thought I lmight like this better than the xxx IIPA, but in the end it’s not as complete nor compex a beer as it’s older brother. It’s a beutiful standard IPA, if you like hops you’;ll like this. 

On Tap @ Goose Island pub lincoln park
Very impressive IPA, excellent malty flavor with hop ballence crisp, almost tastes like a bitter, very well done.

Re-rate, Jan ’07 on draft at Durty Nellie’s: Original experience stands, no wet dog aromas, though, just a really nice overall IPA, good earthy and resinous notes supporting the citrus. Original Rating: Poured an amber to pale color with a frothy nice white head, very nice lacing, looking pretty so far. The aroma was grapefruity, quite nice, other citrus notes, some citrus rinds. Slight wet dog aspect to the aroma, but it didn’t come out after the first few minutes or in the flavor. The flavor otherwise followed suit, light resinous notes also underneath it all but citrus/grapefruits definitely the highlight. Moderate mouthfeel, fairly clean finish, nice stuff. Not quite as outstanding and rich as my favorite Stone IPA, but pretty darned nice and drinkable.

pours slightly hazed golden with solid creamy white head. great head retention. nose earthy, juicy, citrusy, hop nose. flavor is more earthy than most ipa, big bitterness and citrusy, leathery, grapefruity hop flavor. brillantly balanced. totally sessionable. high underrated. really nice ipa when fresh.3.8. 



on tap at clybourn, wow this beer is briillant on tap quite a bit better. big piney and citrus hop character that tastes great. i could drink a lot of this. very under rated and much better on tap. 4.0.
pretty decent if uninspired IPA. straightforward typical american ipa. nothing wrong with it.

Years ago when this was a seasonal at the brewpub I loved this stuff.  As more and more flavorful hop beers have come along and my insatiable appetite for hops moderated to an almost reasonable level I have grown less fond of this beer.
