It is still one that I enjoy when I’m jonesin’ for hops.  You can smell it coming from across the bar.  It also has a nice IPA color and appropriate head.  Lovely on hand pump.  For the most part I find that it is way out of malt/hop balance.  Sometimes it’s just the perfect thing, lots of time it’s not.

12oz bottle,  Best when consumed by 050107.  Pours a slightly hazy honey orange with a one finger eggshell head.  Aroma of perfumey floral and grapefruity hops, some caramel and biscuity malts--leaning more towards biscuity.  Flavor comes across as perfumey hops, a bit of grass, and a nice biscuity backbone.  Bitterness never gets beyond moderate.  Semidry mildly bitter finish.  Moderate carbonation, light to medium bodied.  Was surprised I hadn’t rated this long ago.

clear golden with a nice lasting white head that leaves good lacing. woody funky hop aroma. bittersweet salted caramel flavor. bitter dry finish. light to medium bodied nice lively carbonation. decent but nothing to get excited about.
Bottle from Ross. Thanks brother! Pours golden orange with a minimal white head. Flavor is juicy and piney hops throughout. A great ipa that I would buy more of was it available to me.

Nice sweet hoppy aroma.  Pours golden yellow with a small white head that disappears quickly.  No noticeable carbonation.  Medium sweet hop induced frutyness.  Little froth, almost flat mouth feel.  Flavor stays with you all way to the bottom of the glass.  This is a full flavor beer that is not overpowering.  For my money, and I didn’t pay much, This is a decent ale.
Big jump to go from 4 straight traditional scottish ales, with no hops, to this. Got that great aroma, not too bitter with some nice hops throughout. Pretty good stuff.
Very much a mediocre IPA.  Some mild flavor of hops, grapefruit, malt, and yeast but neither well blended nor well balanced.  Finish tastes like cardboard.

Bottle.  Clear amber to light copper with a craggy white head.  Striped lacing. Grapefruit and some floral hop aromas.  Biscuity to light caramely malt body infused with grapefruit zest hoppiness.  Finishes very clean and dry for the style, with just the mildest hoppy/bitter aftertaste.  Subtle carbonation. Relatively modest ABV for the style and overall drinkability may alllow this to be considered a "session IPA."  I can imagine this being the ideal pizza beer.

A great IPA from Chicago. This is the first Goose Island brew I’ve had and if the rest are anything like this they will be on top of my list of brewers! The pour was a hazy orange with a thin white head. The taste was all malt offsetted by a great hoppy bitter aftertaste. Gooses honk and I would honk for another bottle of this! World class!

Bottle.  Dark yellow, with a medium off-white head.  From the aroma, this beer is pretty heavily hopped.  Mostly a pine smell.  Light and resinous, with a slight bit of malt.  Despite the light body, the finish is a bit sour.

12 oz bottle: a medium hopped citrus aroma with a small amount malts in the scent.  Appearance is an orange/amber color with a small white head.  Taste is more citrus than big over the top hops a light malt texture melds throughout.  Palate is kind of sweet with the bitterness lingering on after a half a minute or so.  Overall, as an IPA it’s a good drinking beer, but it does lack in the hop flavor.  It’s a nice medium bodied beer that can be enjoyed by all.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a slightly hazy gold with a thin head that was gone after a few sips. Pleasant citrus and pine aroma.  Citrus and pine are also present in the flavor along with a touch of malt. I’ve had a few IPA’s recently that all seemed to be heavily dominated by grapefruit flavors, which I do not care for. The citrus in this IPA leans more towards orange and does not give you that pucker-up bitterness.  Really good stuff and quite enjoyable.

bottle:  Attractive head with some lacing.  Light orange color with lots of carbonation.  Heavy pine & citrus in the aroma. with some pastry.  Muted spicy hop finish, but still strong and long.  Entry is bready and mildly sweet.  Good body.  Creamy/milky all the way through.
Poured from bottle...Nice golden color. Slightly cloudy. Small head, but very nice lace. Light, fruit taste, some hops, but not real bitter. This was a great beer.
(Tap) Pours a light brown with a medium-sized white head. Hoppy aroma and flavor, with fruity notes as well. Malty notes balance and smooth the beer. Nice finish, with a great hoppy aftertaste.
Bottle. Pours light amber with nice white head. My first IPA. Aroma of HOPS and fruit. Taste is a hoppy, fruity delight. Light with a slightly bitter finish. Good beer

pours cloudy orange with white head.  wonderful hop aroma, citrusy and spicy with a hint of pine.  Flavor starts with malt then leads to strong hop flavor, fruity and citrusy, sharp bitter bite in the finish.  A nice crisp IPA.

12oz bottle from the pub pack. My first IPA.  Hops and loads of them.  The smeel is definitely grapefuit as someone mentioned, I couldnt think of it until I saw that.  Grapefruit and hops.  Pours a golden oragne with a nice white head laces the glass well,  and it sticks around for a little bit.  The taste is wonderful,   first a citrusy malt, then a bitter kick and a nice medium finish on the palate.  Body is medium-light.  Great beer.

This offering from Goose Island pours a foggy dirty blonde that leaves a thick frothy tan head that leaves a sticky residue that stays with this head. The aroma is honey, hops citrus, earthy west coast feel to this IPA. The taste actually starts malty sweet, folllowed by healthy dose of bitterness as not to forget this is a IPA. This IPA continues to take your palate on a herbal, honey, tea, ride and the finish is very nice. This is a quality IPA if it were distributed around here I would have this in my fridge all year.

Light amber/orange color, with an impressive off-white head. Very nice lacing. Inviting pine/citrus aroma. Flavors are an extension of the aroma, but add to that some malt, and then round it all out with a pleasant bitterness. Very smooth, and extremely drinkable. My glass is already empty, so I think I’ll have another.

Bottle.   Pours a a hazy orange color witha fine looking off white head, decent lacing.   Aroma is all hops, floral, pine, sweet.   Taste is grapefruit, pine, a knock of malt.   Palate is very smooth, medium body, bitter finish that lingers!   Ver nice all the way round.   Why it has taken me sooo long to try this I’ll never know.   Solid everyday drinker.
12 oz bottle. Clear golden color with white head. Aroma and taste of hops with slight bitter after taste.
12 oz bottle at Kyle’s "This Is Not A Beer Tasting" beer tasting. Clear gold with a small white head. Grapefruit nose, some pine. Flavor is cirtus rind, nicely bitter. Good.

A slightly hazy orange-amber color with a nice white head.  Hoppy grapefruit aroma.  Nice flavor, obviously it’s hoppy, some nice malt flavors as well.  Nice bitter finish.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  I drank this A LOT in college.  Now that I’ve moved to Chicago, I find myself drinking a lot once again.  Overall very good, but not the best IPA.
Very good IPA, nice and hoppy, another good offering from Goose Island.  I wish it were more readily available as well.

Bottle. Slight hazy copper/orange body under a fingerthick off-white head. Beautiful flowery hop-aroma, also citrus and dry malts.  Taste is complex and mellow; citrus again, with a decent malt base and a delicate  hopbitterness. Everlasting bitter finish. A great beer.
Get a lot of hops in the aroma.Pours copper with a big off white head.Big hops in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a bitter hop finish.

On tap at the Clybourn brewpub. Pale golden colour with a mostly diminishing frothy white head. Grapefruit and pine aroma with light caramel notes. Light toasty and caramel malts with a lingering fresh pine and grapefruit bitter finish. Medium bodied, juicy. Good stuff.

12 oz. bottle via trade with 11026 - Pours a golden color with a good size off white head.  Decent lacing.  Has a nice citrus hop aroma.  Flavor has light esters, light toasted malt, and citrus hops.  Medium body.  No lingering aftertaste.  Very nice.  Thanks Steve.

Bottle picked up at Tuckers Maltings, Newton Abbot,, Devon 14-11-06 had the same evening. Poured a warm golden colour, this was a super crisp refreshing hoppy beer, with great citrusy flavours very impressive, I liked this a lot and have had this before but forgot how good it was.

pours a honey color with a one finger head light to medium body. nice smooth hop smell with some pine and malt with a little sweet grapefruit and orange. ok lacing, nice and smooth pine hop taste with malt and a little orange peel caramel, and has a small dry hop after taste. nice all around ipa a must try.

aroma of sweet pine; pours a dark cloudy gold; flavor is a bold bitter but works as a session beer also.  I love this beer, it has a great flavor and the hop resins linger on and on.  This and the New Glarus IPA make living in the midwest alot less depressing.

12 oz bottle via shigadeyo (thanks Craig!). Chilled 2 hours. This pours a clear copper with an average white head. Nose is mostly citrus, lemon, grapefuit and grass. Taste is mostly grapefruit and grassy hops. Very thin body, watery mouthfeel. A bit below average for an IPA...

A Mes rate: 35.5cl bottle from Wine of Course. Typically american IPA and therefore not something I particularly care for. Very aromatic and hoppy all round. Lots of citrus and... oh my god I am bored. Something tarty about it too. And tarty in an unpleasant way. Don’t see any reason to make a fuss over this. Well crafted but boring.

I’ve had this in bottle and on tap at the brewpub. Both were excellent.

Draught at the brew pub (Clybourn location). Clear orange color with bubbly white head that laced the glass. Attractive citrusy hop aroma with assertive grapefruity hop flavor supported by a malty caramel backbone. Dry on the tongue with lingering hop bitterness. Delicious.

Beautiful hasy medium amber body.  Average head with good lacing.  Aroma was very hoppy, herbs, grapefruit and some light pine.  Flavors of walnuts, caramel, toffee, and light grain.  Bittersweet up front, sweet finish.  Medium body, dry, and slightly metallic finish.  This was a very tasty IPA.  Flying Dog does it better, but this is one of my favorites.  I will be getting more of this.

12oz - Aroma is weird: soapy, grassy with some piney hops.  Pours transparent copper with a small head and decent lacing.  Flavor is not as soapy as aroma and has much more hop bitterness with a strong malt profile.  Palate is tart and creamy.  Not bad, but not great.
Bottle.  Orangish pour, hazier than I would have expected.  Smells the hops right away on the pour with oranges and lemons.  Good full body, slight bitter finish.  Very refreshing IPA.

Slightly hazy orange golden with white head. The aroma is a bit spicy, with citrus hops predominating.  The aroma suggests bitter spicyness, yet it’s somewhat sweet for an IPA. Honeyish malt backbone with a subtle orangey light hop finish. Nice IPA, yet the bitterness is very low and the sweetness may be almost too much considering it’s low dryness. But it’s still a nice IPA.
Dark yellow orange color. Short white head. Smells like hops and citrus. Great hoppy flavor somewhat dry very malty. Very smooth aftertaste somewhat on the light side. Very good overall
Deep golden color with a very short lived head.  Great pine/citrus/floral aroma.  Flavor starts with lots of citrus and pine notes.  Nice malt body comes through with a bitter finish.  Very nice.

Aroma:I can smell the hops. Smells nice... Appearance:Medium brown. Nice head somewhat bubbly. Head dissapates quickly... Flavor:Bitter and malty. Not very burnt. Hearty... I like it..... Palate:Thin. Not very carbonated. Not necessarily the best thing about this but it’s alright.
Overall: I love it. Very good not a horrible price (had worse beer much more expensive). It’s damn good and I wish the rating would come higher. The palate brings it down in and of itself but it fits well with the general feel of the drink.
brewtopia 10/21/06.  Citrus in the aroma with some caramel malt.  Taste is a piney bitterness,  caramel malt, and lots of citrus.  good IPA.
Bottle, pours slightly cloudy with a nice golden color.  Fruity aroma with hints of grapefruit, citrus and light floral.  Good hoppiness, great flavor and finish.  A high quality IPA.

This is better than GI’s Impy IPA that cost almost $5 a bottle.
This inexpensive brew is better than many higher priced IPA’s. Many faint notes come together nicely-- nothing is overplayed and I leaves you guessing and wanting more. Lime/orange tea. More herbs/spices than most. Maybe banana or pear.

First impressions are wonderful with this beer.  Aroma is all hops and citrus.  Very inviting.  It’s a light brown to dirty gold color and had a thick white head that never eniterly vanished.  Taste delivered what aroma promised.  Hops and citrus.  Although I could have gone for a little more in the flavor it is still a great beer.

A hop lovers dream, as soon as the cap comes off you can smell the hoppy fruity aroma. The beer is a pale brown and settles in the glass with a thin beady head. The taste is as the aroma prmoises..full of hop and citrus maybe too hoppy for some.... the finish is long lasting and satisfying.
Light copper color, Flowery, grapefruit hop aroma.  Taste is of grapes, grapefruit, with some caramely notes.  Finish was semi-dry.
Bottle.  Not a bad IPA, but not enough hops for me.  Pretty nice mouthfeel with a hint of caramel.  More noticable malt than most IPAs.  If they added more hops I think they’d have something here.
Gold, crisp-looking pour with a milkshake head.  Hop and spice aroma.  The flavor was similar with hops, fleshy fruit, faint anise at the end.

Older bottle.  Pours golden with a thin white head.    Decent hop aroma, floral, citrus and soapy with a good malt background.  Taste is more malty than I would’ve thought, decent floral/citrus hop taste, but not enough for my taste.  Some nice caramel notes in the finish.   Medium body, a little carbonation.

Bottle dated best by 1/14/07.  Amber pour w/ 1 finger white head.  Medium floral hop aroma w/ a hint of spice and a nice caramel malt background.  Flavor is pretty much the same as the aroma.  The hop flavor has a nice juicy quality to it.  Malts and hops are well balanced.  Medium body with a creamy mouthfeel.

Firm hops aroma.  Pretty light golden amber.  Smooth for an IPA.  Relies on the hops without a disctinct citrus flavor.  Thought that it might have a little more kick for an IPA.   But looking at it overall as a pale ale, it is very good.

Clear golden shade with a foamy white head.  Fairly usual piney, grassy aroma with sweet tea.  Heavy bitterness on the tongue chased by mandarin orange sweetness - good juicy hops.  Another well done example of IPA.

Bottle, Cellar Bar, St Andrews. Hazy caramel-amber colour, bubbly white head. Hoppy, slightly sweet bitter nose, strawberry tones. Taste is sweet hops, grassy and lemony. More like and English bitter than an IPA to me. Palate is grassy hoppy dryness, long bitter finish. Rather nice.
12 oz bottle. Great India pale ale. A pleasure to drink and to smell. Lots of hops for a very fresh taste. Very nice IPA.

Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a small long lasting off-white head. Hoppy fruity aroma with some floral citrus hints. Very hoppy bitter flavor with some malty hints and hints of caramel. Long hoppy finish.
Bottle.  Pineapple-orange hops aroma.  Bright orange-yellow with small head.  Initially a strong sweet orange juice flavor followed by moderate citrus hops.  An excellent IPA.
Golden color with a thin white head.  Nice hoppy aroma, with a hint of caramel and vanilla.  For the money ($5.99 in my neck of the woods) this is a very good IPA.
Golden honey color with a bit of a head that left some lacing on my Stella Artois tulip glass.  Citrusy aroma.  Nice balance of hops and malt.  nothing overpowering, just a solid IPA.

Orange and clear with a nice grapefruit-pine  aroma.  Sweet taste brought on by pleasant malts.  Piney hop taste is very nice and flavorful.  Light and crisp finish makes for an all-around, easy drinking session IPA.
poured a nice orange amber hue with a white fast fading head. sweet caramell aroma with notes of pine.  medium body hop profile with some sweet malt notes. a real crisp finish.

Pours a lighter orange color with a medium white head.  Aroma is of citrus and pine hops with caramel and a hint of sweet malts.  Flavor starts off with the citrus and pine that gives way to the sweet malts and caramel.  Finishes slightly bitter.  Better then I expected on this one, but not my favorite IPA.

It pours a carmel orange with a small white head, the hop aromas are cascade like piney bit of citrus and malty.  The flavor is carmel and malt with some hop bitterness that lingers.  Probably their best year round brew.
It pours hazy orange with a small frothy head.  Aroma is lightly malty and heavy perfume hopps.  Flavor is heavly bitter and the finish is the same, Light to medium bodied, a bit watery and lively .

Bottle. Nice hazy amber appearance with a thick ring of bubbles. Nose-sweet hops, PNW hops, and pine. Taste-medium bitter, Earl Grey tea, Fruit Loops, lime, citrus, grapefruit, low-medium sweetness. Very solid IPA. Probably one of the most well crafted understated IPA’s that I have had in quite some time. True to style and tame in all the right ways.

Bottled. Hazy golden in colour. Minor white head. It has a bitter aroma of malt and juniper berries. The flavour is sweetly bitter and there are hints of juniper berries. It has a pleasantly sweet aftertaste.

355ml bottle. Smells like sweet, Pine needles.  My first IPA. Full and rich flavor.  Soapy in the middle.  Tastes like someone swept up after one took out the Christmas tree and made it into a beer...Slight banana taste also.  Chill down a little and it is really quite nice.

Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a small longlasting off-white head. Hoppy fruity aroma with some floral citrus hints. Very hoppy bitter flavor with some malty hints and hints of caramel. Long hoppy finish.

after having a few bottles of this beer over the last few days I decided to rate this. ffrom the bottle, poured copper with a nice off white head with some lacin. aroma a nice sweet hoppness comes out first, than  caramel, orange, some floral. flavor a dry hop spicey, some malts sneak out, couldn’t get the sweetness or caramel I got in the aroma. This has got to be one of the better IPA’s I have had from a bottle no harshness just a nice smooth beer Glad I picked up a 6er bad thing is I am drinking my last bottle have to get more.
Bottled. Hazy orange colour, small white head. Not too sweet hoppy aroma with weak hints of caramel. Flavour is hayish hops with almost no sweetish notes around. Hoppy bitterish aftertaste.

Thanks to Dan at Gannon’s for this...
Appears a hazy orange toned amber with small amounts of CO2 slowly rising to the top. Fluffy white head slowly fades into a mild cap. Nice streaks of lacing.
Smell is of creamy vanilla, orange citrus, delicate spice...kinda like a spiced up orange cream sickle with a touch of earthiness.
Taste is of the above mentioned aromas with an herbal quality that seems to play well together.
Mouthfeel is hoppily spiced and sweet at the front of the tongue leading to a medium bodied balanced brew.

Bottled (BB 07/2006).
Golden color, small white head. Bready malty, hoppy nose. Fruity sweetish mildly hoppy - good balance with malts and hops. Good APA, not much IPA.

Bottle: Deep golden coloured, light hazy, firm lacing small foamy layer; deceptive rich hoppy aroma: aromatic, sweet, herbal, floral....; strong and dry bitter flavour, surprisingly light bodied, fizzy, but smooth mouthfeel, just a little sweetness in the background; very persistant floral hoppy finish, supported by a juicy maltiness. This is the real thing ! A superbly crafted Ale !

(bottle from kevin...thanks!)clear orange body with a small white head.aroma mixed parts of pine,citrus,some fresh green apples,and caramel malts.flavor mixed the same parts with a bit of ice tea thrown in as well.very nice indeed.
very bitter, orange, hazy, frothy, minimal head, this is one of my go to beers, it is no ruination IPA, but a very good IPA that is readily available in the midwest.
Not bad. Kind of reminds me of Bell’s Two Hearted Ale excepted maybe a little sweeter. Lots of cascade hops. Eggshell head and orange looking. Decent.

355 ml bottle. Golden orange with a glowing haze. Quite a bit of carbonation. Orangey, piney and honey aromas. Clearly huge amounts of hops being used. Citrusy, sweet and sour, and some bitter, flavours. Medium-bodied, but with a good malty sweet body and background. Main focus is hop aroma, with a healthy dose of bittering hops. Finishes slightly dry and not too bitter. Great IPA.
Everything that an IPA should be. Well hopped, but not as complex as Founders IPA or Bells Two Hearted Ale. $5/case less than other top IPAs.
Bottled. Good mild IPA from Goose. Decent gold/yellow color, light but fomay head. Hoppy aroma, but not over-powering. Same on taste. Good stuff.
Bottle: Hazy yellow colour, with a nice creamy white foam.Aroma of hops, amltynes, and a bit citric. Mouth feeling of hops and fruitynes, and a medium nice finish. Medium body.
Orange with  a rough big bubble head. Big fruity hop aroma, like a super charged ESB. I nice drinker. Plenty of hops and dusty malt. Flavour has strong fruit notes similar to the aroma. Intriguing.

Not a big fan of IPA’s but this was a fairly decent one.  Not too harsh and the taste wasn’t too rancid.  I wouldn’t go out of my way to buy this again but there are other brews I would run away from first.

Bottle from Hy-Vee Liquors poured into 16oz shaker - Pours dark golden brown  with a 1.5 finger beige head that goes away fairly fast; Lots of hops and a hint of caramel to the nose; A citrusy initial taste that has a BIG floral side to it; A piney backtaste that doesn’t overpower at all; No bitterness what so ever! I’m quite impressed!

12 oz. Bottle. Pours an almost clear light golden color a nice white head and lacing all the way down the glass. Pine and caramel in the nose. Pine, grapefruit, and toasty caramel flavors that balance with the hop bitterness at the end. Good IPA.

Pours a med. chill hazed amber with a white frothy head. Aroma is citrusy but mild with some caramel character. The body is med-light. The flavors are rather formulaic East Coast IPA with some citrus and pine, a touch of caramel, but nothing really impresses. Dry light bitterness in the finish. My wife says it’s a nice APA. I would not disagree.
pours golden amber with off-white head, spicy hops and citrus, dry finish. overall - nothing spectacular, but a decent IPA.
May 06. Dull looking golden body, cascade hops on the nose, spice, not much difference in this IPA than an APA, medium body.

Poured a clear yellow gold color with a small white head.  big and sweet aroma with candy, sugar and hops.  Hops were citrus and floral.  Fruity notes show as well.  Hoppy flavor and sweet caramel malt.  Moderate bitterness with a dry finish.  Medium bodied.
12 oz Bottle. Good pine and citrus hop aroma. Lighter shade of orange body with off white head. Citrus hop flavor of oranges. Refreshing brew with some dryness on the palate.

Bottle poured a clear golden amber with a lasting off white head. Aromas of grapefruit rind, pine, light carmel and a hint of orange. Palate was light bodied and dry. Flavors of grapefruit, light orange, a hint of pine and a hint of spice with a pleasently dry bitter finish.
Good stuff, had this a while a go, I would definately buy it again. standard goose island stuff.
tastes like most other pale ales, strong hint of hops along with some other flavors,nothing special, yet it is very stong with the hops
Pleasent, sunny aroma. Poured well with a nice, white head. Although a little to bitter for my palate. Also, the after taste lingered longer than I like. Would recoment if you enjoy an IPA.
Golden orange with a white head. Sweet floral aroma with some citrus. The taste had a little malt and then fruit, which lead to a sharp grapefruit hoppiness. Excellent.

From a 12 oz. twist cap long neck brown bottle with a best before date on the back label, 06/26/06.

Made a good appearance, poured a hazy reddish and orange hued golden with a foamy white that settled into a thin foamy lacing, small amount of sticking, moderate carbonation.

Had a spicy, grassy hop nose with a light floral and fruity aromas, also a touch of grain.

A crisp, mild dry hop texture and smooth light bodied mouth feel, good drinkability.

Good IPA taste, a dry spicy rind and grassy hop bitterness, mild and rolling on the tongue, toasted grainy malty with a very subtle fruitiness in the middle and a dry hoppy and grainy finish with a lemon rind lingering in the palate.

A nice and tasty AIPA from Goose Island, a good everyday IPA.
One of the better Indian Pale Ales I have had. Wish we could get this beer in Tennessee, but as with it seems most good beers, you can’t.

12 oz bottle - Pours golden with a white head.  Aroma has floral hops with a little malt backing it up - mainly hops here though.  Medium bodied bodied with sharp carbontion.  Taste is sharp with not much malt to speak of - very hoppy.  Floral spicy hops mainly.  With the lively carbonation mixing with the spicy hops this comes off even more spicy and biting - it this case that is a good thing.  While this isn’t the most complex IPA out there, everything that is here is good.  A nice enjoyable IPA.
Pours deep golden with a long lasting off=white head. Subdued pine scent, some metal as well. Good hop flavor with a touch of grapefruit. Decent bitterness. Another good IPA.

Clear golden brew with medium thick small bubbled head. Good sticky lacing.

Nice hoppy smell. A little milder smell than I expected. A slight metallic aroma.

Nice hoppy taste. A little too much malt for an IPA. For the most part well balanced but there could easily be more hoppy flavor in this one. Slightly grainy finish.

Smooth feel. Dry bitter finish. Enjoyable but missing a little something...

Pours a nice straw orange color with a creamy head that dissipated pretty quickly.  Aroma has a nice balance of malt and spicy hops.  That taste is surprisingly very smooth with a bitter fruity aftertaste that lingers.  I really enjoyed this IPA.

Bottle courtesy of ross. Pours a hazy orange with a large mostly lasting creamy off-white head. Nice aroma of citrus and pine hops along with some malt. Flavour’s also hoppy along with some sweetness to balance it out and a nice bitter finish. Medium bodied. This is a really good and refreshing IPA -- great stuff!

I was pleasently suprised by how good this was.  This IPA really is as good as any other American IPA I’ve had.  Huge hop aroma and huge citrusy grapefruit aroma.  Has all the best qualities that an IPA has that I enjoy.
Golden color. Thick white head. Flavor of hops and grapefruit. A great beer.
A lot of citris taste that hits you hard mid palette.  Very clean but hoppy finish, just too much citris for me, but a good beer.
Nice golden color.  Smell of wonderful hops.  Taste of rye, and sweet hops.  Nice dry bitterness at the end.

12 oz Bottle: Pours a mostly clear honey color with a medium size frothy off-white head that is mostly lasting. The hoppy spicy aroma is fruity with hints of citrus and pineapple. Flavor is sweet and fruity with pineapple and grapefruit finishing with a lime bitterness. This beer is very refreshing to drink since the hops do not overpower you in the finish. Delicious!

Imagine, if you will, a soldier coming home from war.  He arrives at his home, his mother waiting for him, he walks up and gives her a hug.

Thats the feeling drinking this beer gives me when I drink something else and then come back to it.
Grapefruit and spicy herb flavour, honey coloured with a fizzy head.  Odd bitterness for an IPA, aftertaste lingers a bit too long.

bottle 12 oz. Not quite clear golden with good carb & large OW head & fair lace. Aroma is semi sweet malt, grapefruit, & hops. Flavor is sweet malt, grapefruit, & hops followed by a rather bitter hop finish. It’s too sweet for me, with a pronounced hop burn & bite. Unbalanced. Too heavy on the bittering hops, which don’t seem to fit in right,  and not enough hop flavor. Reminds me of SNPA.
Pours orange amber with off-white head that fades.  Strong hoppy orange citrus aroma with a flavor to match.  Nice malt balance in the finish.

Tasted 08/04/2006. 330ml bottle from Rumble’s, Wellington.
Pale gold, with a brief pure-white head and soft carbonation.  Perfumey bouquet of sweet malts, stonefruit blossom, citrus and pine sap.  Chewy, somewhat sappy, malts up front, with dry orangey notes through the middle, and an intensely bitter, slightly metallic, finish. Lingers on and on and on.  Medium body, mild carbonation.  Simple and very well made.  Very much a hop lovers fantasy but with a good malt balance.  Retasted 01/10/2007.  Fantastic balance of intensity between malt and hops.  Gorgeous, and worth more than my original 3.9.
Honey colored with a think white head.  Highly carbonated.  Slight hops.  Smooth finish.  Hoppy aftertaste that burned my lips.
Bottle.Copper colour with a nice white head.Hoppy aroma. Taste of sweet malt and hops. Balanced beer with agreat finish.

bottle - Pours up copper colored with a thin,  head.  The pine hop aroma is very good.  The bitter and rather well balanced flavor is pretty typical for the style.  There are some mild citrus notes and the dry finish is okay.

First rating
Initial Rating Date: 4/9/2006
Bottle at Delirium Café in Gothenburg, Sweden. Courtesy of Rickgordon.
Honey color, white head. Very much citrus hops in the scent, classic Cascade perghaps? Hoppy taste, good bitterness.
8/3/8/4/14=3.7

Rerate
Bottle at CBC Denver, April 11 2014.
Clear, golden color, white head. Hoppy, citrus, bitter, grass taste. Bitter, lemon zest aftertaste. Fizzy mouthfeel, medium high bitterness. Green, hoppy, citrus scent.
8/3/7/2/14=3.4

Much creamy and supporter head, optimal resistance. Orange/amber color, limpid, light loads and with a good fizz. Complex and agreeable scent; notes of sweet malt, abundant hop, a lot sweet with rumors of withered grape and flowers. Medium pungent taste, lightly dry only on the end. Powerful bitter mixed with sweet notes of flowers. Harmonic and much persistent end.

Bottle from Kevin  Gracias!
Pours thick and gold, with a healthy head and an aroma of sweet, sugary pine and grapefruit.  Lively carbonation.  Flavor is sweet grapefruit with sugar on the edges, and just a hint of pine in the finish.  Palate is silky.  Oh man, this is goooooood stuff.  Goose Island rocks, and I will start the wheels turning to get their stuff in Texas.  This  is  goooood.
It had a cloudy yellow/orange color with a small head.  You can definitely taste the hops.  It had a nice finish.
I love IPA’s and this is definitly a good example of one. Poured fantastically with great lacing. Very full body with strong hop finish. Fantastic.

Bottled. Sampled at Delirium Café, Göteborg. 
It was about time Håkan at Delirium got hands on American quality beers. Light amber colour, good steady head. Big US hops in the aroma, with notes of citrus and rubber. Smooth mouthfeel, not super malty, with notes of mandarine, grape and citrus. The bitterness was much lower than expected. Maybe bottle was not all fresh? Loads of flavouring hops though.

Bottle from Utobeer.  Copper colour with thin white head.  Nicely aromatic US hop aroma, with a cross between grapefruit and tea.  Fine in mouth, bit lacking in structure and malt balance, but hey.  Finish is unsurprisingly zingy and hoppy with grapefruit and more tea.  I mean yeah, it’s nice.  Difficult to get a character in a beer so richly hopped 3.6/5

Re-rate 11/07/07 Bottle at Brew Wharf, Borough.  Lovely beer.  Lovely grapefruit hop aroma and excellent bitterness on finish.  Really impressed.

Bottle.  Pours a pale amber with a white foamy head that leaves little lacing.  The aroma is a sweet hops with citrus and pine accents.  The flavor lives up to the aroma with an evident sweetness and pine overtones.  The finish is mildly bitter, but it lingers well and combined with a crisp clean finish makes this very drinkable.

The aroma was fruitily hoppy with hints of citrus/apricot. The appearance was yellow-orange. The flavor was lightly sweet up front with a hoppy, pine cone-like finish with a lingering aftertaste - just the way I like it!!! The mouthfeel was pleasantly fizzy on the tip of my tongue and medium bodied. Overal a nice IPA.

Bottle. Pours hazy light orange/amber with a good white head.  Aroma is mildly floral and citrus.  Flavor is same with nice bitterness and a slightly sweet background.  Goes down extremely easy.  Finish is nice, crisp and bitter but not overpowering.  Very good.

wonderfull summer beer, but its freezing over here! still very refreshing, flowery, and just a tad bitter beer. apricot(cannabis) blossom comes to mind, how can hop be so nice!!! great balance.  there is something about it...

Hokey smokes; already on the ninth of the night.  Not feeling woozy yet but definitely more relaxed.  I’ve heard good things of this Goose Island.  I would like to confirm the word of those who speak of this fine brewery.  Well-balanced IPA with the malts playing along with the main attraction of the hops.
Draft Wrigleyville: Light golden color, some floral and citrus in it it. It’s a solid IPA.

Has a pleasant, mild hoppy aroma to it.  Decent golden amber color with a light head.  Wonderful hoppy flavor, I quite enjoyed it.  Has a good body, texture, and carbonation.  Overall, a pretty good IPA.

Clear golden orange with a creamy head. Lovely strong peach and grapefruit aroma thanks to the generous helping of hops. Translates to a nice strong bitterness that seems to balance well. Medium bodied with a good carbonation level and a fairly long finish. Quite refreshing, and amounting to a good regular drinking beer

Amber with a rich white head. Pungent citrus and floral aroma with some underlying malty sweetness. Sweet caramel flavour nicely balanced by grapefruit bitterness. Dry finish. Quite soft, medium body. A wonderful, and dangerously drinkable IPA.

I love beers like this. Aroma is grapefruit and gooseberry out its nut. Taste is similarly full of citrus flavours with sweetness coming off the malts, not a big bold chewy body, but a good sweetness, to make it one of the most drinkable beers iv had in a month or two. Get me a case of this so i can have a few days off.

Poured from the bottle, a clear amber with a good frothy head. A beautifully strong aroma very floral with sweet citrus fruit. Flavour is caramally malt with a hoppy bitterness all the way through the mouth, leaving a quite pleasant dryness. Delicious.

Amber body, nice white head, slightly hazy, low carbonation. Intense floral, herbal  and perfume notes in the aroma; traces of yeast in the background. Taste is mildly sweet (caramel, licorice) beautifully, balanced by a strong nutty, resiny and dry hops profile, and followed by a very long and pleasant finish, definitely bitter. Not an extreme IPA but a very well balanced and addictive brew.
Bottle of 355 ml from Vinmonopolet, Norway. Pale brown. Thin head. Dominated by hops all the way through. Hoppy aroma, hoppy flavour and hoppy aftertaste - and I like it.

12 oz Bottle: Pours a light golden-orange-yellow color.  An average off-white head.  Aroma is very floral, some hops, yeast, breads, etc.  The flavor is sweeter than most IPAs.  Rather cirtusy (lemons and oranges), hops,  maybe a little nutty, some definite caramel notes, and I feel like there is a balance of the "dry malt middle", a rather good taste.  Even though its a little thin and watery.  i disagree with the dry discription they give it themselves, and would say its a sweeter watered down version of a west coast IPA -which sounds bad, but its not too many West coast IPAs are over the top, and this is very good.

(02.11.06) On tap at Firkin’s, Libertyville, IL  Clear amber hued ale having a giant long-lasting white head with good lacing.  No discernable carbonation.  Hop/sweet malt aroma.  Medium-bodied ale that starts with light malt sweetness and citrusy (grapefruit) hop flavor.  Finishes with a light malt fade and some lingering hop bitterness.   A good drinkable IPA.

I’m no fan of IPA’s. They are too hoppy. There are only one or two I can think of that are appealing to me. This one is hoppy, although I won’t hold it against the brewer. I can recognize a better than average IPA when I taste one. This one pours a light brown from the bottle. Good head retention and lacing. There is that distinct hop aroma that dominates the flavor as well. The palate is quite characteristic, but that’s why I gave it an average rating. As far as drinkability goes, well I wouldn’t drink more than one or two at a time before I had to drink something else.

A tasty little IPA, very well balanced, lots of resiny hops oils in the nose, a ton of citrus, nice medium bodied mouthfeel with a great hop character and nice carbonation.  Very enjoyable, with a clean finish.

On tap at Goose Island Clybourn.  A very nice IPA.  Gold body with a good white head.  Aroma of hops and citrus, a bit of sweetness.  Flavor is hoppy and citrusy, very light and refreshing with just that touch of sweetness.

Light malt; moderate hops, average head (lasting, white, w/excellent lacing); sparkling clear; no particles; beautiful amber color; excellent flavor -- not over the top like Red Hook; light-to-medium body; soft carbonation; my personal favorite!
Average IPA, I’ve had this a bunch over the years and am reading it retrosprectively.  Good citrus/bitter balance.  Crisp and smooth to drink.
Golden with dissapearing white head. Aroma is flower and hops with some sweetness. Soft taste with notes of sweetness and a nice bitter aftertaste with hints of flowers
Bottle 0,355l. Golden colour. Lasting white head. Smell of perfume. Aroma of fruit - mainly citrus. A pleasant bitterness. A long aftertaste ending in a dry, fruity bitterness. Refreshing.

Clear amber body with a frothy head. Aroma is obviously hop dominated, mostly citrus and grapefruit, notes of caramel malt. Flavor is much the same, but as it warmed it completely fell apart. The last few sips were a mess. Before that it was a good IPA.

A cracking American IPA. Shining gold with a short head. Smelled great: very bright with luscious soft fruit and nose-tingling gooseberry tartness. Soft caramel and fresh hops. Medium bodied. Typical US PA flavour mix of caramel vs piney hops, but better balanced than most. Long satisfying bitter finish. Very good indeed. (Duff homecoming gathering)
Big hoppy aroma, grassy and hint of spice. big grassy hop flavour big bitter taste. dark amber in colour with huge white head. very pleasant beer.
Pours an orange golden color with a medium sized white head.  Aroma is of faint pine needles and hops.  Flavor is slightly hoppy and piney.  Better than average, but nothing spectacular here.

Heard a lot about this beer before I moved to Chicago.  Good, but not as good as I had hoped.  Little darker than I like.  Don’t care too much for the aroma but good hoppy flavor.  Tap much better than bottle.

12z bottle.  clear golden hue with little head.  Citrus and bread in the nose.  Fruity and lively.  Dry and piney.

Almost a year later, at the request of a buddy, her is my new rating.  Still a 12oz bottle.  Filtered and golden amber, spiral white head.  Grapefruity cirtus aromas with notes a bready cereal grains.  Medium bodied with a crisp hop note.  Slight malty sweetness but the hops dominate the palate.  Sticky hops.  Flavors of citrus and resinous pine.  It’s a good IPA, but still not one of my favorites by a long shot.

Pale and hazy. Spruce and hops in the aroma-very pronounced. The flavor is quite tasty orange, malt, and nuts nicely balanced. Has none of that soapy quality that IPAs usually have- a big plus for me. Bitter but just in the right amount so that it doesn’t overwhelm the overall effect. Beat me hurt me force me to write bad checks-I like this IPA.

Bottled. Pours a medium golden color with traces of orange. Somewhat sweet crisp hop aroma. Bitter right up front. Quite malty as well. Finish is slightly bitter. Reminds me of an extra hoppy English IPA.

Decent sized fluffy white head.  Light carbonation.  Lots of fluffy hops floaters in there.  Light carbonation.  Nice and hoppy aroma.  Light citrus with a nice balance of malts.  Hops araom fades pretty quickly.  Little vegetal now.  Color is a cloudy dark orange.  Flavor is sharp bitterness.  Very dry and puckering.  Not how I remember it.  Bitterness overpowers the malts.  Grapefruit rind, and spices.  Finish is dry and very bitter.  This could have been much better and I think that it is.  This bottle may just be off a little bit.

Bottle (12oz).  Thanks to my friend Dave B for this one.  Poured slightly hazy orange-amber with a decent creamy white head.  Aroma of solid pine/citrus hops, a bit floral, some malt.  Taste is tingly resiny grapefruit and lemon zest hops, enough malt to balance it, crisp bitter almost dry finish.  Average body, lively and astringent mouthfeel. Soild, if unspectacular, IPA.
Pours a nice deep amber color.  Aromas of hops/hops/citrus.  Strong hop flavors with malts and a nice dry finish.

Bottle. I did not get a very pronounced aroma. What I did pick up was some malt and toffee. No hops. Mellowed bottle maybe? Pours clear copper, with a diminishing white fizzy head. Flavor is not agressive. Taste has notes of nuts and citrusy hops, blalanced by some sweet toasted malt. Finish is dry, bitter, and grassy. Not much resin in the finish, and a little on the thin side. This got better as it got to room temp. A good middle of the road IPA. I have had this one several times at the brewpub, and it is much better on tap there. Same with all of the other bottted Goose beer, with the exception of the small batch beers.

pours a slightly hazy orangish gold.  aroma is of lemon, little hops as well.  taste starts sweet and has a decent bitter finish.  had with their honkers ale and thought it was very similar, slightly more bitter.

Draught at the brewpub, Wrigleyville location, 2007-09-29, 7-4-8-4-16=39
Light amber color. Hoppy aroma, fruity, very nice. Good malty flavor, with sticky sugars, good body, and a powerful hopping, aromatic and resiny, a bit fruity too. Very good, especially for being a low gravity one.

Bottle, 2005-11-05, 7-4-6-3-13=33
Golden to light amber color. Beautiful fruity hoppy aroma. Weaker body than expected, some sweetness, quite bitter and aromatic but not aggressive. Mild American IPA.

got the one by accident - i ordered some imp ipa from liquid solutions, and this was in its place.  matt worked it out though (thanks matt).  from the bottle - fruity and malty, with a decent hop kick.  a pretty good ipa if i must say so.  when i was drinking it i was picturing how good the iipa could be based off this one, and i must say those expectations are damn high.  now i just need to get the beer.

OK, time to rate this beer, as it has been appearing in my home with increasing regularity.  Finally, an IPA upon which me and my wife agree.  She finds it surprisingly drinkable for 58 IBU’s.  I’m impressed by how refreshing this ale is.  A most welcome houseguest, to keep company with alpha king and bitter woman.

On tap at Wrigleyville.  Pours translucent orange with a foamy white head.  Has all the standard IPA stuff going on...pine, citrus, etc.  Had a nice bite on the finish.  It’s not going to turn any heads but it is a fine example of a "normal" IPA.

Pours a copper, orange, thin head, some lacing.  Aroma is pleasant, floral hops and some citrus.  Flavor has some caramel and nuttiness.  Lots of hops, floral, citrusy, and a little piney,  but they are not overpowering.  This was good.

Happy Deli, NYC; 12 oz bottle. Solid Midwestern IPA accentuated with plenty of West Coast hoppiness. Light orange appearance, light white head, decent lacing. Fresh, floral aroma with some light citrus notes. Flavor has a strong ctirusy bent balanced with some malty,
nutty notes. Overall, a solid IPA.
Honey sweet aroma, golden blonde.  Has a honey flavor with great hopiness.  Well balanced.

Bottle; BBD 031906: Lively pour and abundant carbonation; large, firm, pillowy head; concentrated grapefruit and evergreen aroma with some grass and mild toasty malts; slightly hazy, deep amber body; musty malt front end, and flowery, very piney, citric hop finish that’s quite smooth; rounded, oily palate; not much malt charactor. I like this, but just can’t see myself drinking very many at a time.
This beer was very tasty. IPA are my favorite. This one was pretty good.  Had it at Brewtopia in NYC
Hoppy, floral essence, kind of a perfumy aftertaste in a good way.  Will look for more goose island products.

Visually stunning. Yellow/ orange sunburst appearence with lots of clarity.  Fluffy white head, large! Smells nicely of pine.  Tastes like pine and some citrus maybe lemon.  I could see myself having a couple of these.  Flavorful, yet still drinkable.  I have yet to have anything but exceptional from Goose Island.

This is a very solid IPA on the upper end of the hopping chart,  Nice tangy citrus twang going on that kind of keeps thing a bit more interesting than many IPA’s.  As I look at the other reviews I think it is also a light pine character that I couldn’t place that works very well.

Pour is nice warming amber with a thin soapy off white head...smell is some pine but grapefruit everywhere...taste is not overpoweringly bitter but a nice spicey fruity flavor is imparted...finish is quick with a nice sweet lemon note...this is one of the better IPAs I’ve had...abundant hop presence, but not all bittering....
Had it for the first time yesterday, on tap at dba in NYC. One of the better IPAs I’ve had...more hops, less malt than most IPAs...just the way I like it.

Excellent grassy aroma.  This IPA hits the tongue with a hoppy, pale-ale mouthfeel and leaves behind a malty, mildly roasted quality as the sharpness fades.  This is one of our favorite session beers.  Goes well with a campfire and your favorite  music du jour.  Bottle after bottle, we rely on the consistency of this truely delightful brew.

i’m having a good night for good looking brews. this is no exception. clear orange pour that shone with a wonderful thick white head. great orange pineapple and pine hop aroma. sweet delicious hop flavor with a great lemon zest quality to it. the sweetness is subdued and the hops are able to show their stuff. great grapefruit and pine flavors with lemon. a very nice IPA

12 oz bottle.  Hazy rich golden colour.  Thin white head.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, light sweet fruity hop nose.  Spicy and citrusy with a touch of pine as well.  Beautiful orange/grapefruit flavour mixed with some soft spiciness as well.  Well-balanced and very tasty IPA.
Standard IPA.  Amber color with a medium whtite head.  Smells hoppy and piney.  Taste is standard some hops with slight malt notes.  Short hoppy aftertaste.  Fine but nothing to write home about.

Tap at Holy Grail in Cincinnati.  This was just listed as Goose Island, with pale ale in parentheses.  But, since the rest of the selection there was mostly BMC, I’m guessing they meant it was this one.  (If anyone knows for sure, please correct me if I’m wrong)  Poured clear and golden with a short head.  Good aroma of grassy hops and citrus fruit.  Flavor and mouthfeel were pretty well balanced and complex.  Tons of dry-hopped goodness along with lemon and orange citrus, a tiny bit of malty sweetness and a little oakiness thrown in for good measure.  Goes down dry and crisp.  Overall, very good.

I forgot to inventory this so in turn I have forgotten who sent it to me.  Thank you, whoever you are.  Poured an effervescent golden with a fizzy white head that dissipated completely.  Aroma of clean hops and a touch of citrus.  Taste is light and hoppy with some lemon.  Not much of a malt backbone to this one, just refreshing hops.  Body is average and well-carbonated.  Although this felt a little watered down to me, it was tasty and clean.
Grapefruit on the nose, and very strong in the flavor.  Hints of sugar in the malt, nice balance.  Nice hop finish, yet crisp and clean.

Moderate to heavy aroma of Cascade hops — grapefruit and pine. Also notes of floral hops. Flavor of citrus, bitter grapefruit with a bit of sweet orange and toasted malts. Slight sour aftertaste to go along with the bitter bite. Crisp as an IPA should be. Nicely done.

BottleGolden copper color, thin sticky head and fairly retentive lacing. The nose is fairly hoppy with cascade type varieties. A bit floral and grassy but not too assertive. The malts gently come up to greet the nose as well. The flavor is heavily caramelized and toasty with a solid mouthfeel and rounded balance. The finish is smooth with a light lick of bitterness as it rounds the back 10 but is missing the usual ping of flavor. Like if you forgot to add salt to a dish, it’s all here, but just not. A good IPA; not focused on the the guns and with a level foundation.
Nice hop character, refreshingly dry. Amber colour, nice aftertaste. One of the best IPAs I’ve tasted.
GABF 2005. Full head, clear yellow body. Light sour hop aroma. Fizzy mouthfeel, with dominant hops that fade to a bitter and long finish.
im not much of an ipa fan but timmy brought me some of this from chicago and i thoughly enjoyed and i agree with him it might be apple or maybe....?

Nice copper color with thick creamy compact white head.  Aroma is decidely hoppy.  Nice citrus hop aroma and hop sweetness with a hint of malt.  Clean hop flavor.  Sweetness from a hop side, and malt also.  Lightness in presence, nice feel.  Strong hop finish.  Roasted malt warmth is also present.  Citrus sits on palate and doesn’t sour or get heavy.    Nice beer.

golden amber color nice hop aroma, fruity, apple maybe?? good hoppiness well balanced, delightful  (9-20-2005)

re-rate(1-17 2009)
pungent hoppy aroma comming from what i conjecture to be fuggle or willamette aroma/dry hops.  a little underlying grapefruit citrus, but mostly just nice english dirty spicy hop flavor and smell.  I should get this more often.  finish is dry, but not too dry.  the malt plays a supporting role, but is not forgotten.  there is just enough to give a little chew and contemplation before pounding the rest of this quenching elixir.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Cloudy light amber colour with a small, creamy head. Very lovely hoppy aroma. Distinct fruity notes, citrus - perhaps grapefruit? Malty with notes of caramel. Marked bitter finish. Very nice and typical American IPA. 160905

Bottled.
Clear amber coloured with a huge off white head.
The aroma is dominated by pine needles, hops and malts with some sweetness.
Hoppy flavour with notes of pine needles and fruits.

Bottle. Tested on Best before-date. A golden/copper beer with a nice white head. Gorgeous grapefruity aroma with hints of pine resin. The taste is balanced, but a little thin to my preference, with a long light bitter aftertaste. Nice mouthfeel. Rating: 8-4-7-3-15-3.7(050913)

Bottle. Since my first sample of this beer, September 2005, I’ve had it on several occasions, but as it seems it will disappear from the Norwegian market, I had to give it one more try. It’s a refreshing and fruity beer with a nice hop profile, and it’s far from extreme, making it rather drinkable. It pours a nice, orange-golden body with a rather small off-white head leaving some fine curtains of foam on the glass. It’s aroma is dominated by citrusy hops, with pine and resin as well. The maltyness is quite subdued, but sweetness and a bready note is detectable in the background. Flavorwise it’s much the same, the fruity hops with it’s pine and resin do most of the job, but the bready, sweet maltyness is doing its part as well. Quite full-bodied it is, and a bit sticky on the palate. In the finish, the malty flavors is even more subdued, leaving more room for bitterness, and of course there’s a lot of fruits, pine and resin too. It’s still a yummy beer, I sure hope it don’t disappear from the already starved Norwegian market. (080214)
Bottled. Pours a dark, clear golden, with a white head. Aroma is hoppy, and slightly sweet, notes of pine and grapefruit. Taste is sweet malts, and a hoppy bitterness. Medium bitter aftertaste
Bottle. Orange colour with a medium white head. Light sweet fruity hoppy aroma and taste. Medium body and a bitter dry finish.

Dominating hop aroma. Tea colored with a thumb thick white head. Ample hop presence, but flavor wise it is mostly just a bitter affair. Very resin tinged aftertatse. The kind of resin associated with hop’s cousin cannabis.

Sampled from bottle. Pours a slightly hazy copper-gold with a lasting, off-white head and remarkable lacing. Aroma is wonderfully hoppy: floral an grapefruit. Flavor is one-dimensionl as the hops (floral/pine resin) create such an astringency to obscure almost all of the malt profile. Medium-bodied and nicely carbonated. Wonderfully bitter IPA that would be much better if some of the flavor addition hops were removed (aroma and bittering addions are wonderfully done).
Had this a while ago.  From the bottle, so not the best case, but very nicely hopped.  Very enjoyable for a hophead.  Not much else going on here, but thats okay with me.

04-Jul-05 (12 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with bkelley68, thanks Brian!) Consumed 4 months before the "best by" date, I’m a bit disappointed in the nose.  Moderately hoppy and lightly malty, there’s also some spoiled vegetal aroma creeping in, and while it’s not nauseating or anything, it’s definitely a distraction.  The flavor is nicely balanced, lightly sweet and malty early, with a fairly mild and bitter hops balancing out the beer in the finish.  Medium bodied, lightly carbonated, smooth on the palate.  Clear, amber color.  Off-white head rises to nearly an inch in height after the pour, and as it slowly settles (and I continue to consume the beer), a fairly solid curtain of lace is left on the glass.  As the lace condenses, it’s very reminiscent of ice crystals that form on a window during a cold winter day.  This is certainly not what I’d consider a hoppy IPA, at least not by west coast standards, but the balance is excellent, and the flavor is pleasant.  A nice, easy drinking IPA is what we have here.15-Aug-05 (Draft: Horse Brass Pub in Portland, OR) Just a quick update about the nose.  Once again, that spoiled vegetal nose is present, so it wasn’t the bottle.  Whatever they do with the hops, it just has a weird aroma.  Otherwise, all other facets are pretty decent.  No changes necessary to the ratings.

Rerate:  I initially rated this when I was a beer novice.  At the time, the beer really was impressive.  I revisited this beer at a head to head IPA tasting and the beer was more malty than I expected.  The malt and hops work together well for a clean flavor.  Out of the 10 beers we sampled this one finished 6th.  Still a good drinking IPA, not top of the line when compared to its peers, however. 

Bottle:  Nice thick off white head.  Orange in color.  Very fruity aroma.  Citrus flavors come through.  Can taste some malt, follows with a nice hoppy aftertaste, not too bitter though.  This is one exceptional brew!   Original rating: 4.4
Very tasty, very hoppy. A nice suprise on a hot July day. What more to say................................................................................

From the bottle.

This one pours a surprisingly light golden with a moderate though short-lived head. The aroma is a picnic of marmalade on whole-grain toast in a pine woods. While the flavor is pleasant enough (if not particularly intense in either its hop or malt profiles), the palate is a bit disapppointing - watery, and overly carbonated. The finish is of dry, slightly metallic, cut-hay hops.

On tap.  Aroma of fresh hops.  A really hoppy, in the citrusy and grassy way, IPA.  Maybe not very well balanced, but since i really enjoy hoppy beers, this one really rocks my socks.  Some malt in the finish but otherwise, its a little off balance.
12oz. bottle. Clear, light golden color with a small white head. Nice fruity, citrus hop aroma. Bitter hop flavor with a bit of malt in the background. Dry finish.

I was suprised to see I hadnt rated this, but thanks to a great SS, I now can.  Real nice up front IPA aroma, sweet citrus aroma but a decent malt textrue.  Mouthfeel is a realy blast.  Oily and viscous until the sharpness kicks in then I taste the nice malty backbone.  Solid beer, nothing amazing, but a top notch session.

On tap. Clear yellow color with sa foamy white head. Very nice fresh piney hop smell. Full mouthfeel. A nice malt taste quickly overtaken by a tasty PacNW hop flavor. Not overly bitter or harsh, a good  ipa here.
Bottle (GBBF): Light copper with a beige head. Huge hoppy aroma. Medium bodied. Sweet citric hop flavour with some nice caramel and spice behind. Nice beer.

The requisite pine and citrus aroma, leaning towards grapefruit, wafts from this hazy deep golden ale with orange highlights. Flavor is pretty zippy but leans toward the overt bitterness with citrus skin harshness covering up some moderate fruit, a little fuzzy with pine resin burps. Not my fave IPA but drinkable.

Pours transparent red tinted amber with a medium white head that sticks around. Aroma of fresh pungent fruity mildly citrusy hops and a solid toasty slightly caramel malt backing. Flavor is of citrusy fruity hops and a solid toasty caramely malt. Very nice balance. Medium body silky ever so slightly viscous palate. Aftertaste (and the burps) are a very nice fresh hoppiness and gentle malt sweetness. Very nice IPA.
Amber body, frothy tan head.  Aroma is nice and spicy, very citrusy and hoppy.  Flavor is doughy and sweet, with a nice balance of peppery hops and bready malts.  Dry finish.  Good!
An amber color.  A pine aroma with floral hints.  Nicely hopped but not overly bitter.  Has a medium body.
A well put together beer. An aftertaste that is a delight and lingers for awhile. A pleasant beer from start to finish. A must try for any beer taster!!

Bottled @ GBBF 2005: Golden coloured. Clear. Beige dense head. Herbal and chocolatish aroma. Flavour is very "american". Hoppy flavour like herbs, flowers, grains and some light spices. Is bitter and fruity in the end, and has a good lasting on the palate. Good one.

Plain, light orange body, barely a head at all.  The aroma is delicately hopped, slightly fruity and earlthy.  The flavor is a little weak, but its a nice balance of hops, malts and herbal notes.  Finishes thin, but pleasantly.

I was just in the midwest and, since this brewery was so ubiquitous, I pretty much passed it by for the more obscure beers - now that I can get it in NY, I figured I would give it a shot - I’m kind of sorry I didn’t get some more of their beer when I had the chance - strawberry blonde color with minimal head - aroma of pine, grapefruit and cedar chips - crisp and quite balanced - not very "heavy duty" compared to a lot of other IPAs, but it is a damn fine product.

This one is so common to my area that I think it often gets overlooked. Goose Island brews a damn fine IPA. It may not get the attention of a stone of Dogfish Head, and this may be justified, but, it is very close to the elite IPAs and it is relatively inexpensive and always available. It pours amber and pretty clear, has good hop aroma, and very good flavor, and a very good dry finish. Overall-very solid, a GREAT session beer!

This beer pours a medium amber color with a clean enveloping pearlish head with a nice amount of lacing. The aroma is not overbearing, but releasing the cap yielded a few seconds of overwhelming hops and citrus. Definitely an earthy, woody, citrusy aroma to this though it is of course mostly hops. This is full flavored, though it really settles as it warms. The same could be said for the carbonation which is prickling when cold but soothes when warmed up. Malty mid-sip followed by bitter hoppy citrusyness, then the typically malty, sticky, tangy finish. Some bits of wood and fruits...solid but not overly dry. A fun session beer.

Tap: Super light.  Really hoppy.  Kind of a cannabis tinged nose and flavor.  Crisp.  Balanced out with yeast, and faint malts.  However, a very short finish.  Solid IPA.  Some of the fruity, perfume flavors get lost along the way.
Bottled. Deep golden colour, with a fine white head. Nose of yeast, fruit and hops. Malty, hoppy flavor, but to watery. could need more spices and hops. This was a dissapointment...

Bottle.  Pours a hazy reddish copper, rocky head.  Woody and mild spicy hop nose, mild alcohol. Pleasant toffee and resin hop start to the beer and finishes dry with a spicy lingering hop flavor.  Some metallic notes in the finish.  Medium body, Medium driankability.  "Second 6er on the cincy trip."

A little disappointing in the hop department. Has a slightly bitter nose, very biting. The malt is apparent in the aroma. Nice amber coloring, slightly hazy. Flavor is nice and balanced, which is nice for most, though I prefer more hop profile, hence my disappointment. Smooth finish, with a touch of fruit (citrus) at the end. Overall, not my preferred IPA, but I wouldn’t turn it down.
Bottle.  Poured a fine amber with a bubbly white head. Smells of piney hops and a hint of fruit.  Nice dry mouthfeel, with a hoppy bite.  Smooth drinker.  Nice.
slightly hazy orange, bubbly white head.  aroma of flowers, orange, apricot, grapefuit and earth.  flavous has orange hard candy, smooth flowery hops, earth, pithy bitter finish.  nice.

Pours slightly hazy, golden brown with a smallish head.  Smells distinctively of hops, with a touch of yeast.  Supurbly balanced; a stong hop presence that doesn’t overwhelm.  In fact, the hop seems quite in harmony with the malt, a rarity in IPAs.  There’s absolutely nothing wrong with this beer, but yet somehow it just doesn’t seem remarkable in any real way, either.

Well this beer comes highly recommended to me.  The beer pours orangish amber in color with ample light beige head.  The aroma is a nice balance of floral hops, caramel malt, and fruity yeast.  The flavor is upfront bitterness followed by a solid caramel toffee sweetness and a lingering hop finish.  This is what an IPA should be hoppy and balanced, and thusly very drinkable.
A hazy orange beer with a beutiful white head. The aroma is light - especially for an IPA - but there are some hops to be detected. The flavor is sweet grassy - quite nice - and with a dry end.

Bottle: Vibrant golden, clear, moderate white frothy head, fairly nice lacing, lively carbonation.   Corn oil nose, slight perfume, only a smidgen of hops.   Somewhat bland up front, with an emergence of tea or tobacco leaves near the end.   Moderate body and mouthfeel.   Slightly sweet finish, with the hops only coming out at this point.   Overall, a light IPA thats fairly clean but could stand to be less transparent up front.

Poured orange with a thick white head.  Very hoppy aroma with citrus, graitfruit and pine.  Taste started out a bit too graitfruity but smoothed out quickly.  The mouthfeel had a solid citrus and pine combination.  Good example of the style overall.
A favorite IPA. Not quite as robust as some but excellent nonetheless. More on the order of Alpha King than Two Hearted, say. Consistently great, nicely balanced.

Orangey pour.  Big rush of hops right off the bat, but the aromas seem to blow off over time.  Mild malty backbone coated with piney hops.  Thin bodied.  Very similar to the Hopscotch, but the APA seemed fresher.

Pour is a nice hazy orange with almost no head.  Aroma is a fine citrus-pine.  Flavor is outstanding.  Lots of grapefruit hops with a nice malty backbone.  A very tasty IPA and at a reasonable price.  Bottled or on tap this is a good one.

Pours a light clear amber with a decent off-white bubbly head which dissipates quickly and leaves some lacing.  Somewhat citrus nose, decent amount of hops - long finish.  Light mouthfeel, refreshing.   Nice summer drink.

Clear red gold amber with a medium sized white head.  Citrus and floral hop aromatics.  Pleasing bitter and citrus hop flavors complemented by an equally present hop sweetness.  Rather malty finish.  Mouthfeel is medium light, somewhat sticky.

This one had drifted past its best before date without my noticing, but seemingly none the worse for that. Hazy (didn’t realise its bottle conditioned until  I poured it) orangey colour. There’s pine in the mix but this seemed more citric (grapefruit and bitter orange) and less resinous than some other US IPAs I’ve tried.  Refreshingly sharp, but not excessively so. Quite a classy little number. Bottled, from Safeway.

On tap at brewpub.  A little overcarbonated in my opinion (I think it was on nitrogen, which I don’t really like), and not as hoppy as I like my IPA’s.  Probably true to British-style IPA’s, but not exactly what I’m looking for.  Has a nice amberish color, reasonably hoppy nose and flavor.  Nothing spectacular, but a solid IPA.

Foolishly, I often overlook this brew at the store.  But, for the price, it is truly a special find.  Citrusy and very well hopped, it is an IPA lover’s dream.  Always fresh, this one will become a standard in my fridge.

Poured a clear amber with a moderate white head.  Good lacing.  Aroma was citrus fruit with some pine notes.  Not as pervasive an aroma as I would like.  Light-to-medium malt backbone, with a citrus hoppiness providing much of the flavor (mildly spicy, too).  Very smooth mouthfeel, and quite easy to drink.  Medium, pleasant hop finish.

Bottle.  Pours a nice clear amber color with little head.  Smells of hops, citrus, and pine.  Taste of hops that dominate the flavor leaving the malt to clean up in the finish.  Very smooth and drinkable and leaves you smacking your lips in the finish from all that hoppy bitterness.  The hops are so floral and remind me of Cascade but I’m not sure if that’s what’s  inside this wonderful IPA.

Transparent amber with a creamy, off-white, filmy head. Citrus aromas crossed the board: grapefruit, orange, lemon. Firm flavor, starting with equally present sweetness and bitterness, finishing long and bitter with an oily mouth-presence.



On tap at Goose Island Beer Company (Clybourn), Chicago, IL

The bottle I had did not look like the one pictured, it was a green lable.  Poured a cloudy golden orange.  I should note that it was very hot out the day I tried this so I had it colder than I normally would have (iced mug and all).  Even cold there was a very pleasing sweet pine and citrus hop flowery aroma.  Crisp smelling.  Had a nice hoppy taste despite the cold temperature.  Easy malt flavor.  However, I bet if it had been a bit warmer the hops would have totally over powered the brew (very hop forward).  Body was adequate for the style, but relatively non descript.  A fair brew but not one I would seek out.

12 oz.Bottle:  Pours a Red/Amber color with a large sustaing foamy white head.  Aroma is big flowery hops, some light fruit, and a little pepper spice.  Flavor is hop dominated, sweeter hops at that, with a dry bitter lasting finish.  Could’ve used far more balance.

bottle from duane (i think), pour is a deep cloudy golden color with a creamy off white head that sits on top the entire time. aroma is a ton of flowery hops, a little bit of citrus. flavor starts out very grassy and but balances out very nicely with just enough malts to cut off the bitterness.  aftertaste goes back to the hops, and there is a distinct bitter tail the mouthful which lingers for a while.

Pours a very pale straw-gold, with a nice thick cap of creamy white head, that settles slowly, leaving some nice lacing. Lemon/citrus and herbal hop character, soft, clean, a little bit sweet. Bracing lemon bitterness with a good clingy lingering character. Some odd vegetal character in the finish. A decent IPA, but a bit rough and imbalanced here and there. Some strange distracting off tastes, and rather subdued in aroma.

Bottle acquired in trade with Ughsmash. Poured a medium and hazy amber color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of stronger pine with some grapefruit. Tastes of citrus and pine. Has a light sweetness to it in addition to the bitterness.

Draft @ Clybourn - Sparkling gold, creamy white head.  Nose was loaded with grapefruit, earth, and light piney tones.  Flavor matched with dry citric hops and earthiness throughout, but no real malt backbone to speak of.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, Mojave dry bitter finish.  Not bad, but I like my IPA’s less one dimensional....

This is probably my favorite session IPA. Has a lot of grapefruityhoppiness.  Hazy golden color with a creamy white head that leaves tons of lacing.  I could (and have) drink this all day and never tire of it.
Much better than I anticipated.  Of course hops dominate aroma, taste and aftertaste, with a nice bitterness to go with.  Much more full and developed than I remembered from last time.

Light amber, almost oragnish with a dense mostly diminishing off-white head.  Aroma of piney citrus hops.  Lots of hops everywhere but bitterness is kept subdued.  Some underlying toasted malt provides some balance, but the hops overwhlem over tastes.  Smells fruitier than it tastes.
Bottle. Poured a dark amber hue with a medium off-white head. Aroma is a medium hoppy with a sweet tone. Complex flavor with a medium to full body. Good complex long finish. Good brew.

Slightly cloudy golden yellow color, a strong floral hops aroma with pine. Hops are definitely abundant in this fine refreshing tasting beer. Not much maltiness, bitterness is initally strong than mellows, yet the piney taste of the hops still linger pleasantly at the finish.  I have tasted several Goose Island brews and this is one of my favorites.

Aroma is strong hops and pine, with some citrus floating in and out.  Appearance is translucent copper, with a pure white head that dissipates very fast.  The flavor is hops, hops, and more hops.  Enters strongly bitter, with those hops and their pine flavors dominating the slight maltiness that comes through.  The bitter finish stays on the back of your tongue long you swallow the beer.  Good for the style, but a little too one-dimensional for me.  I would have liked more malt to come through in the flavor, and the finish is just too bitter for my tastes.
(bottle) Light-medium gold with nice white head and some lace. Great pine hops aroma. Flavor is more piney hops, well balanced with malt. A really solid IPA.

Pours copper with a frothy white head.  Aroma is hops and citrus and maybe a little pine.  Flavor is a blast of bitterness very much up front and even later in the brew.  Strong yet very pleasant.  A tasty brew indeed.  Yummy!

Bottle from a friend.  Aroma: before the hops hit (immediately upon pour) there was a doughy smell.  Then the hops came and were balanced between grassy and grapefruit hops.  Appearance: a bubbly 20k gold.  Frothy white head with EXCELLENT lacing.  The flavor was not really a hoppy domination.  A touch of caramel and dough.  Light citrus hops with some fruitiness.  Lots of toasted malts.  Palate is refreshing, sweet, had excellent carbonation, and a medium mouthfeel.
On tap @ GI Clybourn. Reddish orange color with a white head. The aroma is piney first and then citrusy. Malty flavor at first with a huge piney flavor. Nice mouthfeel.

Bottle, from trade with TAR. Good nose, lemon, grass, sourdough, Clean pale golden color, small head that faded to a hazy cover. Bitter flavors, Lemon, kinda metallic and soapy, Thin body, Watery mouthfeel, though a little creamy, sort of, bitter dy finish. Had a scent that reminds me of some lagers. I imagine this once seemed bigger, but now is  on the lite side of things. Thanks TAR.

On tap at Hyatt Downtown

Very nice appearance and great head retention. NIce hop aroma, but could be more evident.  Very hoppy taste, citrusy with grapefruit accent.  Bitterness well balanced with malt.

A surprisingly deep flavor (from a now mass-brewer).  Takes their already hoppy flavor to a new place.  Stays smooh and clean on the palate with malt-caramel flavor mixed in with the hoppy fruit presence. [$6.79/6pk]

Pours a very thick head that lasts -- even the lacing stays up at the top of the glass forming what could be described as a Roman Aqueduct pattern. Beer has a nice light amber color too, though quite light for an IPA it does have the characteristic lack of bubbles. Malt shows through the typical floral hops in the aroma carrying with it a faint impression of tomato soup. Similarly, there are some tomato-garlic soup elements to the flavor, commendable for a beer style not known for much being able to show over the standard high floral hoppiness. The finish is more along the lines of a typical IPA in that hops come back further to the forefront. I agree that this seems more like a great pale ale than a robust IPA, but I’ll only dock it 2 overall points for this in that the beer is very satisfying in any case.

First experience was on tap at Clybourn.  Thought I should give it another try (via bottle) because Goose Island rarely lets me down.  Turns out I was right...

October 31, 2005 / 12-oz. bottle.
Still a beauty with a more promulgating and alluring spicy hop and floral aroma.  Balanced profile and void of the searing qualities I found on tap.  Fantastic malt sweetening to hold up the brisk bitterness.

April 11, 2005 / On tap at the brewery.
 Color is a murky brownish-orange.  Smells dry hopped, with a predictable floral bouquet, along with a dash of lemon grass.  Flavor is grassy and hoppy, but not as aggressively hopped as aroma suggested.  Creamy, moderate body.  Seems to be missing some carbonation, but there’s a descent pilsener and caramel malt presence along with the 40-some IBUs that help balance the beer and bring it back on track.  Finish is nice, bitter, and sweetly floral.  Backend hop finish is better and more consistent with the IPA genre than the first taste on the palate would suggest.  Still, I think I’d be more inclined to file this as a Pale Ale rather than an IPA.
Draft at the brewery.  Not the strong hop taste in most good pale ales.  The lightness and lack of a strong flavor does go well with the good food severed at the brewery.

Very nicely done (if a bit unadventuresome)...great hop aroma with citrus and floral notes...malty sweetness predominantly in the flavor...and hop bite returning to save the day in the finish.  Good all around IPA.
golden colored with citric & floral hoppiness, this brew provided a nice accompanyment to some seriously spicy food.

Pours golden with medium white head.  Floral and citrus aroma.  Initially a very good hops taste but it ends up a little dry and thin thus the low score in the palate catagory.  It’s not bad especially for a beer I can find in Krogers but it reminds me of what  IPA concentrate would taste like.  Similiar to the difference between orange juice from concentrate and fresh squeezed.

Bottle: Poured a medium lightly hazed gold with a fair tight cap. Soft carbonation. Aroma of grapefruit, apricots and sweet malts. Viscous mouth feel...good malt spine gives a sweetish biscuity taste where mild hops and the yeasts add an apricot taste that turns bitter in the finish...very nice.. I like this IPA... wasn’t expecting this from GIB.

Bottle. Hazy orange, nice looking beer. More in the way of pine like hop notes than a heavy citrus palate. Hop/malt balance is nice. Comes across somewhat dry. Hops flavors arent real colorful, but it is still a solid IPA that is easy to drink anytime.

Hoppy aroma, as expected.  Some malt in the taste.  Bitter finish.  Balanced.  Not the best IPA that I’ve had, but it tastes good. Something about it reminds me of Bell’s APA, but I can’t pick it out.  There is a taste of pine...I could taste it most heavily when I burped haha.

Very tasty with a fruity and hoppy aroma. A fresh and nice balanced IPA. My kind of beer.  
  
  
Re-rating. 
355 ml bottle @ Melkebaren, Sandnes. Almost clear amber body with a medium sized white head. Nice aroma of grapefruit, peaches and caramel. Flavor is refreshing fruity, bitter and caramel malt. Quite straight forward IPA, and should not offend anyone, still really nice. Medium body and decent bitter aftertaste.

Poured a pale copper color with a small, off white, bubbly, head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of citrus grapefruit, pine resin, adequate amount of floral hops, with a minor malt backbone.  Taste of citrus, very nice balance in the taste as well.  Citrus hops, with a nice malt balance.
Bottle.  Cloudy and amber.  Orangish aroma.    Malty flavor with a nice bitter finish.  Very tasty and easy to put down.
Bottle. Golden-amber with nice head. Lightly malty, good hop presence - mostly piney and resinous, little grapefruit. Well made and highly drinkable.
Bottle.  I strongly suspect that this is better directly from their tap, like their other beers.  As it is, it’s a pretty mediocre IPA, too watery and lacklusterly flavored.  I give it a 6/10.
Orange hazy amber ale with a light white head. Smooth hops and orange notes in aroma. Sweet malt and good hops with a good citrus bite. Sweet caramel finish. Medium bodied.
Pours a somewhat amber colour, strong hop aroma. Citrus flavours, with strong hops. Very good IPA.

Bottle. Pours a bright orange color with a white foamy head. Nose is bright, dry hop notes. Palate is full, fluffy, with a light tingle. Flavor is full hops up front with a grassy and citrus note. Finishes a bit biscuity as it warms and there is a nice bitterness.
A very nice, yet mellow ipa.  Not huge with the hops but a nice balance.  Some subtle earthy undertones also present in the aroma and flavor.  Not bad.
Bottle. Fruity American hops with citrus zest. Pretty fizzy with annoying notes of damp tea towels.
Medium head, dark orange colour. Malty nose with powerful hop aroma. Dry malty, hoppy body, with both hops and malts lingering long into the aftertaste. Absolutely lovely!

Draught.  At Sharp Edge in East Liberty, Pittsburgh, PA.  Brought home a growler.  Nice brew.  Pours dark golden with nice head and great carbonation.  It’s fun to drink out of the growler on the way home.... I wasn’t driving!  Great roasted hoppy taste (I don’t know what the hop is other than Cascade, but it’s used in 90 minute from Dogfish Head as well).  Nice body, nice carb, great balanced flavor.  Very nice stuff!
A pretty good IPA, not hoppy enough, but still better than many I’ve tried, A great drinking beer, thanks Duane!
A nice pour good head and lacing. Hoppy aroma is there but not as much as I like. A good bottled IPA. Flavor has a little citrus and slightly bitter finish,a nice session IPA.

From the bottle, it pours a light, clear copper-orange color with a small rocky white head. The head disipates quickly leaving some lacing on the rim of the glass. The aroma is of sour grapefruit peel with notes of grass and some sweete malt undertones. The initial flavor is also of sour grapefruit peel.  The middle begins to balance things out with a bit of sweet malt and then the finish is of hop bitterness that lasts a long time.  A VERY nice IPA.
