Excellent IPA.  Goes down easier than just about anything.  Heaven in a bottle.
Light, clear copper body with a small white head. Aroma is citrus and freshly cut grass. Taste is pleasantly bitter, with oranges and lemons. Good session IPA and a great value.

Pours with a light copper hue with good head and lace. Aroma was piney and fruity with some roasted malt and grassy notes.  Initially the taste was piney and mildly bitter.  In the middle it  showed some fruitiness on the edges and a malt presence that I didn’t expect. The finish dry and there was a definite bitter hop flavor.  Mouthfeel was more or less smooth and a notch or two above what I would call "thin".   Probably more of an APA than an IPA, but a good one no matter how you classify it.  Thanks DavidP!

Lovely stuff.  Clear copper.  Huge, puffy white head.  Nice nose, lots of orange and citrus, sweet malts as well.  Good flavor, hops are quite noticeable without being overpowering, tart and citric, but beautifully balanced stuff, lots of caramel and butterscotch.  Creamy as well.  Leaves a nice floral aftertaste.  Really good stuff.
Copper-orange color. Citrus and fruity aroma. Little bitter and malty. Slightly weak character as IPA, but I like this taste. One of my best beer!!

Sparkling copper body topped by a substantial slightly off-white head. The wispy glass lace is a treat. The aroma of piney hops hits you the minute the cap is popped. Deep inhaltions only comfirm the pine hops, but also add a bit of light non-offensive plastic, and light caramel sweetness. The flavor is packed with juicy hops with a smattering of sweet malts swirling around to keep things under control. The body is medium with a fairly attenuated finish. Bitterness develops throughout culminating in a big bitter burst right after the swallow. Nice enough, though it does make my palate weary even though it is not nearly as big as some other hop monsters out there.
Sweet, hoppy, spicy aroma. Nice slightly milky golden tan color. Aroma bursts on the palate with lots of hop. Smacks slightly bitter, but pleasently complex.

draft: aroma, citrus and hops, color orangish, white head, lacing, pleasant citrus and pine flavor,  definitely grapefruit, pleasant hop finish.
Pretty good.
bottle. copper-orange colour with a small white head/lace. beautiful hop aroma and lots of grapefruit. sweet hoppy flavour, slightly acidic. long bitter finish.  A solid IPA.

Thanks to Duane for this.  Dark straw pour, with a medium, fizzy white head that dissipated quickly.  Wow, the aroma.  Reminds me of Titan.  Huge piney esters coupled with resiny florals.  Almost perfect aroma.  Now, for the taste.....I bring it to my eager mouth.....hoppy, very hoppy, with some floral, fruity, spicy hints at mid palate and at the esophageal boundary.  As it warmed, more intense pinet resins emerged.  This beer is as underrated as a 50 cent, disease-free whore with 3 inputs.

Pours hazy orange golden with a solid white head. Aroma is mostly bitter and flower hoppy, not very heavy but nice and fresh. Flavor is fruity and hoppy with a good bitter end and nutty notes. Little thin in the body but still nice and tasty. An easy drinkable IPA.

Pleasant aroma of floral hops, light fruit, and honey.  Golden-amber color, thin white head.  Nice hop flavor, decent malt support, honey, solid bitterness.  Medium body, dry finish.  Good all-around IPA, good balance.
(Bottle) Pours a cloudy light-orange body. The nose has a strong sweet orangy-hops aroma. Great Hi-C hops flavour in the beer - should be the basis of what IPAs are gauged. Solid beer. Thanks Luc.

Rather cloudy(my fault,not paying attention when pouring, so unfair to penalise the beer), aroma is fantastic hops ,hops & more hops, and some malt.
There is so much flavour here, superbly balanced. At the moment this is available at Safeway, but will it survive the Morrison takeover..I hope so.

Nothing special about the pour - muted yellow, small head that soon disappears.  The aroma though!  Wow!  The floral hops smell great - and taste just as good.  Nice malt start - and a great bitter finish.  The IPA thins out in the middle though.  Who cares!  For $6.50 a six this could be one of my new favorite IPAs.

Very nice floral aroma.  Pours slightly hazy and light orange.  Off-white head with large bubbles fades quickly.  Very good balance between malt and hops.  Well carbonated and light on the palate.  Maybe a bit thin.  Overall a very nice IPA.
This was the first IPA I ever had and I still drink it today.  Very good starter IPA had a odd smell  like flowers, buttasted good.  The head could have stayed around a little longer.

Bottle Pours a hazy amber orange with a small white head and thin lacing.   Aroma is plenty of hops but fruity, citrus and melon maybe.  Flavor is rich citrusy hops and lots of balancing sweet malts.  Feel is very full bodied thick and smooth  Aftertaste is a nice sharp bitterness but fits well with all the other flavors.  A very nice drinkable IPA.  Thanks MrFacto

12 oz brown long neck.
in appearance this is a slightly murky orange, with a large bubble white head, that goes fast but does leave substantial lace.
The aroma is quite subdued for an American IPA, but all the usual aromas are present.
This is quite malty for an American IPA, its all malt at the very first sip, but soon the hops take over.in the middle and back of the tongue. Quite spicy and citric. good bitter after taste.
Quite nice on the palate, maybe just a touch on the thin side.
Its a nice enough beer and drinkable..but not very exciting.

The head was gone in no time.  Kinda cloudy.    Lots and lots of flavor... much more hoppy than MacTarnahan IPA, which I drank side by side with it.  As the others said it is kinda dry which made me love the aftertaste which is also slightly bitter.  This is probably the best IPA I can get at my local liquor store (Lucas Liquor in St. Louis).

Wow.  I am surprised at how good this is.  Orangeish gold color and kinda foggy.  Beautiful citrus hop aroma.  Perfect bitterness and very flavorful.  Best Goose Island I’ve had thus far.

Rerate. This beer has changed over the years. Certainly it has tamed or my expectations of an IPA have changed.

Bottle. Poured  Golden amber with nice fizzy head, and the aroma was outstandging. Malts yes, but good nose of hops and pine . Wow, hops jump right out, but the middle is dry and malty. The flavor is quite nice and last well.
Pours a hazy orange/yellow, nice big white head, lots of lacing. aroma of piney hops, lemon, and orange. Flavor is very smooth and full, very balanced hops and malt. Very nice.

Orange and hazy red in the glass with some lacing from the thin white head.  Aromas are apricot, lemon, pancake, and malt.  Medium-bodied, lots of round hop flavors, but little texture and an indifferent finish.  They are right on about the dry malt middle, which lends the beer a balance and drinkability.  Not big hops, but a good straight-up IPA.

My favorite from These guys... not as hoppy as I was hoping for, but I think i may have an issue when it comes to that area.  Again, I like the $1.30 price tag on the goose island stuff (which may be why i like them so much!)
bottle.  poured a clear amber with a very nice off-white head.  Laceing was extremely nice and left a good  trail as I worked my way to the bottom of the glass.  quite hoppy, a true IPA.

Clear amber appearance with an average head  and good lacing.  Hoppy aroma blended some spicyness along with the citrus.  Medium-bodied with a decent malt backbone to balance the hops.  Dry, bitter finish.
Pours orange/amber with a tiny white head. Stong citrus aroma. Great grapefruit hoppy taste and an aftertaste of the same. This beer is way underrated. Crisp and hoppy. Great stuff.
Nice amber colour with a gorgous hoppy aroma backed up by that unmistakable IPA big hoppy taste.....yet anothet cracker from this brewery.

Bottle. Poured a medium sized off-white head, fair lacing, transparent, carbonated, and an orange hue. Malty, hoppy and sweet in the aroma. Flavor was sweet, lightly bitter, and very hoppy. Tingly, hoppy and somewhat dry mouthfeel. Medium bodied.
Green hoppy nose.  Lightly toasted malt, a little doughy.  Sweet malt, slightly herbal.  Floral sweet finish.  This is a solid beer.

Thanks to Indra for sending this one my way.
Good ambe color under an average white head.
Flowery hop aroma with some pine in there too.
The flavor starts with ainitial hop bitterness and then the malt comes in from behind to balance this one out nicely.  Good quaffable IPA.
Very intresting, and a great beer. Fro those that enjoy this one you should also try the midway IPA. Some will like that even better

This is a very good IPA and at a reasonably good value. I appreciate the lingering bitterness of the hops. There’s plenty of tang to go around just as you’d expect. Good malty body is there but you have to get past the hops to find it...just as it should be with an IPA. What I really like about this IPA is that is readily available at a lot of retail outlets.
One of the best IPAs around. Not nasty or over the top like some. Very smooth and highly quaffable with BBQ chips.

Bottle from ford9719. Dark golden with huge frothy white head. Great lacing. Aroma rather bland, standard ipa. Malt dominates, less hoppier than I expected. Flavor again huge caramel malt sweetness and only the faintest pine resin in the finish. Third time around for this beer, and I always expect more for some reason.
A very good IPA, nice mixture of hops and malt.  It has a very lite fruit hint along with that hop bite which goes together nicely.

A good brew,and for an ipa it is farly smooth.Nice citris nose,and taste.
Nothing metalic,or off putting about this brew.
Bottle.  Medium amber color.  Fast fading white head.  Some lacing.  Flowery aroma with malt.  Body is medium with a decent mouthfeel.  Malty taste with a decent hop backing.  A nice IPA.
Dark gold color with small head.  Bitter hops aroma.  Kind of a flowery and bitter taste.  It is not so overabundant on hops as to make you sick.  A tasty IPA.

Bottle:  Aroma is hoppy with grapefruit and pine.  Pours a light transparent amber with a small white head with little retention.   Nice balance of malts and hops.  LIghtly sweet initial taste with a grapefruit and pine aftertaste. Strong orange presence.   Little more hops would improve the beer but overall a nice IPA.

Poured a orange-yellow with small rocky head.  Nice floral aroma.  The flavor is dry, yet sweet at the same time, with a nicely balanced citric hop edge and sharp orange-rind finish.  Yummy.  One of my everday beers ...

Not a bad IPA, but, once again, the Goose Island folk are being overly cautious.  It pours a dark golden color with a one-fingered head that settles down pretty quickly.  Nice bitter, earthy hop aroma.  I don’t catch the "fruity aroma" described in their ad.  Dry & bitter, but not real flavorful like American IPAs have been lately.  A decent drink... Thank goodness, ’cause I have five to go.
Gold/Amber Coloring. Small Head. Good Lacing.  Hops, With Some Wheat and Citrus Flavors.  For Not Being a Lover of IPA’s, I Have to Say I Really Enjoyed This One.

pretty descent ipa from goose.  quite bitter, more than expected.  nice smell and taste of hops and citrus.  poured out a purty golden color, and went down quite smooth.  came in a goose variety pack.

at a bar in chicago bottled:  this one was good......a copper cool crisp color and an off white poofy head.  red hot notes of citrus and pine in the nose...definately hopped....follows through in the  mouth some spice feel and fruitiness that is quite well balanced.  the real litmus test was when i tried to feed this to my bud friends and it was too much for them...this usually means its good.  the best goose island beer i had while in chicago.

Pours amber/gold with a medium, off-white, frothy head; tons of lacing.  Lovely aroma, with lots of hops and also plenty of malts to balance; nice caramel along with the citrus.  Flavor is predominantly hoppy, as expected.  Mouthfeel not as clean as I’d like, but it’s certainly not watery, it’s just that the finish doesn’t linger as long as some other stronger IPAs, but I really can’t complain about that.  Overall, this is a solid IPA--one of my favorites--and, I think, I very good IPA for people who don’t really like IPAs all that much.

At one time I considered this a very bitter beer now I find it watery.  The color has also changed from an amber to more golden now.  I have heard that they have some money problems and this may be a cut back beer or maybe my memory is fading.  Still a decent IPA.
Citrus and hops on the nose. Poured a nice gold, with a medium white head. Flavor of citrus and hops, nice bitterness.
(Draught)  Pours a clear golden color with a descent-sized white head.  Beautiful bouquet of florals and grapfruit aroma.  Flavor is grapfruity.  Enjoyable IPA!

On tap at the Crescent Moon Alehouse.   I first had this IPA years ago at the Chicago brewpub and thought that it was outstanding, until I tried some of their specialty brews. Suddenly, the IPA fell into the B-O-R-I-N-G category. I’m glad that I have rediscovered this ale at my neighborhood public house. This is a solid IPA by any determination. The hop aroma is very pronounced. I’m not so sure why this is as light as it is in color. Malt content is there. I don’t think that it is too light, but it isn’t as thick as some IPA’s. Could this be fuggle hops? It just does not taste like garden-variety cascade hops like so many other IPA’s. Not the best IPA, and certainly not the best beer made by Goose Island, but I was so very wrong for ever considering this boring. Very memorable bitter finish leaves you with the need to have another.
UPDATE: In the bottle at the Huber Haus IPA tasting. Definitely Columbus Hops. Finishes almost pot-like. Still a great beer.

One of the best American beers easily available in Scotland. Heavy, fruity american (cascade?) hop aroma, orangey, resinous, with some vanilla and pepper. Lovely medium mouthfeel with oily, bitterness and a long bitter finish, again with fruit evident as well as bags of hops.

12oz bottle BBD020705  Nice, rich brassy color.  Good head & lace...happy bubbles.  Nice nose of malt & floral, citrusy, piney hops.  This smells fresh.  I wonder how long after bottling that date is?  Light bodied.  Flavor doesn’t quite live up to the aroma.  Malt is somewhat there, hop flavors are there, but not a super bold beer.  It is light drinking, which hurts it a tad.  Hops dominate, but bitterness not as promounced as some.  Still, a lingering hop resin, citric note perists in the aftertaste.  Seems more pale ale than IPA...But a good hoppy beer.

Some say that this is the best of the regular production Goose Island products. Perhaps the best lacing of any beer I’ve ever had. Beautiful huge white foamy head. This is a good IPA all around. Very nice grapefruit nose. Hoppy body. Very bitter finish, almost like an ESB. Quite good. Nice colorful labels as well.

Golden orange  in color with a white head. Has a orange and lemon citrus notes in the aroma. Sometimes it can smell like juicy fruit gum, or have grassy hops dominate the citrus. Flavor varies significantly from batch to batch. Some are very sweet and citrusy while others have much more hop profile to them. Very nice hoppy citrus lemon and orange taste with some noticable malt to balance. A superb brew very fruity and tasty.

08.29.04  12oz bottle.  Golden color, or a pale amber; smallish head.  Pretty standard micro-IPA in most respects, but with a real kick-ass aroma. Lots of citrus blossoms, springtime pines, and grapefruit breakfast smells make for a delicious nose.  The flavors don’t really keep up as the hops, which were so welcome in the aromas, completely take over the flavor.  Nice bitterness on finish, but an aftertaste that lingers in a not so great way.  Thanks Bunkypop.

Draught:  Clear, ruby-amber color.  Lasting, average, creamy white head.  Excellent lacing.  Heavy flowery, grassy, piney, sprucy, citrusy, hop flavor.  Also some clove notes.  Medium body and slick texture.  Average carbination.  Bitter finish.  Heavily bitter.  Pretty good IPA.
Bottle from Safeway. Golden coloured, with a good white head. Very hoppy, aroma and a hoppy taste. Bitter and slightly malty aftertaste. Medium body. Good IPA.

Clear amber with a thick frothy off white head.  Aroma of citrus, tangerine, caramel, pine, and light bread with a hint of spice.   Medium velvety body with a moderate amount of carbonation.  Flavor of bread, orange peel, grapefruit, biscuits, caramel, and pine with a hint of spice and leather.  Hoppy, but not as ridiculously overdone as with some American IPAs. Good.

Very hoppy nose, clear golden/orange color, very thin white head, a little light in the palate, hoppy flavor but lacking depth, no subtle hints of fruit or gnomes hats, a little malty and then a bitter hop finish, not bad but not a stand out by any stretch.
Excellent hop flower nose  - after that a nice sharp flavour but then gives way to a pretty standard IPA.  Good but not great.

Piney aroma, hoppy taste. Bitter, as you would expect from the style.
Good beer.

This was good but it seems to me that all IPAs are starting to taste the same, within a small deviation.  I can’t remember the last time I had an IPA offer something new to me.   Pours a clear copper/amber color with a small white and well-lacing head.  Aroma is IPA.  Flavor is IPA.  Body is IPA.  See what I mean?

Bottled at Derby Beer Festival. Outstanding stuff; shimmering amber body topped with a firm white head. Stunning hoppiness, limes shine through in the refreshing flavour, biscuit dry finish. I’ll certainly be buying a few cases of this in the vain hope that the English summer wiill let me enjoy a few out on the patio.
Bottled.  Bright clean amber body, large bone/light brown head. Generous hop and vanilla aroma. Classic American IPA flavour, hoppy and delicious. I love these beers.

A fantastic IPA. Copper in colour with loads of leafy hops, citrus, and pine notes. Grapefruit and white grape flavors abound. A fair amount of malt and bitterness as well. I could see some fans of really bitter IPAs thinking this one is a bit on the tame side, but it strikes a near-perfect balance for me. This is one I really wish I could get locally.

Slightly hazy bright copper color, full and firm cream colored head, looked great. Quite hoppy throughout, leafy and green with some notes of citrus, with a solid malt backbone. Very drinkable, long finish but not overly bitter, medium body. I enjoyed this one. Thanks NorthYorkSammy.

Light bright golden color - light foamy white head.  The nose is sweet and malty with a resiney hoppiness sticking through.  Organic leafy hop notes along with a tinge of citrus - grapefruit (a conglomeration of hop smells).  Fresh smelling and quite malty.  The body is lightly spritzy with a light hop bite at the front.  Sweetens quickly with a light malty bite.  Finishes moderately long with an organic/leafy hop bitterness.
Great IPA i had this one fresh at one of goose island’s brew pubs.  moderate malt.  lots of citrus hops that are also evident in the nose.

Pours golden copper with an off white head. Aroma is hoppy and grapefruity, very sniffable. Taste is of hops, pine, grapefruit/citrus. Good malt backing. Moderately sweet, nice bitter aftertaste. Mouthfeel is full, round and creamy with lively carbonation. Not aggressive or over the top. Some lacing left on the glass, decent head retention. Overall, a fine IPA

Nice and hoppy aroma; piney. Tough to smell with clove cigarettes during the 9th annual Prairie Rock Brewfest in Elgin, IL, however. Orangish, brown in color. Off-white head. Not much lace or head. Hoppy initial mouthfeel. Malty finish. Pollished compared to the America’s Whistle Stop Pale Ale I had right before. Nice spicey finish not unlike earlier versions of the GI Oktoberfest. Excellent brew.

Frequent trips to Chicago and the Midwest in the mid 90’s had me drink my share of Goose Island.  IPA was no exception.   I brought back a six-pack from a recent trip to Cleveland.     Goose Island’s IPA has a citrus aroma, light (cascade?) hop flavor and mild sweetness.   Easy to drink even though its higher alcohol content.  WCSB Rocks!
Nice natural IPA. Well-balanced and pleasant. Got it directly on tap at the brewery and enjoyed it a lot. However it took them 5 minutes to pour it. But it was worth the wait.

attractive gold color with a frothy white head.  primarily centennial-like bitterness in the aroma, but the aroma turns complex with a tangier fruitier hops presence.  first taste is hoppy and bitter, but turns dry and malty.  finishes pretty clean, very refreshing on a summer night.  i could drink a lot of this, i think!
A nice easy to drik session IPA.  Gold in color with a bit of head.  Good notes of hops and some citrus.  A good anytime beer.

Gold color, dissipitating foam. Lace. Grapefruit citrsu hoppy floral aroma. Grapefruit taste with some bitterness. Light creamy texture. Dry aftertaste with bit of burn. Distinctive American hops, bit aggressive and tongue still numb,

beautiful golden appearance w/ solid carbonation.. verry little head.
Smell was a citrusy hoppy aroma appealing to my sence.
Taste followed the smell.. mildly bitter with an odd citrus taste that I could not discern... overall this was one of the few IPA’s I’ve tried and liked as I’m not a fan of the bitter bears.

(355 ml bottle). This was my first American IPA, now available in Norway! Deep golden colour, good head. Lovely hoppy citrussy aroma. I got more pleasure sniffing this beer than I got from drinking it. Flavour is all hops (where are the malts?), dominant initial grapefruity bitterness like I expected (not unpleasant), quite drinkable, but the one-dimensional, medicinal and wormwoodlike bitterness that remains in the aftertaste is not to my liking.

Shiny gold body with a soapy/fizzy white head. Light orange citrus hops aroma with some strawberry. May need to be fresher for better aroma. Flavor is also light... again, a sweet orange-light hops. The flavor is really good, but not earth shattering or powerful.
Bottled. Says its bottle conditioned but it doesn’t appear to be. Herbal hop aroma/flavour... high bitterness. Pretty good, not great.

Mostly lasting white head with good lacing throning over a clear honey body. Supposedly bottle-conditioned. Aroma develops  distinct orange peel and honey resembling malt. Not too complex, but obviously balanced. Slightly tart, spicy and dry palate with plenty of fresh orange and a bit of pepper. Light-medium body, quite creamy with lively carbonation. Very typical IPA, you like the style or you don’t, but this one is certainly gonna be nobody’s favorite. It’s just an unpretentious straightforward easy-going american india pale ale, just how many of these do we need though?

nice golden color, not as dark as some pales, but nice color nonetheless. Full head, lots of CO2.  Aroma is hopped pleasantly with a distinct sweetness that shows the strong malt character. Now to taste: very hoppy with a good amount of malt taste, though not the sweetness that the aroma suggests. a bit much CO2, though. I do enjoy the nice complexities of the malt interacting with the hops. another solid brew from my hometown brewery.

Straw yellow, huge hop aroma, no malt. Taste hop bitterness and alcohol, with very little malt sweetness. Too much bitterness without any balance. Acidic bite from too much CO2. Don't care too much for this one.
I always make sure to have a few of these when I'm at the brewery in Chicago.  Decent hop content.

This was an ok IPA.  It could be well improved with a little more hops.  Overall, pale with a mild flavor.  Drunk with other styles of beer, seems nice.  Does not stand up as well to other IPAs though.
Honey gold.  Fresh and hoppy aroma.  the taste is pleasantly tart and dry; very good as opposed to excellent.  Head not particularly well retained.
Very good IPA. Not my favorite but tastes good and satifying. Nice head out of bottle. Hoppy flavor. Goose Island makes a fine product.

12oz Bottle best By 08/24/04 Thanks to EddieG for this bonus Brew! Poured a clear dark gold with a bit of a head that died quickly. Has a nice hoppy doughy aroma. Slightly floral and citric. Smooth body and crisp with a bitter finish. Flavor could be better. Decent hoppiness and backed up by a good dose of malt. Reminds me a bit of Brutal Bitter in a way. Overall a decent IPA.

12oz. bottle:  The beer pours a golden color with a hint of orange to it.  It has a slightly hazy appearance, with a bit of a white head.  A big grapefruit nose of hops.  Also a hint of some floral notes.  The taste is bold and hoppy:  a hint of grapefruit in the taste also.  A very good effort!

355ml brown bottle poured into a Dentergems glass of similar volume.Medium white head which dispersed slowly. Some lacing.Yellow gold colour with tiny bubbles.Peach and melon aroma with hops. Like the smell on entering a London high street 24 hour Off-Licence.Ruby grapefruit flavour and nice hops.If Her Majesty's troops in colonial India had IPA like this shipped out to them they would never have left. A lovely at a good price(£1.29 in London)
Amber coloured, nice head. Good hoppy aroma flavour is citrus and spice, better than expected.

Golden in color, just a slight film of head around the top & edges of the glass, some lacing, nose was decently hopped with a nice mix of sweet malt, medium in body, hoppy & spicy flavors, piney & dry, aftertaste a bit dry & with some resiny notes, not a bad IPA

Bottle. Rerating this after a long absence. The body is dark orange and this has a long lasting off white head with small bubbles. There is a lot of lacing on the glass. The aroma is oranges and caramel. The taste has some bitter grapefruit with a very smooth and slick mouthfeel. There is also a little burnt toffee and some mild spice like corriander. Nicely made, but a little too much citrrus for my tastes.

Pours a almost perfectly clear copper color, topped by a pale cream head that is supported by fairly low carbonation.  Some notes of pine and citrus in the aroma, quite a bit of hop floral nectar characteristics.  A bit of fruitiness and sharp astringent hoppiness in the nose as well, but in a good way.  Taste is sharp and bitter from the hops, supported by a biscuit like maltiness.  Quite a dry beer overall as well, but quite a bit maltier than I at first realized.  A good amount of hop flavor and a solid dry malt character in the middle is a counter point to the bitterness in the finish.  The hops are sharp produce a tingle as this beer passes my lips, just like a good IPA should.

This was the first IPA that I tried and I absolutely loved it. The aroma is like a spritz of orange. The color, while not as nice as some more expensive IPAs, is an orange that further suggests a citrus flavor. The flavor has a very nice mix of bitterness, with hops that linger through the floral/citrus and a good, dry finish. Only problem is that it could stand to be a bit more hoppy.
Nice golden color, a somewhat thin head.  Clean citrus-hop aroma; good mouthfeel with a smooth malty finish that keeps this beer interesting to the end.

Golden colour with minimal head.  The aroma is citrusy with notes of lemons.  The flavour is immensely hoppy but too extreme.  Almost like grapefruit at breakfast which desperately needs sugar.  Too hoppy for me but doubtless a fine beer.  Score 3.1
Subsequent ratings scored 3.5, 3.8, 3.6, 3.6, 3.6 and 3.6. Average becomes 3.5
Nice citrus flavor, quite hoppy with a zany bitterness.  A bit too much hoppiness for me but other than that, it's preety good.
A well balanced hop flavor with good nose and head. A IPA that can be had all night. Decent head and nice lacing make this a fine IPA.
Had this when in Chicago last ... excellent.  Could use just a bit more hops/bitterness.

Aroma begins with a crisp, grassy hop, towards the middle more sour apples develop.  Deep golden color, clear with some tiny bubbles, and nice head.  Flavor mirrors the aroma, very hoppy at first, not the piney quality of west coasts, and towards the middle the malt comes alive.  Firm body and  touch of sourness.  Crisp tart finish.  Decent.
a very good IPA.  Not very  hoppy.. but i consider that an advantage more then a disadvange.  Sweet taste, just enough hops to keep it intresting, but still nothing special.

Smells like grapefruit and pine, what a shocker. Amber with decent head. Thin mouthfeel. One dimensional malt flavor is completely dominated by citric hops. Where is this frutiness I have been hearing about? Hops won't go away, even after the glass has long been emptied. Should come with a white and black generic American IPA label on it with a caution: This beer lacks creativity or character. BTW, if you are looking for a great IPA from this region, get the Bells Two Hearted Ale listed to your right.

The appearance is nothing special but fairly standard for the style.  Frothy white head on an amber body.  Aroma is dominated by the floral /citrus aroma. The taste however is supported by a nice malt backbone for an IPA. Mouthfeel is nice and buttery. I like this beer and would add it to my repurchase list.  Give this one a shot.

sweet n' fruity floral hop aroma..nice, semi-bitter yet grainy flavors with some notes of grapefruit.  Not as complex as you'd think from the aroma..but somewhat balanced and refreshing with tangerine notes here and there.

This is a pale ale. It is a pale orangish color, and it is an ale
Hops dominate the nose, but there is a more than ample malt backbone.  Good medium mouthfeel, clean, hoppy follow through.  Beer as it ought to be.
GABF '03. Gold pour with minimal head. Brewed more in the English Style IPA and not as hoppy as I like. Nice floral aroma and mellow malt finish.
Deep gold with a nice aroma. Wow, lots of hops in here. Strong finish and aftertaste; not a daily drinker.
Reddish-amber with a somewhat thin off-white head. Nice citrusy aroma and taste, with a decent bitter hop finish. Not bad at all.

gold in color.  smells like toast with orange marmalade.  starts sweet and citrusy, then a bit of a bitter hop bite... but not the 'ooomph' i like in my ipas.  thin palate.  not offensive, not great, but very drinkable.

On tap

Reddish-copper color with a nice head.  Caramel maltiness with spicy, citrusy hops.  Raisin-y undertones.  Pleasant bitter aftertaste, light-creamy mouthfeel. Great session brew in my opinion.  It's an average, quality IPA.

Re-rate: 13/6/04 Tried again (3 bottles) whilst watching England narrowly lose to France at Euro 2004. Much better than I gave it credit for, and better than the highly enjoyable Sierra Nevada Pale Ale. Refreshing and a real good, hoppy hit. // Original rating [3.1] - This looked like a nice drink, and, indeed was. An initial burst of citrus favour gives way to an extended bitter alcohol hit, and aftertaste. Quite nice.

Quite clear for an India Pale. Nice orange color to it with a lot of carbonation.There is a cream quarter inch head with some nice lacing. Definite grapefruit peel smell to it, quite citrusy and bitter smelling. Quite bitter flavor as well, but inoffensive. Good but I think that I like the flavor of the Avery IPA q bit better.

Oh my Proteus, this is an actually GOOD IPA made in Chicago! Hoppy and strong, with a surprising citrusy finish, this is a beer I'll buy again (it also helped that the six-pack (bottles) was on sale at Krogers for $4.99)!
Amber coloured. Very hoppy aroma with notes of peach-flavoured ice tea and honey. Lots of good bitterness in the flavour.

This is everything I hate about IPA's. It has so much promise but leaves that bitter after taste which just turns off many tasters. The first sign that this is not going to be a pleasant experience on how fast the head disappers.

Slightly hazy golden yellow body. Quickly diminshing white head with no lacing.

Hops dominate the aroma but there's also an underlying sour malt aroma too.

Lots of hops with a nice hint of malt. Sweet with a lingering bitterness. Simple.

Medium-bodied with a crisp finish.

11/7/03:  bottle.  
 freshly hopped nose, (possibly some Centennial hops were used).  light orange-brown body.  when poured the initial head size was medium-large and after settling there was a thin white head remaining.  minimal lacing.  high hop flavor with a hint of pine.  bitter hop finish.
Citrus hoppy, lemon, orange. The hops do not jump out at ya, they are mild but this is rather smooth and drinkable. Nice session ale.

My favorite out of the bottle although tasted at Clyborn Brewpub.  Goilden with a heavy white head.  English malt is very  pronounced and nicely paired with american hops (goldings and centenials perhaps).  Fairly bitter with a floral and pine nose.  I like this IPA

Bottle:  Deep gold in color with a white head.  The aroma and flavor really did not impress.  The flavor just did not develop in the way I like.  I love IPAs, I like Goose Island, but I don't like the Goose Island IPA.  I'm glad I tried it, but I'm more glad that I got a single.

Nice earthy hop aroma. Not the citrusy, grapefruity, Cascade aroma that is oh so common in American IPA's. Good deep golden color. Light carbonation and a pillowy white head. Sturdy malt base, earthy hop flavor. I think this is a nice balanced beer. An English style IPA, not American. It won't blow your head off with hops, but that's nice once and a while! Well done!

UPDATE 2/1/05:  best when consumed by 042405 1244 / what? aroma of grapefruit and a bit of sweaty laundry. head that is very airy and diminishes into nothing in a pace that is too fast. palate seems less active than usual; perhaps a bit flat. bubblegum sweetness, with dry pine and juicy grapefruit hops. i’ve had much better bottles. downrated. UPDATE 3/12/05: best when consumed by 042405 1044 / snifter / awesome! a great bottle! the nose reminded me of Three Floyd’s Gumballhead, and so does the flavor. the body is a hazy amber with a white and tight head that diminishes while leaving lace, and then a nice thick ring around the glass is left. primarily bubblegum, pine, and grapefruit; crisp and smooth, not flat at all; sweet, bitter, then dry, then sweet again because i took another sip; not without a great punch this time around! i uprated all scores because this is what it truly is out of the bottle.
Reddish Brown, with a thick, uniform white head. Grapeftuit and raw hop aroma. Bitter, fruity, earthy hops right up front. Not balanced, but doesn't need to be. I like it.

12 oz bottle pours a slightly hazy light amber with a decent head and some lace.  The aroma was hoppy and slightly malty.  The flavor left me wanting more from an IPA, not hoppy enough and an off flavor in the malt backbone that I can't seem to pinpoint.  The palate was fine, but the flavor threw me.  I won't bother again...

Bottle.  Pours slightly cloudy, yellow-amber with a small off white head.  Aroma is nice, lots of floral hops, citrus and a hint of maple syrup in the sweet roasted malts.  Flavor starts out with mild sweet malts before being overrun with the bold hops and a lingering nutty flavor.  Medium body and smooth with perfect carbonation.  Really nice IPA - thanks Marinaro500.
GABF 2003:  Clear gold color with a large white head.  Pine aroma, with a full body.  Ends fairly bitter without much fanfare.
Somewhat grain-flavored, vegatables aroma mixed with pale hops and oranges.  Good palate scouring, but lacks the IPA kick I expect.  Can be bland and stale at times.

This year batch is very good and worthy of an rating increase, +1 Appearance (better head rentention) and +1 Flavor (hops in balance but still nicely bitter) and a +1 OVERALL, SO MUCH MORE ENJOYABLE, not that I did not enjoy it before. On tap Wrigleyville: Light copper hue with good head and lace. Aroma was piney and fruity with some roasted malt and grassy notes. The taste was very bitter initally, piney. The midsection of the drink showed some fruity twangy on the edge and solid malt presence in the middle of the palate. The finish was metallic and dry. Thin to medium-bodied with a lively mouthfeel. A solid IPA that isn’t as agressive as some Americans versions but far more the many traditional IPA’s from Britian. Crisp IPA with good hoppy character.
This beer smells and looks a lot better then it tastes.  Oh well, it makes Adam Sandler movies a whole lot funnier.
Orangish color with medium head. Not overwhelming with the hops aroma but solid.Hoppy bitter taste that finishes the same way. A average IPA
nothing special. just another wannabe IPA. I'm not a huge fan of ales in general, but this one wasnt as harsh as the other ales i've had. hoppy.

Attacked by hops was my first thought on this one.A strong almost overpowering hop taste hits the back of your mouth.After that a combination of fruit and some bitterness.But those hops are still there.A very pleasant beer but not for those who like run of the mill
tastes.

This brew poured a small head of fine to medium sized mostly diminsihing bubbles that left a uncarbonated light transparent orange yellow colored body behind.  It had a mild hop aroma atypical of most IPA's.  Its mouthfeel was bubbly anfd full of IPA hop flavor.  The flavor was typical of an IPA with strong hops notes.

Complex aroma with citrus, grapes, some tobacco, and lots of hops.  Light amber color with a very big, thick head.  Flavor of bitter hops.  Aftertaste is also bitter with some malt.  Medium bodied.  Well done.

Bottle. Bright dark golden color with a stady dark cream colored head. Pleasant freah hops aroma. Nose of mild grapefruit and just a hint of malt sweetness. Light piney flavors start with a finish that is a bit more malty and sweet. Light hops acids seem to carry their way through this one. I like this quite a bit but lacks malt depth english hops to send this one sailing to India. A very good APA.

dark orangeish-amber with a nice head. floral and citrus hop aroma. Nice flavor of flowers, pine, grapefruit and citrus,  pleasant change of pace with floral hops more prevalent. malt also balances nicely and  leads to a pleasant bitter hop finish.

On the teeter-totter of pine versus grapefruit, pine won this one.  So much so, in fact, that my bottle was actually infested by the southern pine beetle.  Unfortunately, piney IPAs are becoming rarer and rarer due to the affection of this peculiar insect for the resinous, bitter aroma of Pinus virginiana.  Luckily, I detected no sawflies, so I plunged into the glass with the fervor of a child opening Christmas presents.  And it was good.  Comes across as a lighter-bodied cousin of DFH 90 Minute IPA.  Aroma is piney, and the flavor is dynamic bitter hops and crisp malts.  Solid.

This was my first IPA and I guess I am not a fan of this style. Did nothing for me, I didnt like the sour-ness. someone mentioned Black currants, and that hit it on the head, tastes like gasoline to me. It did, however, have a nice pour. I will not give up on the IPA thing, maybe after a couple more I can get a taste for it.

Light amber color, frothy head. Strong hops and grapefruit aroma. Blackcurrant. Oily hoppy flavor  with blackcurrant and a bit of citrus. Hoppy, oily aftertaste. Very nice beer, big in aroma and taste, but maybe just a bit onedimensional.

12 years later: Bottle, golden color. Soft oily hops and grapefruit in the aroma. Oily grassy citric hopbityter flavor with hints of peach and pineapple. Tasty IPA, pleasant to drink.
Amber in color with an ample off white head. Aroma is floral and heavy hop. Flavor is slightly malt with an excellent smack of hops. Finish is somewhat dry with a smooth hops bite. An excellent brew.
Got a 6 of this while visiting my brother in Chicago.  Filled with strong hops (if not a little artificial).  A very good beer for its price.

Poured from the bottle a pure golden color with a big fluffy white head.  Floral aroma immediately filled my nose, and the hops create a fruity flavor and a nice finish.  A treat to have - thanks to my friend timdanchanta who found this one on a recent trip to the Windy City.

Wow this is pretty good.
I agree that if it wasn't for other truely outstanding IPA's such as Three Floyds Dreadnaught, this would be at the top of the list. It's close to it though. Has a nice aroma, poured nice dark golden color with a slight head remaining through the glass. Nice lacing along the way as well. Great flavor with hints of grapefruit. Good carbonation. This is another outstanding beer that you must try if you like IPAs, which are now part of my favorites list as I seem to have been getting really good ones lately. Do not pass Go, Just GO, and get some of this.
aroma.. flavour, plate it nice, good mouth feel nice and full. WOW I recomend this beer.

This is good beer, just not great beer.  If it weren't for all the truly outstanding IPAs I've had lately, I would probably be excited by this IPA.  The aroma is hops, not in huge amounts, but pleasent all the same.  Beer pours dark golden with nice thick head.  The head is retained throughout and there is heavy lacing.  Flavor is good, nice hop bitterness, but it seems to play out a bit too soon.  I also think this IPA lacks a true alcohol punch.

Had this one at the brew pub right down the street from Wrigley Field.  I was pleasantly surprised by this IPA.  Nice fruity aroma.  Starts lightly on the palate with a burst of hops in the end.  Long and tasty finish.
A good, solid IPA.  Sweet, clean, fresh aroma and fizzy, hoppy (lemon?) flavor.  I'd have it again.
(Draft IPA) Slightly cloudy amber-copper w/ persistent head. Fresh perfume-y, orange-y aroma. Firm, slightly resiny feel. Good malt profile w/ lots of clean bitterness. Long finish.

Lots of flavour, as you would expect from an American IPA. The nose and flavour were quite sweet fruity, and full of lychees and pine. The finish dries out a bit aswell, which definitely makes a bit more bearable. A good beer.
Tap @ GIBC, RBSG2003. Called the Draft IPA. Lacks some balance, but overall quite well done - fruity? Nah. Pine and earth all over. You've had this one many times.
The best of the geese, for me, so far. I've been fond of the Goose Island beers, and the hops in this one will please.

Color is a clear golden yellow with a thin white creamy foamed head, some spotty lace. This smells like an IPA, oh....so hoppy fresh. Nice estery aroma of peach and a bit of apple, super bright and strong on the nose, just as it should be. A treasure of pleasure to wiff. The taste is nicely bittered hop, firm & mild, lightly earthy, supreme drinking here. Has a waxy/oily feel and is quite full with dulled lightly bittering dryness, ...nice! I was surprised to say the least, the goose has landed, I'm impressed, good job on this IPA. Hopheads should be able to enjoy this I would think, I did, and I don't consider myself to be, but I know decent IPA's when I drink em and this fits right up there.

Pours a grand orange amber whatever color, with a decent head and a fairly lively carbonation. The head didn't last long but it has a pleasing strawberry aroma with some hops. Tasty and very well balanced with a smooth finish. I didn't find it near as hoppy as the last couple IPA's I've tried, but I think this is a very refreshing and well made brew.

Draft, at the brewery. Not a hophead’s IPA, but a good one to suggest to friends. All the homebrewers gathered at the brewery break room agreed the color was "orange." A nice fizzy head helps spread the hop aroma. Yes, there is hop bitterness, but as Dick Solomon on "Third Rock" said, "Not in that fun, spanky way." You also get a balanced fruity taste that matches the maltiness nicely. Well done, and in stores at popular prices.
Re-tasted, 2/6/04: Hmm... the hop component is getting stronger, if anything. Not "extreme" yet, but still good (and I ran my finger through a trash can of foam they were using for blow-off in this brew’s fermenter... mmm, bitter!
Light orange color, white head, good lacing. Aroma of beef stew simmering on the stove. Nice, mildly hopped brew. Not too bitter and worth buying again.

My Bottom Line:

Smooth caramel gets bitten by pine needles in this sweetish IPA which seems to sit between American versions and English Premium Bitters.



Further Personal Perceptions:

-A sheet of foam covers the shiny amber.

-This is not what I want at all from an IPA. My problem, I guess.

-The soft prickling and sugary cereals take too much room for my tastes in the style.

-Hop fruitiness is shy, surprisingly.



On tap at the brewery.
This is a good IPA.  Very floral hops aroma, nice citrus sensation, creamy mouthfeel.  Good head and lacing.  I like it a lot.

Love the hops! Big foam. I'm actually commenting on the nitro draft version, served at the original GI. The bottled version sort of wimps out but's still good.
************
Just had one on tap at the Goose and it's a changed beer. Golden, not a dark copper color as before, no nitro blend, just CO2 and it's lost a lot of the hop bite and fruitiness.

Hazy, light-golden color.  Kind of like a lighter bodied iced tea.  Citrus nose.  Quickly diminishing head.  Small amount of carbonation.  Fairly bitter flavor, hoppy.  Again, with citrus.  Pretty good representation of the style.

Again, another great value from Goose Island. This IPA is far better than most macro-brewed concoctions. The appearence of the ale and the head are lovely. The first whiff is delectable. Taste is refreshing with an extraordinary balance of hop flavours. Try this!

Good colour, orange with a light amber tint. A great smell for hop lovers...most likely very well dry-hopped. The taste was great too...very light in the mouth, but with a hoppy aftertaste that lingers perfectly. One of the better IPA's by a larger producer of beers.

On tap, Clybourn Ave.  Strong vegetable-rawhop aroma.  Nice golden color for an IPA.  Well-hopped, but a little sulphury, with pretzel and starchy flavors.  Good mouthfeel, but a little too bitter in the finish as though the hops were overboiled.
This is a very well balanced IPA. Not overly bitter like some on the market, but enough to satisfy your palate. Nice citrusy aroma. One of my favorites from the grocery store.

Orange colour as weak tea - virtually no head. Citrus-hops and preserved ginger, succade, in the nose. taste is very hop-bitter, noble hops. Bitter-herbal too. Again something as preserved dessert-ginger or khulfi. Quite refreshing, yet not light-bodied. A bit oily. Long bitterish aftertaste, giving an impression of hopextract. Nice American IPA, hyper-classical, but well worth the trouble.

I've got to stay away from these IPA's. Their just too bitter.

NOW I NEED 75 CHARACTERS TO DESCRIBE A BEER? What the fuck is going on. Okay, this beer tasted like the underside of a llama scrotum. I would have described it as a Goose scrotum considering the name, but I have never seen a scrotum on a goose. I would rather eat a dead dog's dick. If someone would have warmed up piss and mixed it with a touch of very fine diarrhea, I still would have requested they add cod sperm to get the desired taste. The aroma was much more like the smell one might encounter in the ass crack of a boat full of Haitians coming towards Florida. War never solved anything. Except for slavery and the holocaust and to a lesser extent, communism and facism. So go tell that to the flaming liberals who use that phrase as an excuse. Don Cherry was right....as he always is. And I'm an American, not a Canadian. Speaking of communism, isn't that what it is called when someone forces you to use more characters than you really need to in order to describe a beer. Either that, or it's called 6th grade. If anyone is looking for a really good band to check out, take a listen to Down. The lead singer is the singer from Pantera. The big difference here is that he sings. For those who are unfamiliar with Down, please download the song "Stone the Crow" and work from there. They are awesome \m/
nice aroma, good initial hop flavor. then turns dry and slightly sweet hiding hop flavor and the maltiness that I expected.  finnished sweet slightly dry
Beautiful color, bit of a let down on the flavor side.  Mild aroma and a bit of hoppy flavor, but not a much as expected in an IPA.
Although this is on the lighter end of IPA's, it did have a real refreshing "juicy" hop flavor - thickly citrus, with an easy drinking bitterness.  File this under "lawn-mowin' beers"

beautiful cloudy orange pour with a small white head that faded extraordinarily quickly. typical ipa citrus nose. smells like cascade. citrus hoppy flavor with a nice hoppy finish. nice full body, however, the best thing about this beer was its appearance; the rest is really pretty run of the mill ipa, in my opinion.

In a world full of IPAs, this doesn't do enough to keep up with the Jonses.  Lovely foaming white head, dissipating moderately slowly, rather light body color, golden-amber.  Floral but disappointing aroma.  Easy-drinking, a little bitter punch.  Only a mild hop presence that might have well been some peoples' pale ale. (on tap, Goose Island, Clybourn, Chicago)

A good quantity of hops gives this beer a clean crisp finish.  It is let down, however by being too strong, 5.9% is too much for an IPA, and the flavour of the hops is therefore cut too much by the alcohol.

It's slightly cloudy golden/copper. A small head is rather dissappointing at first pour, but it laces well. The aroma is awesome....citrusy hops. Zingy carbonation hits first, then hops of course. The hop character is powerful, yet not overdone or harshly bitter. The only strong bitterness is in the aftertaste and it's not annoying at all. The finish is dry and crisp. An awesome IPA, wonderful hop character and not overpowering.
Very hoppy aroma.  Copper colored with a good head.  Nice flavor.  Not terribly overpowering.  Good overall flavor.
Copper colored with a medium white head. Big hop aroma. Nice hop flavor thats not overpowering.

Big cascade hop nose.  Tons of fresh hop flavor.  Not a lot of malt, but the freshness of the hops is enough to make up for this shortcoming.  Not terribly complex, as it allows hops to tell the whole story.
Bottle - Nice floral and honey aroma.  The hops and malt mix well together in this IPA.    Has a nice citris finish.

Nice hop aroma with delicate golden brown color. Piney hops up front. Wish there was more malt in back to better balance the hops. Mild for an IPA but will buy it again. On draught I'll bet it is superb.

This one starts out with a big hoppy aroma (very nice, a little citrus touch...kind of like a milder version of the Alpha King aroma) and dark golden color with decent white head.  Flavor is mostly hoppy, but not overpoweringly so.  Decent finish, though it could last a TAD longer to make this beer better.  Overall, this is a nice, middle of the road IPA.  It could use a little more depth to the flavor, though the aroma is very nice.  If the taste of this beer was brought up to the aroma's level, it would be a very strong representative of IPAs.
Syrupy looking pale ale with a very hopped  ginger beer aroma and flavour.  An average beer.

Draft: This has a fresh hoppy aroma.  Pours a dark golden with thin lacy head.  Flavor is dry and oaky with a nice balance of malt and hops.  The finish is slightly astrigently bitter, but overall enjoyable.

Wow!  Great ale!  Fantastic hoppy nose with a massive grapefruit kick.  Pours  with an amber hue and a small creamy head that is mostly diminishing.  Flavour is initially sweet with great complex hoppy tones, but goes on to a dry finish.  This is a highly hopped beer (of course being an IPA) that has been a real eye opener for me being the first American craft brewed offering I have sampled.   The question that most begs to be answered is why do I have to go to a specialist to get this kind of American beer?  Especially when perhaps the worst selection of beers in the world, American standard beer, is common place here in Britain.  They give American beer a bad name.  If this is what America has to offer then I just want more...
sharp hoppy nose, little head or lacing, cloudy bronze hue, very hoppy, touches of yeast,  pretty good ale

Bottle (2005, fresh): enormous, large bubbled and rocky white head above a clear, light gold body.  The large froth diminishes, but leaves nice lace and a thin film.  Sweet, sugary pine/grapefruit aroma with a bit of resiny vanilla.  Stong, underlying bitterness, but quick to leave the palate with a clean finish.  A pretty good for about $6.50 for a 6-pack.


Draught, Clybourn brewpub: Very light yellow straw.  Sweet floral aroma, probably the best part of this beer. . . good lace.  Small grapefruits, but mostly floral flavours on the tongue.  Not complex: hops upfront in your face, but they diminish quickly and disappear completely just after swallowing.

Not a big fan of IPA’s.  Too much hop, which just peels the taste buds off my tongue. This has all the ingredients of an IPA, nice aroma, the necessary bite of hops, which all Goose Island beers have.  One was enough.  (2/2/2/1/8).
re-rate;  talk about a change in palate, I now consider this a session beer.  Either my tongue has been burnt through or they changed the recipie as this is not nearly as bitter as I remember.  In fact I was reminiscening with someone about the first time I tried this and how bitter it was and would like to re-live that experience again.  Well not with this beer.  Decent hop aroma and like their Honkers skewed toward the English style.  Mildly bitter.  An average example.  Score reflects re-rate.

Cloudy golden color. Thin head. Little lace. Big American-style-IPA aroma. Bitter finish is like sucking on grapefruit rind.  It is a world better on tap at the brewpub than out of the bottles--much fresher, more vibrant and actually worth drinking.
Wow, this is good. Toasty, with a touch on the malty side and so not quite as dry as I like them. Some citric notes. A softened feel, big foam, very clear. Robust and strong.

Bottle conditioned. Hazy gold, poor head and moderate condition. First aroma was like opening a new pocket of hops followed by a grapefruity citrusness. Underlying caramel in the mouth gets clobbered by aggressive citrus hops and a harsh hop bitterness in the finish makes it a little unbalanced for me. Not in the league of the Dogfish Head IPA or Victory Hop Devil, but what is.
hops, hops and more hops- great american ipa................................

Straw colored, medium-thick head with good lacing.  Aroma of Fuggles-hoppy and a little skunky.  In the mouth this beer tastes hoppy, but not bitter.  As you swallow the tastes are that skunky hop flavor and a hint of peach.  Decently balanced and definately drinkable-if you enjoy a well-hopped beer.

Very citrusy. Hoppy enough, I suppose, but finishes with a bit of a sweet taste that doesn’t seem quite right. Also, the tail end of the hops flavor is capsicum-type spicy: burns the tongue a little. Not much in the way of appearance or mouthfeel. Re-rate 12/05: Didn’t take detailed notes this time, but I did enjoy this much more than the first time I had it. Very fresh hoppy character and clean all around.
A tremendous amount of bite and tons of Fuggles and Cascades get the job done here.  Ugh.
Bottle:Amber color, off white head. Floral grapefruit hop nose.Decently hopped but not overpowering. Good body

Nice ambery peachy colour.  Big floral, fruity aroma.  Taste matches aroma well, with good IPA flavours.  Not as bitter as some better IPAs.  Very smooth.  Good finish and an ejoyable beer from a friend who brought this back from the brewery.
Light amber pour.  Medium head that falls fast.  Unfortunate bitterness that ruins the beer.  Highly hopped, which makes  my stomach cry for Pepto or Tums later on.  I just don't dig the hops.
Good hop aroma present.  Assertive level of bitterness, but seems slightly overdone or unbalanced.  Enjoyable but not as smooth as others in the style range.
I''m not an IPA fan really, so giving it this rating needs to be taken as a compliment.  It''s not a bad IPA.

On the "bitter" side of IPA's... similar to Sierra Nevada or Anchor in the "bitter" style.  My Favorite Goose Island brew... There's a few IPA's I might like slightly better, but this is OVER a 4.00 beer.  I'm never disappointed to drink this.  HINT! To reduce bitterness, double or Triple-pour it from one glass to the other. Needs aereation.

Slight hop aroma.  Medium bodied.  Not as hoppy as 
i would have expected but still enjoyable.
I wasn't wildly impressed, I did like the citrusy nature (it's definitely worthwhile to try) but there are better IPAs out there.

i dont want to bash on these guys because they do good work but this just wasn''t what i was looking for just to much hop for this guy to handle so i''ll give it the middle of the road rate i''m sure this is someones favorite just not mine
A commendable US IPA.  A cut-grass freshness and good hops bite is presesnt.  Still, White Shield and Empire Pale Ale rule.  Try 'em if you can.
Pour with a nice head.  Light amber in color and little cloudy.  Aroma of hops.  Taste fruity, sweet and bitter from the hops.  Not crazy bitter.  A very enjoyable IPA.

Had a few (3) bottles of this after I returned home from the Buckeyes game.  Fresh nose
of pine and citrus.  Pours a light sparkling amber.  The large rocky white head is fully
lasting with excellent lacing.  The flavor is bitter and warm with moderate to heavy
acidity.  The brew finishes strong with citrus overtones and a nice heavy bitterness.  The
light creamy body has lively carbonation and finishes dry.

Gold color, medium head. Mildly hopped with very pleasant aromatic hops. This is a slightly sweet malted IPA. This is not a traditional IPA in that it is not real hoppy, but it does have a very nice hop signature without being overpowering. Finish is smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Very well done.  Exceeded my expectations, especially from this brewery.  Nicely hopped, with a good aftertaste.

A rough pour yields a dense white head which quickly dissipates to a bubbly ring atop the clearest amber one could imagine..  Aroma is dry-hopped to hell baby; reminds me of a hop vineyard; only the freshest flowers here alongside oranges and pine.  Front is somewhat light, middle is hoppy with citric/slighlty sour twang that transitions superbly into a very lasting toasted malt finish.  Fresh hops leave a nice residue in the mouth for some time.  This is about as clean and crisp as an IPA can get.

This is an extremely tasty treat. Excellent hoppy aroma.  Pale golden color.  Pretty good balance between sweeet maltiness and powerful hoppiness.  Could use just a touch more caramel sweetness.  The IPA this is most reminiscent of to me is the Sweetwater, just not quite as good.  Still excellent though.

Very satisfying throughout.  It does have a slightly fruity aroma, which leads into a malty flavor.  The hops are very apparent, which makes the finish even better.  Extremely drinking and nice on the palate.
As an IPA fan, I was impressed with this beer.  It had a little more maltiness than I expected, but the degree of hopping was very nice.  A good balancing act, according to my palate...
Nice and hoppy, the way a beer should be. Citrusy hops overwhelm the flavor here, but it still makes for a very tasty beer.
pretty good ipa.  although as it warmed it lost some of its kick.  i think i prefer sierra nevada although not technically an IPA.

August 2002: On tap at Hopleaf, Chicago.  Very fruity, more malty than usual, very sweet but reasonably hoppy; berry-like quality to the nose and flavor; body is on the lightish side; nose not terribly distinctive.  First beer from this brewer I've had in a few years; I'll have more.6/3/7/3/14=3.4

Hmmm, my notes are about the same 2 years later, but I think I just appreciate the style much more.  More fruitiness and distinctiveness to the nose and a better body as well, I think.  On tap (CO2) at the brewpub this time.
Intense hops aroma and taste, very drinkable although not overly satisfying or refreshing.  If you want to know what hops tastes like, try this beer.

Very fresh aroma - newly mown grass clippings, heavy rain in the evergreens, just grated lemon zest.  All of this adds up to a wicked dry punch of hop bitters in the mouth, with enough malt presence and body to pull it off.  Clearly the best Goose Island offering I've had.

A good answer to the question, ’What do hops taste like?’.  Piney, grassy, citrusy, the aroma is the best part of this beer.  Flavor is all hops without much else to get in the way.  Will satisfy any hop craving.

(draft) Clear light copper body with medium head.  Very strong pine aroma.  Pine/grapefruit flavor, but not overwhelming.  Nice carbonation keeps it nice on the tongue.  Fairly dry finish.  It's good, but one can only consume pine for so long -- definitely not a session beer.

Rerate:Too generous first time.   Bottle conditioned but you cant't tell except for the bubbles on the head. Pours highly carbonated but minimal,milky,lacey head.The head is quality but small. Aroma straight fruity,piney.Taste is very BITTER. There might be malts their but I can't tell.EXREMELY drinkable.Full flavored till the end but not a knockout. This beer is barely balanced.This will satisfy any hop craving.
Not your typical IPA but definitely exploding with hops.  Very good beer....

I had the Draft IPA at the pub and it is better than the bottle.  There is a huge hop nose and a great cascading head.  The color is deep yellow.  The flavor is very spicey with strong citrus notes.  Very clean finish.

Crisp aroma, bright and floral.  Tangy, sweet, and great balance.  Lovely hoppy remnants linger in my mouth long after I've finished, which is ideal.   Texture is maybe a touch thin, but this just adds to its drinkability; not really a session beer, but I could put away a sixer of this without thinking.  Readily available around here, so a perfect beer for quenching my thirst for hop.

It poured a copper golden color and left a nice white head that left some nice lace. A little bit of carbonation. It had an aroma of hops and some hops and some citrus. The taste was of hops, citrus and malt. The finish was a touch dry and bitter with elements of the forementioned, which was good. I found this to be a great IPA for the money(at least in my state). While not the best by far, a good IPA for those that aren't trying to break the bank.
Damn fine American IPA.  Loaded with hops, this one will not leave you disappointed.  Piney aroma and a grapefruit after taste.  Wonderful out of the bottle.
Had it in Cincy. Nice hop bitter. A good IPA. Not great, but I would buy it again.
a tad harsh for an ipa.  has a very raw taste to it.........................

This review must be considered on two opposing sides.  To the good:  This is by far the best
*Goose Island* product I've had.  I very much dislike the "musty" quality of most of their brews, and that's essentially missing here (Halleluiah!).
On the negative side:  This is not a terribly good IPA (my favorite brew).  The nose is
good, the mouthfeel is tasty and correct, though a  bit light-bodied, and (unusual for Goose Island) not much malt.
The finish is awful.  The hop flavor vanishes, and you are left with the unmistakable taste of City of Chicago
Water.  But I give any brewer willing to try and put out a good IPA extra credit.  Bell's "Two Hearted" ale, and even Arcadia's IPA
are much better, though.
Smelled great, the hops kicked ass throughout actually.  Not as bitter as the traditional IPA, but it had a great flavor.  We will say, good beer but not overly indicative of the style.
Dry and hoppy, crisp, definitely a notch above the standard micro IPA.......

Clear golden body with a thick, fluffy white head.  Earthy hops and grainy malt are the predominate forces in the aroma.  Noble hops, light pine, whole, toasted grains, mild apple, citrus fruit (orange and grapefruit), sweet caramel, musky perfume and some oily nuts.  The body is not full, but also not too thin.  The carbonation is light and smooth, making for easy drinking.  Sweet and fruity up front, the flavors eventually turn to the bitterness of the ample hop content.  The bitterness is intense, but not bracing or tongue scraping, as the hops are not those crazy, super high Alpha Acid hops, but subtle, earthy and pungent beauties.  I could drink this all the time, I’m convinced.  Neither too hoppy nor too sweet.  Balanced, tasty and smooth.  Well done.

6/3/2002This was a surprisingly good IPA.  Nice aroma and body.  A pleasant surprise.  8 - 4 - 8 - 3 - 16:  3.9

A very nice IPA, and living nearby, it's always super-fresh! This weekend I bought a fresh sixpack and started drinking the first one right off the shelf(warm) and it was a very enjoyable experience. The hoppy nose was evident from 3 ft!
(draft) Golden yellow, beautiful head. Fruity/hoppy nose. Just a sip of the head revealed the hops in this badboy. Medium bodied with tons of malt and even more hops, excellent IPA.

excellent brew..wonderful hoppiness and an egg-shell white creamy head that stuck around to the end! great effort. just finishing another 6-pack of this, and i have to say the pine character in the flavor is just incredible...just a shade under Yulesmith and Hog Heaven
I'm not a big Goose Island fan but I did enjoy this beer.  This has everything an IPA should.  More hop flavor wouldn't hurt.  The aroma is top notch.
Maybe I got a bad bottle or something, but I found this to be quite bad.....
India Pale Ale is just not my thing. There is always something about them that almost gives me a tounge stinging sensation.  But this one does get points for a really great aroma.

I'm not always a big fan of IPAs, but I could't find much wrong with this. Great hops ratio and better coloring than your typical IPA. This and Samuel Smith's are both IPAs that kind of transcend the norm.

12 oz. bottle, pours clear light amber color, nice head, leaves a lace in the glass. A flowery strong piney aroma, medium body, balanced malt and alot of hops, I like this IPA one of Goose Island best brews. I can put down a few.
For a solid, everyday IPA, hard to beat.....................................

Amber coloured. Huge flowery, citric hoppiness in the aroma. A firm body, but as in most American IPAs everything revolves around the hops. Need I say "bitter finish"? Really tasty, if you like American hops. I do!
One of the better IPAs I have had.  Smooth and hoppy makes this a beer full of flavor and is very enjoyable.

A good IPA that represents the IPAs very well. Gret complex flavor and a fruity aroma makes it a pleasent beer to drink.  Its only flaw is a somewhat thin body.  very nice citrus notes and wonderful centennial hop aroma.
Strong hoppy flavor, nice amber color.  One of the better American IPA's....

Clear-golden with a frothy-white head. Leans toward a British-style IPA, but it does have a good snappiness to it. Smooth maltiness with pleasant notes of nuts and bread. Overall, it’s very rounded, fruity and floral, and it’s highly quaffable.

pretty close to a true amber: i borrowed a girlfriend's amber earring to compare: the goose island, with it's very light haze only lacks a little petrified gnat to make it identical. pantone 138 (that's graphic designer talk for "brown orange").  them little bubbles on top are adequate,  they don't hold the fragrance down, (as if they could), and an aromatic abundance of orangey-hops are free to move about the cabin.  very fresh and clean smelling: perhaps surgical equipment should be disinfected in a good india pale ale.  considering the price and availability (both good- out here in the rust belt anyway), though it's not hugely distinctive, this is a noble, work horse ale.
Good, but nothing real distinctive.  Your pretty standard IPA.  Tastes great at the key shop, in the new basement, or the back of a Honda.
Yum...fantastic aroma.  It made me say "wow" out loud.  Good description from TrappistAlesRule - this is a fine brew.  Think I'll crack another...

Ass-kicking hop flavor. Initially there was a bit of a clash of the hops with its malty body, but they soon balanced into a great beer. Re-rate addition: The nitro tapped version of this is a disappointment--gives it a creamy, inappropriately smooth mouthfeel. This helped me understand what CAMRA guys have against nitro--this is really better in the bottle than after undergoing the nitro treatment.
Pretty good IPA.  It has a grapefruity taste to it.  .......................

Now this is what I'm talking about!  Great bright color, citric, piney aroma, tremendous bitter flavor and aftertaste, with just enough malt to keep it even.  Big Daddy fans will really like this one.  Certainly the best non-West Coast IPA I've had to date.

Incredible presence of hops on the nose and on the finish, strong caramel notes with a touch of sweet grapefruit. Impressive hop finish with a pine needle flavor, ever so slightly off balance, medium length.  Crisp and refreshing, one of my go-to summer brews.
I am sucker for IPAs, and enjoy this from the bottle at home or on tap, when I'm in Chicago.
Very hoppy - enjoyable.  Citric hoppy (grapefruit, a little orangey).  Hops abundant in flavor and aroma.  Medium body keeps it well rounded.
A wonderful IPA.  Pronounced floral hops with distinctive lemon character.  Bittering just shy of too much.  Very refreshing with a finish that reminds me of Earl Gray tea.
Strong hop aroma and flavor. pleasant aftertaste. Good stuff................

Not a bad IPA.  Seemed a little on the mellow side for an IPA.  It had the characteristics of an English IPA in that the hop flavor was smooth and made way for the malt flavor.  Not a typical overpowering American style IPA, but a good drink nonetheless.
Not the best IPA around but well worth the time, lacks abit of the complexity of some of the Westies. I still love it(in the bottle, crap on tap in most places).

Highly fruity hop aroma, citric and floral, with just a small amount of toasty, sweet malt apparent.  Medium golden color with a lasting, fine head.  Flavor profile is appropriately full of juicy hop flavor and bitterness, some grapefruit and lemon, and just enough malt to keep the hops from being too dominating.  Palate is quenching and lightly creamy, body is light-medium.  Refreshing and tasty.
Nice hoppy flavor and aroma with a hint of citrus and piney acidic bite. Nice alcohol effect and addictiveness...

Hop aroma, flavor and bitterness comes out of this beer and slaps you in the face! The brewery uses Cascade and Fuggles and I think the Fuggles really come through in the aroma well!  This beer is closer to a English IPA than an American one, well crafted and clean.  Malt flavors in the background balance out the huge hop bill.  If you are a hophead this is the beer for you.
I love Goose Island beers, but I hate IPA's, so this one loses out..........

Bottle rating (April 2005):  Golden colour.  Arom is deep hops.  Cleansing bitterness, woody, slightly oxidized.  Flavours are rather blunt - needs a punch of pale malt or a slap of citrus to come alive.Tap rating (from March 2000):  Fantastic aroma with big American hops.  But they serve this on nitrogen and that just makes the flavours collapse into a jumbled mess.  Probably much better on bottle/cask/CO2.  Ar 8; Ap 2; F 3; P 2; O 6
Zippy Doo Dah, a hoppy and spicy IPA, one of the better beers from this fine brewery, If you like hops, try this beer.
